EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon on July 1st through the 4th. However, slightly cooler and drier air were able to mix into the area on the 5th, resulting in slightly lower heat indices.

A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 111-114F for nearly four hours from 130 to 515 PM CDT on May 22, 2024. By proxy, and data from northern Kenedy (1 hour of 111 to 112 heat index during this window), it can be inferred that inland Willacy County had similar heat index values for a similar period of time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: By proxy, between locations in northern Kenedy and in northern Cameron County, Willacy County is assumed to have observed heat index values between 111 and 114F between 1 and 430 PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure over the region resulted in above normal temperatures across the region. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, two heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time. One fatality also occurred in La Paz County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Heat Advisory was in effect for parts of North and Central Texas generally along and east of I-35 and south of I-20 from May 25th through the 27th. Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees each afternoon in these locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached or exceeded 105 across the county each afternoon from May 25th through May 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A developing atmospheric heat dome began to influence the mid Valley at the start of the week before Memorial Day 2024, as temperatures soared into the upper 90s to low-mid 100s beginning May 20th.  The combination of heat and humidity would push feels like temperatures to 111F or higher, the level for a Heat Advisory in the region.  Similar or worse conditions would continue through the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Weather Observing System at the South Texas International Airport, 11 miles north of Edinburg and along the south/north Hidalgo line, recorded 2.5 hours of heat index of 111 or higher, peaking at 113F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A developing atmospheric heat dome began to influence the mid Valley at the start of the week before Memorial Day 2024, as temperatures soared into the upper 90s to low-mid 100s beginning May 20th.  The combination of heat and humidity would push feels like temperatures to 111F or higher, the level for a Heat Advisory in the region.  Similar or worse conditions would continue through the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Weather Observing System at the South Texas International Airport, 11 miles north of Edinburg and along the south/north Hidalgo line, recorded 2.5 hours of heat index of 111 or higher, peaking at 113F, between 435 and 635 PM.  McAllen/Miller International Airport had more than five hours of heat index of 111 to 115 between 130 and 730 PM, peaking during the late afternoon. Weslaco had just under two hours of 111 or higher, peaking just under 112F, between 435 and 625 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 3 to 6 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona resulting in moderate Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death of two individuals found in desert areas. These individuals were in Sam Simon and Sells, respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 3 to 6 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona resulting in moderate Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death of one individual found in desert areas in Cochise County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures at near normal were experienced across the Tucson area on August 28. The high in Tucson was 97 degrees and minor Heat Risk category was reached. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An strong upper level ridge situated itself over western Washington over several days, resulting in multiple high temperature records broken across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 90 degrees was set at KSEA airport on September 5th, breaking the old record of 88 degrees set in 1973.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An strong upper level ridge situated itself over western Washington over several days, resulting in multiple high temperature records broken across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 89 degrees was set at WFO Seattle on September 5th, breaking the old record of 88 degrees set in 1944.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper-level ridge of high pressure centered over the Midwest brought very hot weather to central Illinois on August 26th and 27th.  High temperatures were mostly in the lower to middle 90s on August 26th, but climbed into the 95-100 degree range on the 27th.  With dewpoints hovering in the upper 70s to near 80 degrees, heat index readings peaked from 105 to 115 degrees along and north of the I-72 corridor during the afternoon of August 27th.  While no heat-related deaths were reported, this was the hottest period of weather across central Illinois during the entire summer of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index readings peaked at 105-110 degrees during the afternoon of August 27th.  No heat-related deaths were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A seasonably hot and humid day was observed across central Illinois on August 24th as afternoon high temperatures topped out in the upper 80s to around 90 degrees and heat index values peaked in the middle to upper 90s.  A one year-old child died of hyperthermia after being left unattended in a hot vehicle for several hours in Normal in McLean County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A one year-old child was left unattended in a hot car for several hours in Normal in McLean County.  The McLean County coroner ruled the child's death occurred due to hyperthermia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built over the Pacific Northwest for a big period of warmer and drier conditions - with the warmest temperatures of the year so far in the calendar year.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 64 degrees was set at Olympia Airport on March 15th, breaking the old record of 63 degrees set in 1962.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built over the Pacific Northwest for a big period of warmer and drier conditions - with the warmest temperatures of the year so far in the calendar year.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 74 degrees was set at KSEA airport on March 16th, breaking the old record of 72 degrees set in 1947.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level ridge settled over Texas allowing temperatures to soar above 105 degrees on the 20th. These excessive temperatures continued on the 21st and 22nd. High temperatures reached 107 degrees at Burnet, Pleasanton, New Braunfels, and Horseshoe Bay on the 20th. On the 21st temperatures climbed higher with highs of 110 at New Braunfels and Burnet. On the 22nd highs reached 109 at Llano and New Braunfels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level ridge settled over Texas allowing temperatures to soar above 105 degrees on the 20th. These excessive temperatures continued on the 21st and 22nd. High temperatures reached 107 degrees at Burnet, Pleasanton, New Braunfels, and Horseshoe Bay on the 20th. On the 21st temperatures climbed higher with highs of 110 at New Braunfels and Burnet. On the 22nd highs reached 109 at Llano and New Braunfels.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the end of August, ridging was noted across the eastern two-thirds of the CONUS. This upper-level pattern and associated surface high pressure system brought afternoon highs in the upper 90s and low 100s in addition to dew points in the 70s and lower 80s to much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. As a result, excessive heat was experienced by many the afternoons of both the 25th and the 26th, where heat indices ranged from 110 to 125 degrees during peak heating in the afternoon. |By the 26th, a shortwave trough ejected into the Pacific Northwest and moved across the northern Rockies. Isolated supercells developed the afternoon of the 26th along a weakening cold front that was slowly pushing south into northern Nebraska. While most of the severe weather from these storms remained north and west of the Omaha NWS County Warning Area, one supercell did make its way into portions of northeast Nebraska bringing hail up to 3.25 inches in diameter.|By the 29th, another shortwave trough ejected into the northern Plains immediately behind the disturbance that brought large hail to portions of northern Nebraska on the 26th. A surface low-pressure associated with this disturbance developed in south-central Canada, with a secondary low pressure that developed near the North Dakota-South Dakota border. A surface cold front was also noted as extending from northeast South Dakota into eastern Colorado. Scattered thunderstorms developed along and ahead of this front across much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the early afternoon hours. While most of these thunderstorms remained under severe limits, there were a few instances of wind gusts ranging from 60 to 70 miles per hour, and one report of quarter sized hail from northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonets in Davis and Daykin measured peak heat indices ranging from 110 to 116 degrees during the afternoon hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two consecutive days of excessive heat were observed in Page County. The first afternoon, the Clarinda AWOS measured a max heat index of 113 degrees. During these two days, the Clarinda AWOS had periodic data outages, so the peak heat index may have been higher. The following afternoon, a 114 degree heat index was measured by a mesonet station in Essex.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across portions of southeast Arizona July 3 through July 4. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation on July 3 and July 4. Additionally, heat was a contributing factor of death for an individual in Tucson on July 3.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced in Tucson on July 3rd, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The high temperature in Tucson was 106 degrees. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the death of one individual found at their residence in Tucson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 3 to 5 degrees above normal were experienced across portions of southeast Arizona July 15. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation and near San Simon in Cochise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 3 to 5 degrees above normal were experienced in Cochise County resulting in moderate Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for an individual found in the desert near San Simon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across the Tucson area on July 13. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the cause of death for two individuals in Tucson on July 13.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across the Tucson area on July 13. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the cause of death for two individuals in Tucson on July 13.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon highs in the low 100s and dew points in the mid 70s brought dangerous heat indices to the area for two consecutive afternoons. On the 25th, the Plattsmouth AWOS recorded a heat index of 111 degrees. The following afternoon, a mesonet station 2 miles east of Plattsmouth recorded a 110 degree heat index.

While most of the severe weather from these storms remained north and west of the Omaha NWS County Warning Area, one supercell did make its way into portions of northeast Nebraska bringing hail up to 3.25 inches in diameter.|By the 29th, another shortwave trough ejected into the northern Plains immediately behind the disturbance that brought large hail to portions of northern Nebraska on the 26th. A surface low-pressure associated with this disturbance developed in south-central Canada, with a secondary low pressure that developed near the North Dakota-South Dakota border. A surface cold front was also noted as extending from northeast South Dakota into eastern Colorado. Scattered thunderstorms developed along and ahead of this front across much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the early afternoon hours. While most of these thunderstorms remained under severe limits, there were a few instances of wind gusts ranging from 60 to 70 miles per hour, and one report of quarter sized hail from northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon highs in the mid 90s and dew points in the upper 70s resulted in excessive heat across portions of the county for two consecutive afternoons. Both days, the Fremont AWOS recorded heat indices up to 110 degrees during the afternoon hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 3 to 5 degrees above normal were experienced across portions of southeast Arizona July 15. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation and near San Simon in Cochise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 3 to 5 degrees above normal were experienced on the Tohono O'odham Nation resulting in moderate Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for an individual found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across portions of southeast Arizona July 3 through July 4. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation on July 3 and July 4. Additionally, heat was a contributing factor of death for an individual in Tucson on July 3.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced on the Tohono O'odham Nation, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of one individual found in the desert near Topowa.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across portions of southeast Arizona July 3 through July 4. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation on July 3 and July 4. Additionally, heat was a contributing factor of death for an individual in Tucson on July 3.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced in Tucson on July 3rd, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The high temperature in Tucson was 106 degrees. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the death of one individual found at their residence in Tucson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level ridge settled over Texas allowing temperatures to soar above 105 degrees on the 20th. These excessive temperatures continued on the 21st and 22nd. High temperatures reached 107 degrees at Burnet, Pleasanton, New Braunfels, and Horseshoe Bay on the 20th. On the 21st temperatures climbed higher with highs of 110 at New Braunfels and Burnet. On the 22nd highs reached 109 at Llano and New Braunfels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level ridge settled over Texas allowing temperatures to soar above 105 degrees on the 20th. These excessive temperatures continued on the 21st and 22nd. High temperatures reached 107 degrees at Burnet, Pleasanton, New Braunfels, and Horseshoe Bay on the 20th. On the 21st temperatures climbed higher with highs of 110 at New Braunfels and Burnet. On the 22nd highs reached 109 at Llano and New Braunfels.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the end of August, ridging was noted across the eastern two-thirds of the CONUS. This upper-level pattern and associated surface high pressure system brought afternoon highs in the upper 90s and low 100s in addition to dew points in the 70s and lower 80s to much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. As a result, excessive heat was experienced by many the afternoons of both the 25th and the 26th, where heat indices ranged from 110 to 125 degrees during peak heating in the afternoon. |By the 26th, a shortwave trough ejected into the Pacific Northwest and moved across the northern Rockies. Isolated supercells developed the afternoon of the 26th along a weakening cold front that was slowly pushing south into northern Nebraska. While most of the severe weather from these storms remained north and west of the Omaha NWS County Warning Area, one supercell did make its way into portions of northeast Nebraska bringing hail up to 3.25 inches in diameter.|By the 29th, another shortwave trough ejected into the northern Plains immediately behind the disturbance that brought large hail to portions of northern Nebraska on the 26th. A surface low-pressure associated with this disturbance developed in south-central Canada, with a secondary low pressure that developed near the North Dakota-South Dakota border. A surface cold front was also noted as extending from northeast South Dakota into eastern Colorado. Scattered thunderstorms developed along and ahead of this front across much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the early afternoon hours. While most of these thunderstorms remained under severe limits, there were a few instances of wind gusts ranging from 60 to 70 miles per hour, and one report of quarter sized hail from northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A max heat index of 123 degrees was recorded by a mesonet station in Macy.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two consecutive afternoons of excessive heat were observed across Washington County. The first afternoon, a max heat index of 111 was observed at the Tekamah ASOS. The following day, heat indices up to 117 were reported across the county by ASOS and Nebraska Mesonet sites.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level ridge settled over Texas allowing temperatures to soar above 105 degrees on the 20th. These excessive temperatures continued on the 21st and 22nd. High temperatures reached 107 degrees at Burnet, Pleasanton, New Braunfels, and Horseshoe Bay on the 20th. On the 21st temperatures climbed higher with highs of 110 at New Braunfels and Burnet. On the 22nd highs reached 109 at Llano and New Braunfels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level ridge settled over Texas allowing temperatures to soar above 105 degrees on the 20th. These excessive temperatures continued on the 21st and 22nd. On the 22nd highs reached 109 at Llano and New Braunfels.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures were around normal across the Tucson Metro area on July 31st. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the death of one individual on July 31.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures at normal were experienced across the Tucson area on July 31. The high in Tucson was 99 degrees and minor Heat Risk category was reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the death for an individual in Tucson on July 31.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure both at the surface and aloft combined with a flow of moist air northward from the Gulf of Mexico resulted in excessive heat across parts of southeastern Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached 105F at Philadelphia International Airport and Northeast Philadelphia Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A third consecutive day of high temperatures reaching the triple digits across much of the North Platte River Valley in the Nebraska panhandle as afternoon highs climbed within a degree of all time August monthly records at Scottsbluff.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scottsbluff Airport ASOS station (KBFF) reported a maximum temperature of 106 degrees Fahrenheit, within a degree of the all time August monthly record high temperature.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The strong atmospheric pattern known as La Canicula, which features a high pressure ridge or heat dome, combined with sufficient surface moisture from light southeast winds to provide several hours of heat index (apparent temperature) at or above 111F each afternoon for several hours in portions of Cameron and southern Hidalgo County.  Other locations, including Willacy, Brooks, and Kenedy County, touched 111 for an hour or less, which is shy of local criteria for a heat event (111 or higher for at least 2 hours). ||There were no known direct injuries or fatalities from the heat, though local hospitalization records for the May through August period showed another year of high admittance rates due to heat-related stress.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System (ASOS) sensor at McAllen (KMFE) recorded a little more than 2 hours total of heat index values of 111F or higher between 2 PM and  530 PM CST, though the period was broken by a short break right around 4 PM (values just below 111F).  Peak heat index reached just below 112F during this window.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure both at the surface and aloft combined with a flow of moist air northward from the Gulf of Mexico resulted in excessive heat across parts of southeastern Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached 105F at Pottstown Limerick Airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached 106F at Robert J. Miller Airpark.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The strong atmospheric pattern known as La Canicula, which features a high pressure ridge or heat dome, combined with sufficient surface moisture from light southeast winds to provide several hours of heat index (apparent temperature) at or above 111F each afternoon for several hours in portions of Cameron and southern Hidalgo County.  Other locations, including Willacy, Brooks, and Kenedy County, touched 111 for an hour or less, which is shy of local criteria for a heat event (111 or higher for at least 2 hours). ||There were no known direct injuries or fatalities from the heat, though local hospitalization records for the May through August period showed another year of high admittance rates due to heat-related stress.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System (ASOS) sensor near Bayview (KPIL) recorded a peak heat index of 115F at around 1 PM CST, with around 2 hours at or above 111F between roughly 1230 and 230 PM CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A flat upper ridge sat over South Texas with above normal moisture and temperatures resulting in dangerously hot heat index values ranging from 110-120 in late May across a large portion of South Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat index values ranged from 110-115.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure both at the surface and aloft combined with a flow of moist air northward from the Gulf of Mexico resulted in excessive heat across parts of central and southern New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached 106F at Monmouth Executive Airport and 107F at Somerset Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 5 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson Metro June 21. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined heat to be a contributing factor in the death of one individual in Tucson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 5 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson Metro June 21. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined heat to be a contributing factor in the death of one individual in Tucson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures around 6 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson area. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor of death for an individual in Tucson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures around 6 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson Metro Area May 18 causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. Tucson International Airport topped out at 99 degrees. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the death of one individual.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions were observed across the region on this day. One fatality was reported, a young child locked in a vehicle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple broadcast media outlets reported the death of a 3 year old girl who was locked inside a vehicle located in the 1000 block of Parliament Lake Drive. The initial call was for a missing child and deputies arrived and discovered the child unconscious in the vehicle. Deputies rendered first aid and took the child to a hospital, where the girl was pronounced dead. Temperatures at the nearest weather station during this time were in the mid to upper 80s with dewpoints in the mid-60s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first triple digits of the season occurred starting May 27 in Tucson through the end of the month. The warmest day occurred on May 28 with a high of 103 in Tucson. Hot temperatures occurred throughout southeast Arizona. On May 28, Moderate Heat Risk category was reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the cause of death in one individual.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures around 6 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tohono O'odham Nation May 28. Highs of around 100-103 degrees occurred with moderate Heat Risk levels.  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of one individual on the Tohono O'odham Nation along a walking path.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon on July 1st through the 4th. However, slightly cooler and drier air were able to mix into the area on the 5th, resulting in slightly lower heat indices.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum heat index of 114 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat index values ranged from 115 to 123.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first of a three-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on July 15, 2024 across much of eastern New York. Heat indices (or feel-like temperatures) reached between 95 to 104 degrees mainly along the Hudson Valley region. ||The hot, humid environment contributed to the development of a cluster of thunderstorms that impact eastern New York in the evening hours of July 15th. Two broken lines of convection became severe in nature, leading to numerous reports of tree and wire damage in the Eastern Catskills and Mohawk Valley in addition to a few isolated reports in the Upper-Hudson Valley.

The first of a three-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on July 15, 2024 across much of eastern New York. Heat indices (or feel-like temperatures) reached between 95 to 104 degrees mainly along the Hudson Valley region. ||The hot, humid environment contributed to the development of a cluster of thunderstorms that impact eastern New York in the evening hours of July 15th. Two broken lines of convection became severe in nature, leading to numerous reports of tree and wire damage in the Eastern Catskills and Mohawk Valley in addition to a few isolated reports in the Upper-Hudson Valley.

The third and final day of a stretch of hot and humid conditions occurred on July 17, 2024 which reached dangerous levels in Dutchess County with heat index values (feels-like temperatures) reaching 95 to 104 degrees. ||A cold front tracking through eastern New York brought scattered showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon hours resulting in several instances of tree and wire damage, especially in Albany, Saratoga and Columbia counties.

A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave. Excessive heat conditions on 7/24 were limited to the Shasta Valley in central Siskiyou County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 07/20/24, reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 50 to 63 degrees. Reported high temperatures ranged from 97 to 106 degrees. On 07/21/24, reported low temperatures ranged from 55 to 68 degrees. Reported high temperatures ranged from 91 to 100 degrees. On 07/22/24, reported low temperatures ranged from 54 to 64 degrees. Reported high temperatures ranged from 96 to 105 degrees. On 07/23/24, reported low temperatures ranged from 56 to 66 degrees. Reported high temperatures ranged from 98 to 108 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A largely ridge-dominated pattern persisted, resulting in anomalously warm temperatures. These hot temperatures resulted in at least one instance of a heat related fatality. Despite the strong ridge, enough moisture continued to work into the area and help in the development of diurnal convection, some of which resulted in flash flooding over more rain sensitive areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 56-year-old woman was hiking on a trail near Quail Creek State Park and reportedly ran out of water. When found by first responders the woman was unresponsive, and despite attempting life-saving measures, she ultimately did not survive. Temperatures nearby look to have peaked between around 103F to 105F during the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The region witnessed three days of high heat and humidity in late July. Peak temperatures for the three day period included a high of 105 degrees measured at the South Dakota extension mesonet station 7 miles southwest of Hayes, 104 degrees at Pierre municipal airport and 103 degrees at the department of transportation weather station in Hayes. The South Dakota extension mesonet station 7 miles southwest of Hayes also observed a high temperature in excess of 100 degrees for all 3 days. ||In addition to the heat, high humidity with dewpoints in the low to mid 70s resulted in widespread heat index values at or above 100 degrees.  A public weather station in Pierre observed a heat index of 108 degrees on July 27th, with Pierre municipal airport measuring a peak heat index of 107 degrees on July 25th. 29 weather stations recorded a peak heat index of 100 degrees or higher on July 25th, 18 on the 26th and a total of 25 stations observed a heat index of 100 degrees or more on the 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure brought excessive heat to the coastal/Coquille Valley portion of the south central Oregon coast from July 4th through July 9th. The excessive heat extended all the way to the coast during the peak of the heat wave from July 5th through July 6th. Low temperatures were in the lower 50s to lower 60s, and high temperatures mainly in the mid 80s to mid 90s, except 100 to 107 degrees in the Coquille Valley on July 5th and 6th. Record high temperatures were reached at the Southwest Oregon Regional Airport in North Bend of 84 degrees on July 5th and 86 degrees on July 6th. The Oregon State Medical Examiner's Office reported a potentially heat related death of a 33 year old male on July 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot, humid conditions were present across portions of eastern New York on July 30, 2024 with dangerous heat indices (or feel-like temperatures) reaching 95 to 99 degrees in Washington County.
Hot, humid conditions were present across portions of eastern New York on July 30, 2024 with dangerous heat indices (or feel-like temperatures) reaching 95 to 99 degrees in Washington County.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon on July 1st through the 4th. However, slightly cooler and drier air were able to mix into the area on the 5th, resulting in slightly lower heat indices.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to Eastern Curry County and Josephine County for 6 consecutive days from July 4th through July 9th, and again on July 13th. Advisory level conditions occurred on July 10th through 12th. During the excessive heat, low temperatures were generally in the lower 50s to lower 60s, and high temperatures from 100 to 110 degrees. But, peak readings were recorded on July 6th of 115 degrees at the Agness RAWS, 112 at the Merlin RAWS, and 114 degrees at the Parkside School in Grants Pass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to the Eastern Douglas County Foothills for 5 consecutive days from July 5th through July 9th, and on July 13th. Advisory conditions occurred from July 10th through July 12th. During the excessive heat, low temperatures were generally in the lower 50s to mid 60s, and high temperatures in the mid 90s to 108 degrees. But, a peak reading was recorded on July 6th of 110 degrees at the Buckeye RAWS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to the South Central Oregon Cascades for 5 consecutive days from July 5th through July 9th, and on July 13th. Advisory conditions occurred from July 10th through July 12th. During the excessive heat, low temperatures were generally in the lower 50s to lower 60s, and high temperatures in the lower 90s to 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures across Eastern Washington  ranged  from 98 to 110. The heat caused roads to buckle in Whitman County near Rosalia on July 9.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Washington DOT reported road buckling at US195 in two locations south of Rosalia. First location quickly repaired with a second location reported just south of the first one.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge that had been persistent across the Southern Plains to start the first several days of July finally began to shift off to the east, in response to an upper trough moving into the area. This trough allowed a weak cool front to slowly progress south through Southern Oklahoma, Western and Central Arkansas during the 5th, where increased large scale forcing and a moist, unstable air mass focused scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front. However, compressional warming occurred along and just south of the front over portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana, where temperatures were able to climb into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. When combined with the humidity, heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees. These storms gradually spread south into Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and extreme Northeast Texas during the afternoon of the 5th, resulting in cooler temperatures across Southern Arkansas by mid-afternoon.
A long stretch of hot temperatures across western Washington caused numerous records to broken during the beginning of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A high temperature of 93 degrees was set at Seattle-Tacoma airport on July 7th breaking the old record of 90 degrees in 2010. A high temperature of 92 degrees was also set at WFO Seattle on July 7th breaking the old record of 89 degrees set in 1945.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long stretch of hot temperatures across western Washington caused numerous records to broken during the beginning of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A high temperature of 97 degrees at Olympia Airport on July 7th broke the previous record of 95 degrees in 1953.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several mesonets in the county measured peak heat indices around 110.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions overspread much of the region on July 15 and July 16, resulting in the hottest temperatures of the Summer in 2024. Heat index values reached and exceeded 100 to 110, with daily record high temperatures tied and set.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS at Front Royal-Warren County Airport (KFRR) measured a peak heat index value of 106, with a high temperature of 102F. Several mesonets in the county measured peak heat indices around 105.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to Jackson County for 6 consecutive days from July 4th through July 9th, and on July 13th. Advisory conditions occurred from July 10th through July 12th. During the excessive heat, low temperatures were generally in the lower 50s to lower 60s, and high temperatures from 100 to 110 degrees. But, peak reading were recorded on July 6th of 112 degrees at the Rogue Valley International Airport, and 113 degrees in the cities of Rogue River and Central Point. Record high temperatures at Rogue Valley International Airport in Medford of 105 degrees on July 4th, 109 degrees on July 5th,  112 degrees on July 6th, 108 degrees on July 7th, 108 degrees on July 8th, and 107 degrees on July 9th. The Oregon State Medical Examiner's Office reported potentially heat related deaths of a 54 year old male on July 6th, and a 55 year old male on July 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built westward over the Mojave Desert, leading to another spell of extreme heat. Thirty-four people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on six straight days. Thirty-four people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes during and immediately after the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid level ridge intensified over Texas and the Southern Plains towards the end of July through the first part of August. Triple digit high temperatures with heat indices at or above 105 were common across the majority of the region from July 29 through the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached or exceeded 105 degrees at the end of July, extending into early August.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Heat Advisory was in effect for parts of North and Central Texas generally along and east of I-35 and south of I-20 from May 25th through the 27th. Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees each afternoon in these locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached or exceeded 105 across the county each afternoon from May 25th through May 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across East Texas on the 3rd through the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very warm temperatures with highs in the lower to mid 90s paired with oppressive dew point readings in the upper 70s to lower 80s produced afternoon and evening heat indices generally from 100 to 120 degrees with little overnight recovery. The most widespread oppressive conditions occurred during the afternoon and evening on July 13, with a secondary peak of heat across far southeast South Dakota on July 15.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daily afternoon and evening heat indices ranged from 100 to 105 degrees with a maximum heat index of 105 degrees at the South Dakota Road Weather Information System site near Alexandria on July 13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge aloft led to triple digit temperatures and heat index values of 105+ across much of the region during the first week of July. A Heat Advisory was needed for all but the western-most counties (where slightly drier air was in place), and an Excessive Heat Warning was even needed for 110+ degree heat indices across some North Texas counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached or exceeded 105 degrees across the county during the afternoon hours from late June through July 4th. In addition, excessive heat conditions with heat index values at or slightly over 110 degrees occurred on July 2nd when an Excessive Heat Warning was in effect.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very warm temperatures with highs in the lower to mid 90s paired with oppressive dew point readings in the upper 70s to lower 80s produced afternoon and evening heat indices generally from 100 to 120 degrees with little overnight recovery. The most widespread oppressive conditions occurred during the afternoon and evening on July 13, with a secondary peak of heat on July 15.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daily afternoon and evening heat indices ranged from 100 to 108 degrees with a maximum heat index of 108 degrees at a personal weather station in Terril, 107 degrees at a personal weather station in Wahpeton, and 106 degrees at a personal weather station near Lake Park on July 13. Heat index values returned to 100 degrees in Milford and Terril on July 15.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure aloft setup over the West Coast, centered over portions of California. This system was nearly stationary which brought a prolonged stretch of hot temperatures to northwest Oregon and southwest Washington. Temperatures ranged from 95 to 105 degrees during this time.  There were 12 suspected heat related fatalities with this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hottest period was from the 5th to 9th where high temperatures ranged from 99 to 104 in Portland. In addition to the hot daytime temperatures, overnight low temperatures were well into the 60s offering little cooling for those without air conditioning. This time of year the normal high is around 80 degrees and the normal low is around 57 degrees. The State Medical Examiners reported 1 suspected heat related fatalities in this zone.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hottest period was from the 5th to 9th where high temperatures ranged from 98 to 103 at Hillsboro Airport in the Tualatin Valley. In addition to the hot daytime temperatures, overnight low temperatures were well into the 60s offering little cooling for those without air conditioning. The normal high is around 80 degrees and the normal low is around 51 degrees. The State Medical Examiners reported 4 suspected heat related fatalities in this zone.

An upper level ridge that had been persistent across the Southern Plains to start the first several days of July finally began to shift off to the east, in response to an upper trough moving into the area. This trough allowed a weak cool front to slowly progress south through Southern Oklahoma, Western and Central Arkansas during the 5th, where increased large scale forcing and a moist, unstable air mass focused scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front. However, compressional warming occurred along and just south of the front over portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana, where temperatures were able to climb into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. When combined with the humidity, heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees. These storms gradually spread south into Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and extreme Northeast Texas during the afternoon of the 5th, resulting in cooler temperatures across Southern Arkansas by mid-afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure persisted over the PacNW for nearly a week. The upper ridge resulted in hot temperatures developing across the region, with widespread moderate to major HeatRisk. Several counties across the region opened cooling centers for the general population.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Franklin county coroner confirmed that a 61 year old male east of Pasco, WA had died of hyperthermia, with alcohol intoxication a contributing factor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across East Texas on the 3rd through the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid level ridge intensified over Texas and the Southern Plains towards the end of July through the first part of August. Triple digit high temperatures with heat indices at or above 105 were common across the majority of the region from July 29 through the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached or exceeded 105 degrees at the end of July, extending into early August.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge aloft led to triple digit temperatures and heat index values of 105+ across much of the region during the first week of July. A Heat Advisory was needed for all but the western-most counties (where slightly drier air was in place), and an Excessive Heat Warning was even needed for 110+ degree heat indices across some North Texas counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached or exceeded 105 degrees across the county during the afternoon hours from late June through July 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first of a three-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on July 15, 2024 across much of eastern New York. Heat indices (or feel-like temperatures) reached between 95 to 104 degrees mainly along the Hudson Valley region. ||The hot, humid environment contributed to the development of a cluster of thunderstorms that impact eastern New York in the evening hours of July 15th. Two broken lines of convection became severe in nature, leading to numerous reports of tree and wire damage in the Eastern Catskills and Mohawk Valley in addition to a few isolated reports in the Upper-Hudson Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon on July 1st through the 4th. However, slightly cooler and drier air were able to mix into the area on the 5th, resulting in slightly lower heat indices.

An upper level ridge that had been persistent across the Southern Plains to start the first several days of July finally began to shift off to the east, in response to an upper trough moving into the area. This trough allowed a weak cool front to slowly progress south through Southern Oklahoma, Western and Central Arkansas during the 5th, where increased large scale forcing and a moist, unstable air mass focused scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front. However, compressional warming occurred along and just south of the front over portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana, where temperatures were able to climb into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. When combined with the humidity, heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees. These storms gradually spread south into Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and extreme Northeast Texas during the afternoon of the 5th, resulting in cooler temperatures across Southern Arkansas by mid-afternoon.

Two broken lines of convection became severe in nature, leading to numerous reports of tree and wire damage in the Eastern Catskills and Mohawk Valley in addition to a few isolated reports in the Upper-Hudson Valley.

A Heat Advisory was needed for all but the western-most counties (where slightly drier air was in place), and an Excessive Heat Warning was even needed for 110+ degree heat indices across some North Texas counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached or exceeded 105 degrees across the county during the afternoon hours from late June through July 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon on July 1st through the 4th. However, slightly cooler and drier air were able to mix into the area on the 5th, resulting in slightly lower heat indices.

The first of a three-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on July 15, 2024 across much of eastern New York. Heat indices (or feel-like temperatures) reached between 95 to 104 degrees mainly along the Hudson Valley region. ||The hot, humid environment contributed to the development of a cluster of thunderstorms that impact eastern New York in the evening hours of July 15th. Two broken lines of convection became severe in nature, leading to numerous reports of tree and wire damage in the Eastern Catskills and Mohawk Valley in addition to a few isolated reports in the Upper-Hudson Valley.

The third and final day of a stretch of hot and humid conditions occurred on July 17, 2024 which reached dangerous levels in Dutchess County with heat index values (feels-like temperatures) reaching 95 to 104 degrees. ||A cold front tracking through eastern New York brought scattered showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon hours resulting in several instances of tree and wire damage, especially in Albany, Saratoga and Columbia counties.

An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across East Texas on the 4th through the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

A very strong mid level ridge slowly moved through the region, resulting in multiple days of excessive heat. At least one instance of injury and fatality were reported from the heat. The strong ridge eventually shifted far enough east and south of the area to allow sufficient moisture to return, resulting in the development of diurnal convection, with some thunderstorms yielding strong wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At approximately 2:30 pm MST, park rangers and search and rescue units from local law enforcement found and began treating two hikers in Snow Canyon State Park who were suffering from heat exhaustion. While treating the injured hikers, the units were notified by a passerby of an unconscious woman nearby. First responders subsequently located the unconscious woman, ultimately determining her to be deceased. Temperatures around the park at the time ranged from 107F at a CWOP site in Ivins to 99F at a higher elevation site near Yellow Knoll. The St George Regional Airport AWOS  was reporting temperatures of around 104F at the time. Excessive Heat Warnings were in effect for several days leading up to and during the event, and Snow Canyon State Park had been running a Drink Up campaign with signs at trailheads urging recreators to stay hydrated and limit outdoor activity during the hottest times of day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long-duration heat event brought dangerously hot conditions with widespread Major to Extreme HeatRisk to interior Northern California over the first two weeks of July. Multiple temperature records were broken or tied over this timeframe. The Sacramento County Coroner reported two fatalities due to the extreme heat, one on July 6th and one on July 7th. Temperatures cooled slightly for a brief period in the Southern Sacramento Valley, Delta and Carquinez Straight, and Northern San Joaquin Valley on July 8th and 9th, but conditions were still hot, before ramping up again on July 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dangerously hot daytime high temperatures of 100 to 115 degrees were observed from July 2nd through July 13th. Little relief from the heat was observed overnight, with low temperatures around the mid 70s to upper 80s over the same timeframe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long-duration heat event brought dangerously hot conditions with widespread Major to Extreme HeatRisk to interior Northern California over the first two weeks of July. Multiple temperature records were broken or tied over this timeframe. The Sacramento County Coroner reported two fatalities due to the extreme heat, one on July 6th and one on July 7th. Temperatures cooled slightly for a brief period in the Southern Sacramento Valley, Delta and Carquinez Straight, and Northern San Joaquin Valley on July 8th and 9th, but conditions were still hot, before ramping up again on July 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dangerously hot daytime high temperatures of 105 to 120 degrees were observed from July 2nd through July 13th. Little relief from the heat was observed overnight, with low temperatures around the 70s to mid 80s over the same timeframe. An all time record high was set at Redding Municipal Airport on July 6th, reaching 119 degrees, breaking the previous record of 118 degrees. Multiple daily record high temperatures were tied or broken at Redding Municipal Airport, and Red Bluff Airport over the duration of the event.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late June, and continued into early July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 1st through the 4th. At least fifteen people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, ten of which were transported to the hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The prevailing upper-level pattern for the end of July featured a trough over the Pacific Northwest, favoring southwesterly flow over the central Great Plains. Two troughs ejected out into the north-central CONUS during this episode. The first brought two back to back nights of severe weather across portions of northeast Nebraska the night of the 28th and the 29th. The second trough moved out into the central Plains and brought the synoptic scale forcing for a historic severe wind event that impacted both Lincoln and Omaha metropolitan areas. Wind gusts as high as 100 miles per hour extended from Lancaster County northeast to the Nebraska-Iowa border, leaving behind a large swath of significant tree, powerline and structural damage. Power outages from this storm lasted for up to a week in some locations, particularly in Omaha. ||This episode also featured several afternoons of excessive heat for portions of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. A few instances of 110 degree heat indices were observed in a few southwest Iowa counties the afternoon of the 29th, with even more widespread excessive heat the afternoon of the 31st across much of the forecast area south of Interstate 80. Peak heat indices in this region topped out between 110 and 115 degrees before afternoon convection cooled temperatures back down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of hot afternoon temperatures and high dew points brought a brief period of excessive heat during the afternoon, with heat indices up to 110 being observed in a few counties across southwest Iowa. The Clarinda AWOS station had artificially high heat indices, but was still likely meeting excessive heat criteria given its proximity to the Shenandoah AWOs station. As such, to be consistent with surrounding areas, heat indices up to 110 were still likely observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge of high pressure pushes inland into California on July 2. This ridge provided our area with a hot and dry airmass which persisted for several days until the ridge moved east and temperatures cooled below dangerous levels on July 14. Several record high maximum temperatures and high minimum temperatures were set between July 6 and July 8 and again on July 11 and 12. In addition to the persistent heat between July 2 and July 13, low daytime humidity with poor overnight recovery and heavy fuel loading resulted in an increased fire danger for much of the area during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the 12 day heat wave event, afternoon highs were mainly between 112 and 118 degrees on July 6 through July 8 and on July 11 and 12. Afternoon highs were mainly between 106 and 112 degrees on July 2 through July 5 and on July 9, 10 and 13.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late June, and continued into early July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 1st through the 4th. At least fifteen people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, ten of which were transported to the hospital.

A strong upper ridge ridge covered the southern U.S. during early July. Meanwhile, moisture surged northward into the Mid-South ahead of an approaching cold front. Dewpoints climbed well into the 70s and afternoon heat index values topped 110 degrees across the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values topped 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The prevailing upper-level pattern for the end of July featured a trough over the Pacific Northwest, favoring southwesterly flow over the central Great Plains. Two troughs ejected out into the north-central CONUS during this episode. The first brought two back to back nights of severe weather across portions of northeast Nebraska the night of the 28th and the 29th. The second trough moved out into the central Plains and brought the synoptic scale forcing for a historic severe wind event that impacted both Lincoln and Omaha metropolitan areas. Wind gusts as high as 100 miles per hour extended from Lancaster County northeast to the Nebraska-Iowa border, leaving behind a large swath of significant tree, powerline and structural damage. Power outages from this storm lasted for up to a week in some locations, particularly in Omaha. ||This episode also featured several afternoons of excessive heat for portions of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. A few instances of 110 degree heat indices were observed in a few southwest Iowa counties the afternoon of the 29th, with even more widespread excessive heat the afternoon of the 31st across much of the forecast area south of Interstate 80. Peak heat indices in this region topped out between 110 and 115 degrees before afternoon convection cooled temperatures back down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of hot temperatures and high dew points brought excessive heat during the afternoon hours. Heat indices climbed as high as 112 degrees for portions of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge of high pressure pushes inland into California on July 2. This ridge provided our area with a hot and dry airmass which persisted for several days until the ridge moved east and temperatures cooled below dangerous levels on July 14. Several record high maximum temperatures and high minimum temperatures were set between July 6 and July 8 and again on July 11 and 12. In addition to the persistent heat between July 2 and July 13, low daytime humidity with poor overnight recovery and heavy fuel loading resulted in an increased fire danger for much of the area during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the 12 day heat wave event, afternoon highs were mainly between 106 and 113 degrees on July 6 through July 8 and on July 11 and 12. Afternoon highs were mainly between 101 and 107 degrees on July 2 through July 5 and on July 9, 10 and 13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very hot airmass with temperatures well into the 90s combined with extremely high dewpoints in the upper 70s to low 80s to produce excessively high heat indices generally between 110 and 115 degrees during the daytime hours. The excessive heat affected all of Eastern NC except for the Outer Banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hofmann RAWS recorded heat indices up to 117 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long-duration heat event brought dangerously hot conditions with widespread Major to Extreme HeatRisk to interior Northern California over the first two weeks of July. Multiple temperature records were broken or tied over this timeframe. The Sacramento County Coroner reported two fatalities due to the extreme heat, one on July 6th and one on July 7th. Temperatures cooled slightly for a brief period in the Southern Sacramento Valley, Delta and Carquinez Straight, and Northern San Joaquin Valley on July 8th and 9th, but conditions were still hot, before ramping up again on July 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dangerously hot daytime high temperatures of 100 to 115 degrees were observed from July 2nd through July 13th. Little relief from the heat was observed overnight, with low temperatures around the 60s to mid 70s over the same timeframe. Multiple daily high temperature records were tied or broken at Downtown Sacramento and Sacramento Executive Airport. Temperatures cooled slightly on July 8th and 9th, but conditions were still hot. Temperatures ramped back up again on the 10th and continued through the 13th. The Sacramento County Coroner reported two direct fatalities with this excessive heat event, one on July 6th, and the other on July 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the first of two heatwaves that western Montana experienced in July of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high of 97 at Kalispell on the 11th broke the previous daily record of 95 set back in 1975. The SKQ Dam also reported a record high of 98 on the 11th which broke the previous record of 97 degrees set back in 1953. The hottest temperature reported was 103 degrees in Hot Springs on the 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the first of two heatwaves that western Montana experienced in July of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hottest temperature readings in degrees were as follows: 102 in Alberton, and 101 at Thompson Falls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the first of two heatwaves that western Montana experienced in July of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Missoula International Airport reached 101 degrees on the 10th. The Stevensville COOP reported an official high of 98 degrees which interestingly enough, was five degrees lower than the nearby unofficial RAWS station.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Patuxent NAS (KNAK) measured a peak heat index value of 110. Numerous other sensors in the county measured similar values.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions overspread much of Maryland on July 5, producing heat indices above 100 to 110.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several mesonets in the county measured peak heat indices around 110.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level flow the evening of the 13th features a low-amplitude shortwave trough that had ejected out into the northern Great Plains. At the surface, a weakening stationary front was noted on WPC surface analysis to extend from northwest Nebraska into southeast Nebraska. Isolated strong thunderstorms that developed along this boundary brought a single severe wind gust in Knox County. However, the primary impact of this episode was the excessive heat that impacted much of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. Heat indices the afternoon of the 15th in this area peaked between 110 and 115 degrees. The highest heat index was 117 degrees, observed by an AWOS station in Harlan, Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A maximum heat index of 110 degrees was observed the afternoon of the 15th.

A strong ridge and approaching shortwave trough surged moisture across the area to allow dewpoints to creep into the low to mid 70s with hot conditions in place. Fortunately, convection and excellent mixing allowed heat indices to remain below excessive levels. Nonetheless, hot and humid conditions persisted ahead of a cold frontal passage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper ridge ridge covered the southern U.S. during early July. Meanwhile, moisture surged northward into the Mid-South ahead of an approaching cold front. Dewpoints climbed well into the 70s and afternoon heat index values topped 110 degrees across the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values topped 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level flow the evening of the 13th features a low-amplitude shortwave trough that had ejected out into the northern Great Plains. At the surface, a weakening stationary front was noted on WPC surface analysis to extend from northwest Nebraska into southeast Nebraska. Isolated strong thunderstorms that developed along this boundary brought a single severe wind gust in Knox County. However, the primary impact of this episode was the excessive heat that impacted much of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. Heat indices the afternoon of the 15th in this area peaked between 110 and 115 degrees. The highest heat index was 117 degrees, observed by an AWOS station in Harlan, Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A maximum heat index of 116 degrees was observed the afternoon of the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level flow the evening of the 13th features a low-amplitude shortwave trough that had ejected out into the northern Great Plains. At the surface, a weakening stationary front was noted on WPC surface analysis to extend from northwest Nebraska into southeast Nebraska. Isolated strong thunderstorms that developed along this boundary brought a single severe wind gust in Knox County. However, the primary impact of this episode was the excessive heat that impacted much of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. Heat indices the afternoon of the 15th in this area peaked between 110 and 115 degrees. The highest heat index was 117 degrees, observed by an AWOS station in Harlan, Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A maximum heat index of 117 degrees was observed the afternoon of the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The prevailing upper-level pattern for the end of July featured a trough over the Pacific Northwest, favoring southwesterly flow over the central Great Plains. Two troughs ejected out into the north-central CONUS during this episode. The first brought two back to back nights of severe weather across portions of northeast Nebraska the night of the 28th and the 29th. The second trough moved out into the central Plains and brought the synoptic scale forcing for a historic severe wind event that impacted both Lincoln and Omaha metropolitan areas. Wind gusts as high as 100 miles per hour extended from Lancaster County northeast to the Nebraska-Iowa border, leaving behind a large swath of significant tree, powerline and structural damage. Power outages from this storm lasted for up to a week in some locations, particularly in Omaha.||This episode also featured several afternoons of excessive heat for portions of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. A few instances of 110 degree heat indices were observed in a few southwest Iowa counties the afternoon of the 29th, with even more widespread excessive heat the afternoon of the 31st across much of the forecast area south of Interstate 80. Peak heat indices in this region topped out between 110 and 115 degrees before afternoon convection cooled temperatures back down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of hot temperatures and high dew points brought excessive heat during the afternoon hour for portions of the county. Though no official observations came from the county, its proximity to other counties with observed excessive heat indices supports the likelihood that the same conditions were present here. Peak heat indices likely reached  about 112 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High heat and humidity resulted in dangerous heat index values for central and northeast South Dakota on the afternoon of Saturday July 13th. A heat index of 116 degrees observed in Stockholm and 108 degrees in Pierre. 26 other weather stations observed a peak heat index above 100 degrees in and around central and northeast South Dakota.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper ridge ridge covered the southern U.S. during early July. Meanwhile, moisture surged northward into the Mid-South ahead of an approaching cold front. Dewpoints climbed well into the 70s and afternoon heat index values topped 110 degrees across the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values topped 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions overspread much of the region on July 15 and July 16, resulting in the hottest temperatures of the Summer in 2024. Heat index values reached and exceeded 100 to 110, with daily record high temperatures tied and set.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Washington Dulles International Airport (KIAD) measured a peak heat index value of 108. The high temperature at Washington Dulles was 99F. Several mesonets in the county measured peak heat indices around 110.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level flow the evening of the 13th features a low-amplitude shortwave trough that had ejected out into the northern Great Plains. At the surface, a weakening stationary front was noted on WPC surface analysis to extend from northwest Nebraska into southeast Nebraska. Isolated strong thunderstorms that developed along this boundary brought a single severe wind gust in Knox County. However, the primary impact of this episode was the excessive heat that impacted much of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. Heat indices the afternoon of the 15th in this area peaked between 110 and 115 degrees. The highest heat index was 117 degrees, observed by an AWOS station in Harlan, Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices up to 112 impacted portions of the county for a few hours during the afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The prevailing upper-level pattern for the end of July featured a trough over the Pacific Northwest, favoring southwesterly flow over the central Great Plains. Two troughs ejected out into the north-central CONUS during this episode. The first brought two back to back nights of severe weather across portions of northeast Nebraska the night of the 28th and the 29th. The second trough moved out into the central Plains and brought the synoptic scale forcing for a historic severe wind event that impacted both Lincoln and Omaha metropolitan areas. Wind gusts as high as 100 miles per hour extended from Lancaster County northeast to the Nebraska-Iowa border, leaving behind a large swath of significant tree, powerline and structural damage. Power outages from this storm lasted for up to a week in some locations, particularly in Omaha.||This episode also featured several afternoons of excessive heat for portions of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. A few instances of 110 degree heat indices were observed in a few southwest Iowa counties the afternoon of the 29th, with even more widespread excessive heat the afternoon of the 31st across much of the forecast area south of Interstate 80. Peak heat indices in this region topped out between 110 and 115 degrees before afternoon convection cooled temperatures back down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of hot temperatures and high dew points brought excessive heat during the afternoon hour for portions of the county. Though no official observations came from the county, its proximity to other counties with observed excessive heat indices supports the likelihood that the same conditions were present here. Peak heat indices likely reached  about 112 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High heat and humidity resulted in dangerous heat index values for central and northeast South Dakota on the afternoon of Saturday July 13th. A heat index of 116 degrees observed in Stockholm and 108 degrees in Pierre. 26 other weather stations observed a peak heat index above 100 degrees in and around central and northeast South Dakota.

High heat and humidity resulted in dangerous heat index values for central and northeast South Dakota on the afternoon of Saturday July 13th. A heat index of 116 degrees observed in Stockholm and 108 degrees in Pierre. 26 other weather stations observed a peak heat index above 100 degrees in and around central and northeast South Dakota.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 29th through 31st. At least six people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, three of which were transported to the hospital. This heat wave persisted into early August.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level flow the evening of the 13th features a low-amplitude shortwave trough that had ejected out into the northern Great Plains. At the surface, a weakening stationary front was noted on WPC surface analysis to extend from northwest Nebraska into southeast Nebraska. Isolated strong thunderstorms that developed along this boundary brought a single severe wind gust in Knox County. However, the primary impact of this episode was the excessive heat that impacted much of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. Heat indices the afternoon of the 15th in this area peaked between 110 and 115 degrees. The highest heat index was 117 degrees, observed by an AWOS station in Harlan, Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices up to 112 impacted portions of the county for a few hours during the afternoon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A maximum heat index of 112 degrees was observed the afternoon of the 15th.
