EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The prevailing upper-level pattern for the end of July featured a trough over the Pacific Northwest, favoring southwesterly flow over the central Great Plains. Two troughs ejected out into the north-central CONUS during this episode. The first brought two back to back nights of severe weather across portions of northeast Nebraska the night of the 28th and the 29th. The second trough moved out into the central Plains and brought the synoptic scale forcing for a historic severe wind event that impacted both Lincoln and Omaha metropolitan areas. Wind gusts as high as 100 miles per hour extended from Lancaster County northeast to the Nebraska-Iowa border, leaving behind a large swath of significant tree, powerline and structural damage. Power outages from this storm lasted for up to a week in some locations, particularly in Omaha.||This episode also featured several afternoons of excessive heat for portions of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. A few instances of 110 degree heat indices were observed in a few southwest Iowa counties the afternoon of the 29th, with even more widespread excessive heat the afternoon of the 31st across much of the forecast area south of Interstate 80. Peak heat indices in this region topped out between 110 and 115 degrees before afternoon convection cooled temperatures back down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of hot temperatures and high dew points brought excessive heat during the afternoon hours. Heat indices climbed as high as 110 degrees for portions of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 29th through 31st. At least six people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, three of which were transported to the hospital. This heat wave persisted into early August.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level high-pressure system covered the Lower Mississippi Valley at the end of July. Persistent moist southwest flow brought high dewpoints into the region. Hot temperatures combined with dewpoints well into the 70s resulted in widespread afternoon heat index values above 110 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values topped 110 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of hot temperatures and high dew points brought excessive heat during the afternoon hour for portions of the county. Though no official observations came from the county, its proximity to other counties with observed excessive heat indices supports the likelihood that the same conditions were present here. Peak heat indices likely reached  about 112 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure built westward into California on July 21 and 22 which resulted in the return of dangerous heat across the Kern County Deserts on July 21 and across the San Joaquin Valley West Side Hills, Sierra Foothills, Yosemite Valley and Kern River Canyon by July 22. The heat continued through July 26 when an upper trough approached the California coast and brought cooler temperatures to the area as it moved inland on July 27.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 108 and 113 degrees each day between July 21 and July 26.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 29th through 31st. At least six people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, three of which were transported to the hospital. This heat wave persisted into early August.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values topped 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The prevailing upper-level pattern for the end of July featured a trough over the Pacific Northwest, favoring southwesterly flow over the central Great Plains. Two troughs ejected out into the north-central CONUS during this episode. The first brought two back to back nights of severe weather across portions of northeast Nebraska the night of the 28th and the 29th. The second trough moved out into the central Plains and brought the synoptic scale forcing for a historic severe wind event that impacted both Lincoln and Omaha metropolitan areas. Wind gusts as high as 100 miles per hour extended from Lancaster County northeast to the Nebraska-Iowa border, leaving behind a large swath of significant tree, powerline and structural damage. Power outages from this storm lasted for up to a week in some locations, particularly in Omaha.||This episode also featured several afternoons of excessive heat for portions of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. A few instances of 110 degree heat indices were observed in a few southwest Iowa counties the afternoon of the 29th, with even more widespread excessive heat the afternoon of the 31st across much of the forecast area south of Interstate 80. Peak heat indices in this region topped out between 110 and 115 degrees before afternoon convection cooled temperatures back down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of hot temperatures and high dew points brought excessive heat during the afternoon hours. Heat indices climbed as high as 111 degrees for portions of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dangerous heat and humidity occurred on July 10, 2024 across western Massachusetts. Heat index values (or feel-like temperatures) reached between 95 and 100 degrees.
Dangerous heat and humidity occurred on July 10, 2024 across western Massachusetts. Heat index values (or feel-like temperatures) reached between 95 and 100 degrees.

A large upper ridge of high pressure pushes inland into California on July 2. This ridge provided our area with a hot and dry airmass which persisted for several days until the ridge moved east and temperatures cooled below dangerous levels on July 14. Several record high maximum temperatures and high minimum temperatures were set between July 6 and July 8 and again on July 11 and 12. In addition to the persistent heat between July 2 and July 13, low daytime humidity with poor overnight recovery and heavy fuel loading resulted in an increased fire danger for much of the area during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the 12 day heat wave event, afternoon highs were mainly between 109 and 116 degrees on July 6 through July 8 and on July 11 and 12. Afternoon highs were mainly between 104 and 110 degrees on July 2 through July 5 and on July 9, 10 and 13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge of high pressure pushes inland into California on July 2. EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the 12 day heat wave event, afternoon highs were mainly between 109 and 116 degrees on July 6 through July 8 and on July 11 and 12. Afternoon highs were mainly between 104 and 110 degrees on July 2 through July 5 and on July 9, 10 and 13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The region witnessed three days of high heat and humidity in late July. Peak temperatures for the three day period included a high of 105 degrees measured at the South Dakota extension mesonet station 7 miles southwest of Hayes, 104 degrees at Pierre municipal airport and 103 degrees at the department of transportation weather station in Hayes. The South Dakota extension mesonet station 7 miles southwest of Hayes also observed a high temperature in excess of 100 degrees for all 3 days. ||In addition to the heat, high humidity with dewpoints in the low to mid 70s resulted in widespread heat index values at or above 100 degrees.  A public weather station in Pierre observed a heat index of 108 degrees on July 27th, with Pierre municipal airport measuring a peak heat index of 107 degrees on July 25th. 29 weather stations recorded a peak heat index of 100 degrees or higher on July 25th, 18 on the 26th and a total of 25 stations observed a heat index of 100 degrees or more on the 27th.

The heat continued through July 26 when an upper trough approached the California coast and brought cooler temperatures to the area as it moved inland on July 27.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 29th through 31st. At least six people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, three of which were transported to the hospital. This heat wave persisted into early August.

A strong upper-level high-pressure system covered the Lower Mississippi Valley at the end of July. Persistent moist southwest flow brought high dewpoints into the region. Hot temperatures combined with dewpoints well into the 70s resulted in widespread afternoon heat index values above 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to western Siskiyou County for 10 consecutive days from July 4th through July 13th. Low temperatures were generally in the mid 50s to upper 60s, and high temperatures in the upper 90s to 110 degrees. But, peak readings were recorded on July 6th of 114 degrees at Happy Camp and Sawyers Bar, and 115 degrees at Somes Bar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record 10 day heat wave occurred early to mid July 2024. Interior southern California, mountains and deserts, experience the hottest 2 week period for July, and July 2024 was the hottest month of record at Palm Springs. The average monthly temperature in Palm Springs was 100F for July. Borrego Springs average high was also a record at 97.5F. July was also the hottest month on record for the state of California, exceeding the previous year by 1.9F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures were extreme the first 10 days of July. On July 5, 2024, Palm Spring (PSP) recorded a high of 124F which is an all-time high temperature. From July 1 to July 12, the Palm Springs airport had high temperatures of 114 to to 124 including a high of 122F on July 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record 10 day heat wave occurred early to mid July 2024. Interior southern California, mountains and deserts, experience the hottest 2 week period for July, and July 2024 was the hottest month of record at Palm Springs. The average monthly temperature in Palm Springs was 100F for July. Borrego Springs average high was also a record at 97.5F. July was also the hottest month on record for the state of California, exceeding the previous year by 1.9F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anza Borrego State Park recorded high temperatures of 110 to 121F between July 1 to 13, 2024. On July 8th, 2024, a high temperature of 121F was recorded. This severe heat is anomalous even for a desert region.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record 10 day heat wave occurred early to mid July 2024. Interior southern California, mountains and deserts, experience the hottest 2 week period for July, and July 2024 was the hottest month of record at Palm Springs. The average monthly temperature in Palm Springs was 100F for July. Borrego Springs average high was also a record at 97.5F. July was also the hottest month on record for the state of California, exceeding the previous year by 1.9F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat occurred in the Inland Empire July 1 to 11, 2024. On July 5, 2024, San Bernardino airport reached 117F. Other locations in the Inland Empire ranged from 103 to 118F, hottest on the east and south side. Other days during the heat wave recorded upper 90s to 105. The high temperatures again peaked on July 10 and 11 when highest temperatures in the Inland Empire reached 110F.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the High Desert reached 105 to 112F for several days including July 5 to 11 extended period of heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge of high pressure pushes inland into California on July 2. This ridge provided our area with a hot and dry airmass which persisted for several days until the ridge moved east and temperatures cooled below dangerous levels on July 14. Several record high maximum temperatures and high minimum temperatures were set between July 6 and July 8 and again on July 11 and 12. In addition to the persistent heat between July 2 and July 13, low daytime humidity with poor overnight recovery and heavy fuel loading resulted in an increased fire danger for much of the area during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the 12 day heat wave event, afternoon highs were mainly between 109 and 116 degrees on July 6 through July 8 and on July 11 and 12. Afternoon highs were mainly between 104 and 110 degrees on July 2 through July 5 and on July 9, 10 and 13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The region witnessed three days of high heat and humidity in late July. Peak temperatures for the three day period included a high of 105 degrees measured at the South Dakota extension mesonet station 7 miles southwest of Hayes, 104 degrees at Pierre municipal airport and 103 degrees at the department of transportation weather station in Hayes. The South Dakota extension mesonet station 7 miles southwest of Hayes also observed a high temperature in excess of 100 degrees for all 3 days. ||In addition to the heat, high humidity with dewpoints in the low to mid 70s resulted in widespread heat index values at or above 100 degrees.  A public weather station in Pierre observed a heat index of 108 degrees on July 27th, with Pierre municipal airport measuring a peak heat index of 107 degrees on July 25th. 29 weather stations recorded a peak heat index of 100 degrees or higher on July 25th, 18 on the 26th and a total of 25 stations observed a heat index of 100 degrees or more on the 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to central Siskiyou County for 10 consecutive days from July 4th through July 13th. Low temperatures were generally in the lower 60s to lower 70s, and high temperatures in the upper 90s to 105 degrees. But, peak readings were recorded on July 6th of 113 degrees at Hornbrook and Oak Knoll. Record high temperatures were set at Siskiyou County-Montague Airport of 104 degrees on July 4th, 108 degrees on July 5th, 111 degrees on July 6th, 109 degrees on July 7th, 109 degrees on July 8th, 108 degrees on July 9th, 107 degrees on July 12th, and 109 degrees on July 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to south central Siskiyou County for 9 consecutive days from July 5th through July 13th. Low temperatures were generally in the mid 50s to lower 70s, and high temperatures in the upper 90s to 105 degrees. But, peak readings were recorded on July 6th of 106 degrees at the Mt. Shasta RAWS, and 110 degrees at Mott. Record high temperatures were set at Mt. Shasta City of 104 degrees on July 6th, 104 degrees on July 7th, 101 degrees on July 8th, 101 degrees on July 12th, and 104 degrees on July 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure brought excessive heat to north central and southeast Siskiyou County during the peak of a heat wave from July 6th through July 7th. Low temperatures were in the lower 50s to lower 70s, and high temperatures in the mid 90s to 104 degrees.

CZ_NAME: NORTHEAST SISKIYOU AND NORTHWEST MODOC COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to northeast Siskiyou and northwest Modoc counties for 4 consecutive days from July 6th through July 9th, then temperatures were just a little below excessive values on July 10th and 11th. Excessive heat returned on July 12th and 13th. Low temperatures were generally in the lower 50s to upper 60s, and high temperatures in the mid 90s to 101 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record 10 day heat wave occurred early to mid July 2024. Interior southern California, mountains and deserts, experience the hottest 2 week period for July, and July 2024 was the hottest month of record at Palm Springs. EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the mountains were in the 90s to around 100F between July 1 and July 12, 2024.  Highs reached as hot as 103 to 109F up to elevation 4000 feet, especially on July 5, 10 and 11, 2024. Big Bear Lake at 7000 feet had high temperatures in the lower 90s.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperature in the mountains. Idyllwild recorded 104F on July 5 and 6. The all-time high at this location is 104F.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An extended period of excessive heat. On July 5, 2024, it was recorded as high as 106 to 108F at 3500 feet in the San Diego mountains including Descanso. Other days during the heat wave reached the mid 90s to 102F in the Cuyamaca, Laguna and Palomar mountains.

A large area of high pressure built westward into California on July 21 and 22 which resulted in the return of dangerous heat across the Kern County Deserts on July 21 and across the San Joaquin Valley West Side Hills, Sierra Foothills, Yosemite Valley and Kern River Canyon by July 22. The heat continued through July 26 when an upper trough approached the California coast and brought cooler temperatures to the area as it moved inland on July 27.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 108 and 113 degrees on July 23 and 24, and between 105 and 109 degrees on July 22, 25 and 26.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late June, and continued into early July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 1st through the 4th. At least fifteen people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, ten of which were transported to the hospital.

CZ_NAME: LAKE MEAD/LAKE MOHAVE NATIONAL RECREATION AREA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built westward over the Mojave Desert, leading to another spell of extreme heat. Thirty-four people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on seven straight days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built westward over the Mojave Desert, leading to another spell of extreme heat. Thirty-four people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on five straight days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built westward over the Mojave Desert, leading to another spell of extreme heat. Thirty-four people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on five straight days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built westward over the Mojave Desert, leading to another spell of extreme heat. Thirty-four people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on six straight days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to Modoc County for 8 consecutive days from July 6th through July 13th. Low temperatures were generally in the upper 40s to mid 60s, and high temperatures in the mid 90s to 102 degrees. Record high temperatures were set at Alturas of 102 degrees on July 6th, 102 degrees on July 7th, and 102 degrees on July 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure brought excessive heat to the Curry County Coast from July 4th through July 6th. The excessive heat extended all the way to the beaches at Brookings with a Chetco Effect of downslope northeast winds. Low temperatures were in the lower 50s to mid 70s, and high temperatures mainly in the lower 80s to mid 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to central Douglas County for 5 consecutive days from July 5th through July 9th. Low temperatures were generally in the mid 50s to lower 60s, and high temperatures in the mid 90s to 108 degrees. But, a peak reading was recorded on July 6th of 111 degrees at Highway 42 near the Coos County line by ODOT. Record high temperatures were set at Roseburg of 104 degrees on July 5th, 108 degrees on July 6th, 107 degrees on July 7th, 108 degrees on July 8th, and 106 degrees on July 9th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to the Siskiyou Mountains and Southern Oregon Cascades for 5 consecutive days from July 5th through July 9th, and on July 13th. Advisory conditions occurred from July 10th through July 12th. During the excessive heat, low temperatures were generally in the lower 50s to mid 60s, and high temperatures in the lower 90s to 105 degrees. But, a peak reading was recorded on July 6th of 110 degrees at the Buckhorn Springs RAWS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge of high pressure pushes inland into California on July 2. This ridge provided our area with a hot and dry airmass which persisted for several days until the ridge moved east and temperatures cooled below dangerous levels on July 14. Several record high maximum temperatures and high minimum temperatures were set between July 6 and July 8 and again on July 11 and 12. In addition to the persistent heat between July 2 and July 13, low daytime humidity with poor overnight recovery and heavy fuel loading resulted in an increased fire danger for much of the area during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the 12 day heat wave event, afternoon highs were mainly between 109 and 116 degrees on July 6 through July 8 and on July 11 and 12. Afternoon highs were mainly between 104 and 110 degrees on July 2 through July 5 and on July 9, 10 and 13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper ridge ridge covered the southern U.S. during early July. Meanwhile, moisture surged northward into the Mid-South ahead of an approaching cold front. Dewpoints climbed well into the 70s and afternoon heat index values topped 110 degrees across the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values topped 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to the Klamath Basin for 4 consecutive days from July 6th through July 9th, and on July 12th and 13th. Advisory conditions occurred on July 4th and 5th, and on July 10th and 11th. During the excessive heat, low temperatures were generally in the mid 40s to lower 60s, and high temperatures from 95 to 105 degrees. But, a peak reading was recorded on July 6th of 109 degrees at the FW4081 Klamath Falls CWOP station. Record high temperatures were reported at Klamath Falls International Airport of 102 degrees on July 6th, and 101 degrees on July 7th. Records were tied at 98 degrees on July 9th, and 100 degrees on July 13th. The Oregon State Medical Examiner's Office reported a potentially heat related death of a 27 year old male on July 9th.

CZ_NAME: NORTHERN & EASTERN KLAMATH COUNTY & WESTERN LAKE COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge over the western states with an associated thermal trough extending from northern California into southern Oregon brought a long-duration heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to Northern and Eastern Klamath County and Western Lake County for 4 consecutive days from July 6th through July 9th, and on July 12th and 13th. Advisory conditions occurred on July 4th and 5th, and on July 10th and 11th. During the excessive heat, low temperatures were generally in the upper 30s to lower 50s, and high temperatures from the lower 90s to 100 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge and approaching shortwave trough surged moisture across the area to allow dewpoints to creep into the low to mid 70s with hot conditions in place. Fortunately, convection and excellent mixing allowed heat indices to remain below excessive levels. Nonetheless, hot and humid conditions persisted ahead of a cold frontal passage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long stretch of hot temperatures across western Washington caused numerous records to broken during the beginning of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperaure of 85 degrees was set at Quillayute aiport, breaking the old record of 82 degrees set in 2010.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long stretch of hot temperatures across western Washington caused numerous records to broken during the beginning of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature was set at WFO Seattle on July 8th, breaking the old record of 90 degrees set in 1905.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long stretch of hot temperatures across western Washington caused numerous records to broken during the beginning of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 99 degrees was set on July 8th at Olympia Airport, breaking the previous record of 95 degrees in 2010.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure over the Four Corners region and a dry westerly flow over the PacNW resulted in dry and hot conditions developing across the region. This resulted in moderate to major HeatRisk being observed over the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local county coroner confirmed a heat related death of a 70 year old male on July 15th, and the heat related deaths of a couple, 85 year old female and 90 year old male, on July 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge of high pressure pushes inland into California on July 2. This ridge provided our area with a hot and dry airmass which persisted for several days until the ridge moved east and temperatures cooled below dangerous levels on July 14. Several record high maximum temperatures and high minimum temperatures were set between July 6 and July 8 and again on July 11 and 12. In addition to the persistent heat between July 2 and July 13, low daytime humidity with poor overnight recovery and heavy fuel loading resulted in an increased fire danger for much of the area during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the 12 day heat wave event, afternoon highs were mainly between 109 and 116 degrees on July 6 through July 8 and on July 11 and 12. Afternoon highs were mainly between 104 and 110 degrees on July 2 through July 5 and on July 9, 10 and 13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were two heatwaves that occurred in July of 2024. The first heatwave occurred during the second week of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Dworshak Reservoir saw 6 days of highs in the 100s with lows in the low to mid 60s. The hottest day was the 9th when the high reached 106 degrees at Dworshak and the unofficial reading at the Dent RAWS reached 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were two heatwaves that occurred in July of 2024. The first heatwave occurred during the second week of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fenn RAWS hit 100 or higher five times during this heatwave. The highest readings occurred on the 9th when Fenn was 105 degrees, and on the 10th when the Moose Creek RAWS hit 107 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were two heatwaves that occurred in July of 2024. The first heatwave occurred during the second week of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Orofino saw 6 days of temperatures in the lower 100s. The hottest day occurred on the 10th when the high reached 107 degrees. The warmest low temperature was 66 degrees on the morning of the 11th. While the Camas Prairie saw highs in the mid 90s, the Kamiah area was similarly as hot as Orofino.

CZ_NAME: LOWER HELLS CANYON / SALMON RIVER REGION
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were two heatwaves that occurred in July of 2024. The first heatwave occurred during the second week of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were observed in both the Snake River and Salmon River valleys. The Pittsburg Landing RAWS saw its highest reading of 111 degrees on the 9th and 10th. Its low temperatures were in the low to mid 70s with a 76 low on the morning of the 11th. The Riggins COOP station saw its highest temperature of 104 degrees on the 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the first of two heatwaves that western Montana experienced in July of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hottest temperature readings were reported as follows: Libby Dam Base was 102 degrees on the 10th, Eureka was 101 degrees on both the 10th and 11th, and both the Troy RAWS and COOP reported 103 degrees on the 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge and approaching shortwave trough surged moisture across the area to allow dewpoints to creep into the low to mid 70s with hot conditions in place. Fortunately, convection and excellent mixing allowed heat indices to remain below excessive levels. Nonetheless, hot and humid conditions persisted ahead of a cold frontal passage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper ridge ridge covered the southern U.S. during early July. Meanwhile, moisture surged northward into the Mid-South ahead of an approaching cold front. Dewpoints climbed well into the 70s and afternoon heat index values topped 110 degrees across the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values topped 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The prevailing upper-level pattern for the end of July featured a trough over the Pacific Northwest, favoring southwesterly flow over the central Great Plains. Two troughs ejected out into the north-central CONUS during this episode. The first brought two back to back nights of severe weather across portions of northeast Nebraska the night of the 28th and the 29th. The second trough moved out into the central Plains and brought the synoptic scale forcing for a historic severe wind event that impacted both Lincoln and Omaha metropolitan areas. Wind gusts as high as 100 miles per hour extended from Lancaster County northeast to the Nebraska-Iowa border, leaving behind a large swath of significant tree, powerline and structural damage. Power outages from this storm lasted for up to a week in some locations, particularly in Omaha. ||This episode also featured several afternoons of excessive heat for portions of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. A few instances of 110 degree heat indices were observed in a few southwest Iowa counties the afternoon of the 29th, with even more widespread excessive heat the afternoon of the 31st across much of the forecast area south of Interstate 80. Peak heat indices in this region topped out between 110 and 115 degrees before afternoon convection cooled temperatures back down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of hot afternoon temperatures and high dew points brought a brief period of excessive heat during the afternoon, with heat indices up to 110 being observed in a few counties across southwest Iowa.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long-duration heat event brought dangerously hot conditions with widespread Major to Extreme HeatRisk to interior Northern California over the first two weeks of July. Multiple temperature records were broken or tied over this timeframe. The Sacramento County Coroner reported two fatalities due to the extreme heat, one on July 6th and one on July 7th. Temperatures cooled slightly for a brief period in the Southern Sacramento Valley, Delta and Carquinez Straight, and Northern San Joaquin Valley on July 8th and 9th, but conditions were still hot, before ramping up again on July 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dangerously hot daytime high temperatures of 100 to 118 degrees were observed from July 2nd through July 13th. Little relief from the heat was observed overnight, with low temperatures around 75 to 85 degrees over the same timeframe.

CZ_NAME: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWESTERN SHASTA COUNTY TO WESTERN COLUSA COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long-duration heat event brought dangerously hot conditions with widespread Major to Extreme HeatRisk to interior Northern California over the first two weeks of July. Multiple temperature records were broken or tied over this timeframe. The Sacramento County Coroner reported two fatalities due to the extreme heat, one on July 6th and one on July 7th. Temperatures cooled slightly for a brief period in the Southern Sacramento Valley, Delta and Carquinez Straight, and Northern San Joaquin Valley on July 8th and 9th, but conditions were still hot, before ramping up again on July 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dangerously hot daytime high temperatures of up to 100 to 115 degrees were observed from July 2nd through July 13th. Little relief from the heat was observed overnight, with low temperatures around the mid 70s to upper 80s over the same timeframe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late June, and continued into early July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of west central Arkansas on the 2nd through the 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper ridge ridge covered the southern U.S. during early July. Meanwhile, moisture surged northward into the Mid-South ahead of an approaching cold front. Dewpoints climbed well into the 70s and afternoon heat index values topped 110 degrees across the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values topped 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The prevailing upper-level pattern for the end of July featured a trough over the Pacific Northwest, favoring southwesterly flow over the central Great Plains. Two troughs ejected out into the north-central CONUS during this episode. The first brought two back to back nights of severe weather across portions of northeast Nebraska the night of the 28th and the 29th. The second trough moved out into the central Plains and brought the synoptic scale forcing for a historic severe wind event that impacted both Lincoln and Omaha metropolitan areas. Wind gusts as high as 100 miles per hour extended from Lancaster County northeast to the Nebraska-Iowa border, leaving behind a large swath of significant tree, powerline and structural damage. Power outages from this storm lasted for up to a week in some locations, particularly in Omaha. ||This episode also featured several afternoons of excessive heat for portions of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. A few instances of 110 degree heat indices were observed in a few southwest Iowa counties the afternoon of the 29th, with even more widespread excessive heat the afternoon of the 31st across much of the forecast area south of Interstate 80. Peak heat indices in this region topped out between 110 and 115 degrees before afternoon convection cooled temperatures back down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of hot afternoon temperatures and high dew points brought a brief period of excessive heat during the afternoon, with heat indices up to 110 being observed in a few counties across southwest Iowa.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge of high pressure pushes inland into California on July 2. This ridge provided our area with a hot and dry airmass which persisted for several days until the ridge moved east and temperatures cooled below dangerous levels on July 14. Several record high maximum temperatures and high minimum temperatures were set between July 6 and July 8 and again on July 11 and 12. In addition to the persistent heat between July 2 and July 13, low daytime humidity with poor overnight recovery and heavy fuel loading resulted in an increased fire danger for much of the area during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the 12 day heat wave event, afternoon highs were mainly between 106 and 113 degrees on July 6 through July 8 and on July 11 and 12. Afternoon highs were mainly between 101 and 107 degrees on July 2 through July 5 and on July 9, 10 and 13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure strengthened over central California on June 11 which resulted in daytime temperatures rising to the triple digits once again across most of the San Joaquin Valley and the lower Sierra foothills. Some cooling was noted along the west side of the valley on June 12 as an upper low pressure system approached the southern California coast although temperatures further inland remained well above normal. As the low moved inland on June 13, temperatures cooled further and remained below dangerous heat levels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 104 degrees on June 11 and June 12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperature and moisture has continued to prevail across the area, resulting in excessive heat indices across many coastal and urban areas in the islands. These heat values lead to the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in the Mesonet registered heat indices values of 112 degrees for two hours or more.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 112-115F for 3 hours, from 12:52-3:52 PM CDT on May 24, 2024.  The Texas Mesonet station at Sarita recorded heat indices between 111 and 114 from 1230 until 530 PM CDT.  By proxy between these locations, similar values and times are assumed for Willacy County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on June 18, 2024 and continued through June 20, 2024 across southern Vermont outside of the southern Green Mountains. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region each day.

The second of a multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions continued on June 19, 2024 across much of eastern New York outside of the Adirondacks and eastern Catskills. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region.||The heat and humidity also resulted in isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon hours. A few storms became severe downing trees and wires.

Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region.||The heat and humidity also resulted in isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon hours. A few storms became severe downing trees and wires.

The second of a multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions continued on June 19, 2024 across much of eastern New York outside of the Adirondacks and eastern Catskills. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region.||The heat and humidity also resulted in isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon hours. A few storms became severe downing trees and wires.

An unusually strong high pressure system settled in over New England, raising daytime temperatures into the 90s for a period of approximately 3 days. Very humid conditions also occurred during this period, with heat indices rising above 100 to 105 for many locations. Several daily high records were broken or tied, and the all time high record for Caribou was tied during this period. Warm temperatures overnight provided little relief, and the record high low temperature at Caribou was also tied during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bangor International Airport reached a heat index of 106 degrees F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperature and moisture has continued to prevail across the area, resulting in excessive heat indices across many coastal and urban areas in the islands. These heat values lead to the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in the Mesonet registered heat indices values of 112 degrees for two hours or more.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwave troughs traversing the northern CONUS brought unsettled weather to the area for the end of June. On the 21st, a stationary front was draped across northeast Nebraska into Iowa. Ahead of one of the aforementioned shortwave troughs, several rounds of strong thunderstorms developed near this frontal zone and moved across northeast Nebraska. At 8 pm on the 21st, radar imagery showed training thunderstorms had set up across central Nebraska. These storms moved into east-central Nebraska dropping 2 to 6 inches of rain across the Platte River Basin. As a result, minor flooding was observed along the Platte River in Dodge, Saunders, Douglas and Sarpy Counties. Further north in Knox County, additional rounds of thunderstorms brought flooding to the Ponca Creek, prompting emergency management to deploy sand bags. Flooding in these locations continued for several days before subsiding the 23rd.||Behind this first shortwave, a shortwave ridge moved out into the central Plains accompanied by a surface high pressure system. Afternoon high temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the mid and upper 70s brought excessive heat to much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa the afternoons of the 24th and the 25th. Excessive heat was most widespread on the 24th, with heat indices across the entire WFO ranging from 107 to 120 degrees. Afternoon thunderstorms on the 25th mitigated excessive heat, though heat indices did hit 110 in far southwest Iowa.||On the 25th, another shortwave trough brought more unsettled weather to the region. A surface front was draped across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa when the first convection initiated over downtown Omaha. This storm quickly became intense, producing multiple instances of 3 to 4 inch hail in the Omaha metro. As this storm weakened over eastern Sarpy County, additional strong to severe thunderstorms developed across northeast Nebraska. While the most widespread hazard was large hail up to the size of golf balls, two tornadoes were confirmed in Madison County. Later that evening, a bow echo developed and moved through the northern Omaha Metro, bringing wind gusts up to 90 miles per hour at Eppley Airfield and into northern Pottawattamie County. An additional line of storms developed after dark that night across southeast Nebraska and produced scattered damaging wind gusts, the highest of which was an 83 mph wind gust measured by emergency management in Jefferson County.||The unsettled weather at the end of June brought widespread excessive rain to much of southeast South Dakota and Northwest Iowa. Rainfall estimated from these storms showed a swath of 4 to 8 inches of rain that fell between Sioux Falls and Sioux City. The result of this rain and additional rain across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa was river flooding along the Missouri and Little Sioux the last week of June and into July. Flooding during this time frame resulted in numerous road closures, including I-29 between Council Bluffs and Missouri Valley. This stretch of the interstate was closed beginning midnight the night of the 25th, and remained closed through the end of the month. Levee breaches in Monona County on the 25th prompted several evacuations, as resultant flash flooding inundated multiple county roads and homesteads. No injuries or fatalities were reported from this. While flooding subsided in and north of the Omaha metro by the end of the month, river flooding along the Missouri persisted into the first week of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A max heat index of 110 was observed at the Red Oak AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure strengthened over central California on June 11 which resulted in daytime temperatures rising to the triple digits once again across most of the San Joaquin Valley and the lower Sierra foothills. Some cooling was noted along the west side of the valley on June 12 as an upper low pressure system approached the southern California coast although temperatures further inland remained well above normal. As the low moved inland on June 13, temperatures cooled further and remained below dangerous heat levels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 106 degrees on June 11 and June 12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak Heat Index reached 116F at McAllen/Miller Airport at around 130 PM CST and continue through around 630 PM CST on May 8th, peaking at 121F at 353 PM CST.  Nearby Lower Rio Grande Valley Wildlife Refuge Remote Automated Weather Sensor (RAWS) along the Rio Grande southeast of Pharr recorded more than 123F, but this value is likely a high bias.  Still, it was likely that realistic values of 116 to 120 occurred in much of southern Hidalgo County.  Dangerous heat index values of 111 began at 1240 PM CST and continued through 710 PM CST.

The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falfurrias Airport (AWOS) recorded heat indices between 116-123F for 3.5 hours, from 3:35-6:55 PM CDT on May 9, 2024. Between the hours of 1:35-7:35 PM CDT (6 hours), heat indices were at least 111F.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE MOUNTAINS NORTH OF HIGHWAY 198
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge pushed inland into California on June 4 and strengthened further as it shifted into the Great Basin on June 5 and 6. This resulted in the first significant heat wave of the season across the interior of central California between June 5 and June 7. Temperatures cooled off across the area on June 8 although remaining above normal as a cold front crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 104 degrees on June 5 and between 104 and 108 degrees on June 6 and June 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falfurrias (AWOS) recorded max heat indices between 111-118F for 6 hours, from 12:55-6:55 PM CDT on May 24, 2024. Though excessive heat values between 116-118F occurred for a couple of hours, between 3:55-5:55 PM CDT, proxy/trusted locations in northern Hidalgo County and inland Kenedy County suggest that the Brooks Co Airport site may have only briefly touched 116F, the starting point for Excessive Heat.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 104 degrees on June 5 and between 104 and 108 degrees on June 6 and June 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded heat indices between 117-125F for 4 hours, from 1:52-5:52 PM CDT (1252 to 452 CST). The value of 125F was a May record, and rivaled all-time hourly records. Between the hours of 11:52 AM to 6:52 PM CDT (7 hours), heat indices were at least 111F. Ambient temperatures set daily and monthly records for May 9th. By proxy, it can be interpolated that at least southern inland Willacy County had similar heat index values, with slightly lower values farther north.  There were no known direct fatalities, though hospitalizations for heat-related illnesses increased by an unknown number on this day.

By proxy, southern Jim Hogg County likely observed the same values around the same time.  Farther north, the Hebbronville Automated Weather Observing System  recorded a peak heat index of 110F at 530 PM CDT, and the Hellen Station Mesonet reached 111 to 113F intermittently short between 4 and 6 PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At South Texas International Airport 11 miles north of Edinburg and on the line between north and south Hidalgo County, peak heat index ranged from 112F to 117F between around 125 and 615 PM CDT, peaking qt 117F between 315 and 415 PM.  The Remote Automated Observing Station at Linn-San Manuel recorded max heat indices between 114-120F degrees for 5 hours, between 12:46-5:46 PM CDT on May 24, 2024. ||Though heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria (116 or higher for two or more hours) at Linn/San Manuel with values between 118-120F for 3 hours, from 2:46-5:46 PM CDT, the site has a known high bias and proxy values were more likely close to 116F or 117F for about an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falfurrias (AWOS) recorded max heat indices between 111-118F for 7 hours, from 11:55 AM-6:55 PM CDT on May 24, 2024.  However, the location was likely having sensor issues for the latter half of May, as their observations were not commensurate with nearby sites as proxies. Therefore, the best estimate for Brooks County was closer to 111 to 114 from 3 until 6 PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on June 18, 2024 and continued through June 20, 2024 across southern Vermont outside of the southern Green Mountains. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region each day.

A multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on June 18, 2024 and continued into June 20, 2024 across northwestern Connecticut. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region each day. Heat continued for additional days in some locations after June 20.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falfurrias (AWOS) recorded max heat indices of an estimated 111 or higher for a few hours during the afternoon.  Actual observations were much higher, but not matched by nearby proxy observations which did not show values at or above 116F, which is the baseline for Excessive Heat events (lasting 2 or more hours) between 3:55-5:55 PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge pushed inland into California on June 4 and strengthened further as it shifted into the Great Basin on June 5 and 6. This resulted in the first significant heat wave of the season across the interior of central California between June 5 and June 7. Temperatures cooled off across the area on June 8 although remaining above normal as a cold front crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 104 degrees on June 5 and between 104 and 108 degrees on June 6 and June 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second of a multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions continued on June 19, 2024 across much of eastern New York outside of the Adirondacks and eastern Catskills. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region.||The heat and humidity also resulted in isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon hours. A few storms became severe downing trees and wires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built over the southern part of the country allowing temperatures to climb above normal. In combination with high relative humidity heat indices rose to 115 degrees and higher. The heat index in New Braunfels reached 120, LaGrange hit 119, and the Randolph AFB Auxiliary Field in Seguin 118. Several other locations topped out at 117.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Pooling moisture ahead of a frontal boundary pushed dew point readings into the upper 70s and lower 80s, and temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s produced heat index values from 100 to 105 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 104 degrees in Luverne and 101 degrees near Beaver Creek.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 108 degrees on June 5 and between 105 and 110 degrees on June 6 and June 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper ridge built into central California from the Desert Southwest on June 22 and remained over the region through June 25 before weakening ahead of an approaching trough. The ridging resulted widespread triple digit heat across the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and lower Sierra foothills between June 22 and June 25. Some tropical moisture from the remains of Tropical Strom Alberto was pulled up by the upper high and spread into southern California on June 23 and into central California on June 24 which resulted in higher heat indexes across the lower elevations on June 24 and some dry thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening on June 24 which ignited several grass and brush fires in the eastern portion of the San Joaquin Valley and the Sierra foothills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 107 degrees on June 22, between 106 and 110 degrees on June 23 and between 101 and 105 degrees on June 24 and 25.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge contributed to an period of days when temperatures went above seasonal averages across inland areas of central California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several people were overcome by the heat at the American Canyon High School graduation. Three people were taken to the hospital and two more got medical attention on site. Temperatures in the area reached 91 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Texas Mesonet site at Sarita recorded heat index values between 111 and 114 from 115 through 530 PM.  Similar values likely occurred farther south in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat from multiple days of hot daytime temperatures and very warm overnight temperatures was observed on June 4th through June 6th across much of interior Northern California. Daily maximum record temperatures were tied or broken, with Vacaville Airport reaching 104 degrees on June 5th, breaking the old record of 103 set in 2002. Marysville Airport reached 104 degrees on June 5th, which tied the old record of 104 set in 2002.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather stations in the area reported daytime high temperatures of 90 to 100 degrees across this zone, with overnight lows in the 60s to upper 70 degree range from June 4th through June 6th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather stations in the area reported daytime high temperatures of 85 to 100 degrees across this zone, with overnight lows in the 60s to upper 70 degree range from June 4th through June 6th.

The heat index in New Braunfels reached 120, LaGrange hit 119, and the Randolph AFB Auxiliary Field in Seguin 118. Several other locations topped out at 117.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Zapata recorded max heat indices between 111-113F for a little more than four hours from 215 through 625 PM CDT on May 21, 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper ridge built into central California from the Desert Southwest on June 22 and remained over the region through June 25 before weakening ahead of an approaching trough. The ridging resulted widespread triple digit heat across the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and lower Sierra foothills between June 22 and June 25. Some tropical moisture from the remains of Tropical Strom Alberto was pulled up by the upper high and spread into southern California on June 23 and into central California on June 24 which resulted in higher heat indexes across the lower elevations on June 24 and some dry thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening on June 24 which ignited several grass and brush fires in the eastern portion of the San Joaquin Valley and the Sierra foothills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 107 degrees on June 22, between 106 and 110 degrees on June 23 and between 101 and 105 degrees on June 24 and 25.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat from multiple days of hot daytime temperatures and very warm overnight temperatures was observed on June 4th through June 6th across much of interior Northern California. Daily maximum record temperatures were tied or broken, with Vacaville Airport reaching 104 degrees on June 5th, breaking the old record of 103 set in 2002. Marysville Airport reached 104 degrees on June 5th, which tied the old record of 104 set in 2002.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather stations in the area reported daytime high temperatures of 95 to 105 degrees across this zone, with overnight lows in the mid 60 to upper 70 degree range from June 4th through June 6th. Marysville Airport reached 104 degrees on June 5th, tying the record for that date which was set in 2002.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather stations in the area reported daytime high temperatures of 95 to 106 degrees across this zone, with overnight lows in the mid 60 to upper 70 degree range from June 4th through June 6th. Redding Airport and Red Bluff Airport both reached 106 degrees.

Sacramento International Airport reached 104 degrees on June 5th, and Sacramento Executive Airport reached 102.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late June. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid to upper 90s, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 117 degree range across much of west central Arkansas on the 29th through the 30th. This heat wave persisted into early July.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The South Texas International Airport Automated Weather Observation System site, 11 miles north of Edinburg, recorded max heat indices between 111-114 from 115 through 445 PM. A Remote Automated Weather Station near Linn-San Manuel recorded max heat indices between 111-118F for 5 hours from 12:46-5:46 PM CDT - however, the site is known to run higher on temperature than surrounding locations, so the higher values (116 and more, between 146 and 446 PM CDT) are likely unrepresentative.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rancho Los Comitos (Texas Mesonet) recorded max heat indices of 111F for a couple of hours from 2:55-4:55 PM CDT on May 21, 2024. La Puerta Remote Automated Weather Station, 5.645 miles east of Rio Grande City, recorded max heat indices between 112-120F for 6 hours from 12:11-6:11 PM CDT on May 21, 2024. However, the site is known to be unrepresentative compared with proxy observations, so the higher values (116 and above) were not used for this event.  Time was adjusted by proxy to add an hour on either side of the Rancho Los Comitas location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second of a multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions continued on June 19, 2024 across much of eastern New York outside of the Adirondacks and eastern Catskills. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region.||The heat and humidity also resulted in isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon hours. A few storms became severe downing trees and wires.

An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport (KBRO) recorded max heat indices between 111-116F 1.5 hours, from 2:15-3:55 PM CDT on May 8, 2024. Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 111-118F for 3.5 hours, from 2:52-6:20 PM CDT on May 8, 2024.

This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falfurrias (AWOS) recorded max heat indices between 111-117F for about 4.5 hours, from 3:15-7:35 PM CDT on May 8, 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: McAllen International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 111-117F for 6 hours from 11:53 AM-5:53 PM CDT on May 21, 2024.  A period of excessive heat - 116F or higher - lasted from 230 PM to 430 PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second of a multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions continued on June 19, 2024 across much of eastern New York outside of the Adirondacks and eastern Catskills. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region.||The heat and humidity also resulted in isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon hours. A few storms became severe downing trees and wires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Texas Mesonet site in Sarita recorded heat index values between 111F and 113F for a few hours, between 150 and 320 PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across Southeast Oklahoma.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across East and Northeast Texas.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, before retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered just north of the Ark-La-Tex across the Ozarks and Mid-South region, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across North Louisiana.

The third of a multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions continued on June 20, 2024 across much of eastern New York outside of the Adirondacks and eastern Catskills. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region. In anticipation of dangerous conditions, several school districts made the decision to move elementary and middle school students to a half day schedule on Thursday June 20, 2024 including East Greenbush, Bethlehem, Lansingburgh, North Colonie, Stillwater, Voorheesville, and Schenectady. Additionally, the governor of NY activated the Natonal Guard and the state Emergency Operations Center to aid in any emergencies that arose related to the heat.||A strong upper-level ridge began to sink south through eastern New York on Thursday, June 20, giving way to a surface trough tracking north to south. Several upper-level shortwave disturbances within the flow aloft worked in tandem with this surface feature to contribute forcing for ascent in an environment abundant with instability due to antecedent, higher-than-normal heat and humidity. The result was scattered showers and thunderstorms, some of which became severe in nature in the counties of Warren, Washington, Saratoga, Albany, Rensselaer, and Columbia. ||Severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of tree and wire damage across the aforementioned areas in addition to nearly 48,000 people without power. The area greatest impacted was the city of Albany where the results of a storm survey concluded the occurrence of straight line winds with maximized speed of 75 mph. Here, substantial tree damage was sustained in Washington Park where numerous, hardwood tree branches fell and some trees were even uprooted. Additionally, isolated structural damage was also noted as a result of severe thunderstorms in the city of Albany. The Ten Broeck Mansion sustained significant tree damage, a steeple was partially blown off of St. Joseph's Church in the Ten Broeck Triangle Neighborhood, and a building on Thatcher Street partially collapsed resulting in its scheduled demolition (though it was not anticipated to be a total loss).

In anticipation of dangerous conditions, several school districts made the decision to move elementary and middle school students to a half day schedule on Thursday June 20, 2024 including East Greenbush, Bethlehem, Lansingburgh, North Colonie, Stillwater, Voorheesville, and Schenectady. Additionally, the governor of NY activated the Natonal Guard and the state Emergency Operations Center to aid in any emergencies that arose related to the heat.||A strong upper-level ridge began to sink south through eastern New York on Thursday, June 20, giving way to a surface trough tracking north to south. Several upper-level shortwave disturbances within the flow aloft worked in tandem with this surface feature to contribute forcing for ascent in an environment abundant with instability due to antecedent, higher-than-normal heat and humidity. The result was scattered showers and thunderstorms, some of which became severe in nature in the counties of Warren, Washington, Saratoga, Albany, Rensselaer, and Columbia. ||Severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of tree and wire damage across the aforementioned areas in addition to nearly 48,000 people without power. The area greatest impacted was the city of Albany where the results of a storm survey concluded the occurrence of straight line winds with maximized speed of 75 mph. Here, substantial tree damage was sustained in Washington Park where numerous, hardwood tree branches fell and some trees were even uprooted. Additionally, isolated structural damage was also noted as a result of severe thunderstorms in the city of Albany. The Ten Broeck Mansion sustained significant tree damage, a steeple was partially blown off of St. Joseph's Church in the Ten Broeck Triangle Neighborhood, and a building on Thatcher Street partially collapsed resulting in its scheduled demolition (though it was not anticipated to be a total loss).
