EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falfurrias (AWOS) recorded max heat indices between 111-128F for 9 hours, from 10:55 AM-7:55 PM CDT on May 26, 2024. However, since May 20th, the location observed higher values in temperature and humidity than surrounding locations, so the peak values and durations are likely too long.  The best estimate for Excessive Heat (116F or higher) times are used in this entry, between 1:55 and 5:15 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport (KBRO) recorded max heat indices between 114-121F for 6 hours, from 10:53 AM-4:53 PM CDT on May 27, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 117-121F for 3 hours, from 12:53-3:53 PM CDT. Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 113-120F for 4 hours, from 12:52-4:52 PM CDT on May 27, 2024. Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-120F for a couple of hours, from 1:52-3:52 PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. EVENT_NARRATIVE: McAllen International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 111-122F for 7 hours, from 11:53 AM-6:53 PM CDT on May 27, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 117-122F for 4 hours, from 1:53-5:53 PM CDT. South Texas International Airport (11 miles north of Edinburg, on the north/south Hidalgo County line) recorded max heat indices between 113-120F for 5 hours, from 12:55-5:55 PM CDT on May 27, 2024. Max heat indices fell within Excessive Heat Criteria with values between 116-120F for 3 hours, from 2:55-5:55PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge prevailed across the region in late June. A cold front had stalled just to the north of the area and moisture continued to surge into the Mid-South allowing dewpoints to rise into the upper 70s and lower 80s resulting in triple-digit heat indices.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture surged into the region while a strong upper ridge prevailed over the ArkLaTex region. Surface dewpoints climbed into the low to middle 70s while high temperatures rose into the lower to middle 90s resulting in high heat indices. The aforementioned upper ridge continued to intensify resulting in a couple of days of dangerous heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a month of cooler than average for coastal and valleys the first week of June began to heat up. Palm Springs reached its first 110F, topping at 112F on June 6. With the warm up the live fuel moisture and dead fuels dried quickly especially across the mountains and deserts. The Relay fire erupted on June 6, and then the Carmen fire on June 11 in Riverside County. Just south of I-10, the Carmen fire burned 65 acres and destroyed 4 outbuildings.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Palm Springs airport first 110F, reaching 112F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a month of cooler than average for coastal and valleys the first week of June began to heat up. Palm Springs reached its first 110F, topping at 112F on June 6. With the warm up the live fuel moisture and dead fuels dried quickly especially across the mountains and deserts. The Relay fire erupted on June 6, and then the Carmen fire on June 11 in Riverside County. Just south of I-10, the Carmen fire burned 65 acres and destroyed 4 outbuildings.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anza Borrego State Park reached 108F both June 6 and 7th. Hottest days of the year and greatest HeatRisk (departure from averages).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High Desert temperatures reached 102 to 105F in the Apple and Victorville Valleys on both June 5 and 6th, 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperature and moisture has continued to prevail across the area, resulting in excessive heat indices across many coastal and urban areas in the islands. These heat values lead to the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in the Mesonet registered heat indices values of 112 degrees for two hours or more.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across East and Northeast Texas.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across East and Northeast Texas.

Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across East and Northeast Texas.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, before retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered just north of the Ark-La-Tex across the Ozarks and Mid-South region, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across North Louisiana.

A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Zapata recorded max heat indices between 112-116F from 11:55 AM-5:55 PM CDT on May 27, 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The third of a multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions continued on June 20, 2024 across much of eastern New York outside of the Adirondacks and eastern Catskills. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region. In anticipation of dangerous conditions, several school districts made the decision to move elementary and middle school students to a half day schedule on Thursday June 20, 2024 including East Greenbush, Bethlehem, Lansingburgh, North Colonie, Stillwater, Voorheesville, and Schenectady. Additionally, the governor of NY activated the Natonal Guard and the state Emergency Operations Center to aid in any emergencies that arose related to the heat.||A strong upper-level ridge began to sink south through eastern New York on Thursday, June 20, giving way to a surface trough tracking north to south. Several upper-level shortwave disturbances within the flow aloft worked in tandem with this surface feature to contribute forcing for ascent in an environment abundant with instability due to antecedent, higher-than-normal heat and humidity. The result was scattered showers and thunderstorms, some of which became severe in nature in the counties of Warren, Washington, Saratoga, Albany, Rensselaer, and Columbia. ||Severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of tree and wire damage across the aforementioned areas in addition to nearly 48,000 people without power. The area greatest impacted was the city of Albany where the results of a storm survey concluded the occurrence of straight line winds with maximized speed of 75 mph. Here, substantial tree damage was sustained in Washington Park where numerous, hardwood tree branches fell and some trees were even uprooted. Additionally, isolated structural damage was also noted as a result of severe thunderstorms in the city of Albany. The Ten Broeck Mansion sustained significant tree damage, a steeple was partially blown off of St. Joseph's Church in the Ten Broeck Triangle Neighborhood, and a building on Thatcher Street partially collapsed resulting in its scheduled demolition (though it was not anticipated to be a total loss).

Additionally, isolated structural damage was also noted as a result of severe thunderstorms in the city of Albany. The Ten Broeck Mansion sustained significant tree damage, a steeple was partially blown off of St. Joseph's Church in the Ten Broeck Triangle Neighborhood, and a building on Thatcher Street partially collapsed resulting in its scheduled demolition (though it was not anticipated to be a total loss).

June 22, 2024 was the fifth day in the stretch of hot, humid conditions. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across Litchfield County.||Scattered showers and thunderstorms impacted Litchfield County on Saturday, June 22. Isolated instances of thunderstorms becoming severe resulting in some downed trees.
Four people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.

An upper-level ridge prevailed across the region in late June. A cold front had stalled just to the north of the area and moisture continued to surge into the Mid-South allowing dewpoints to rise into the upper 70s and lower 80s resulting in triple-digit heat indices.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture surged into the region while a strong upper ridge prevailed over the ArkLaTex region. The aforementioned upper ridge continued to intensify resulting in a couple of days of dangerous heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on June 18, 2024 and continued through June 20, 2024 across western Massachusetts. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 101 degrees across the region each day. Due to the anticipated impacts of the dangerous heat, cooling centers were opened throughout Berkshire County and local fire departments placed misting fans on street corners in the town of Pittsfield in order to provide relief and mitigate heat-related illness.

Additionally, the governor of NY activated the Natonal Guard and the state Emergency Operations Center to aid in any emergencies that arose related to the heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rancho Los Comitos (Texas Mesonet) recorded max heat indices between 111-115F for 3 hours, from 3:00-6:00 PM CDT (2 to 5 PM CST) on May 8, 2024.  By proxy, southern Jim Hogg County (less than 10 miles north of this location) can be assumed to have observed similar values during this time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 111-118F for 3.5 hours, from 2:52-6:20 PM CDT on May 8, 2024. The Sarita Mesonet station in Kenedy County recorded peak heat index values between 111 and 115F between 2 and 430 PM CST.  By proxy, Willacy County likely had similar heat index values (111 to 116) between 1 PM and 5 PM CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 113-119F for 6 hours, from 11:52 AM-5:52 PM CDT on May 26, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-119F for 4 hours, from 12:52-4:52 PM CDT.  By proxy, Valley International Airport combined with the Texas AgriScience Center location just west of the Willacy/Hidalgo line, which recorded 116-118F heat index values between 420 and 550 PM, are proxy values used to infer heat index values.  Dangerous heat (111F or higher) began approximately one to two hours on either side of the excessive heat conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat from multiple days of hot daytime temperatures and very warm overnight temperatures was observed on June 4th through June 6th across much of interior Northern California. Daily maximum record temperatures were tied or broken, with Vacaville Airport reaching 104 degrees on June 5th, breaking the old record of 103 set in 2002. Marysville Airport reached 104 degrees on June 5th, which tied the old record of 104 set in 2002.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather stations in the area reported daytime high temperatures of 90 to 100 degrees across this zone, with overnight lows in the 60s to low 70 degree range from June 4th through June 6th.

Surface dewpoints climbed into the low to middle 70s while high temperatures rose into the lower to middle 90s resulting in high heat indices. The aforementioned upper ridge continued to intensify resulting in a couple of days of dangerous heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first of a multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on June 18, 2024 across much of eastern New York outside of the Adirondacks and eastern Catskills. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region. In anticipation of dangerous conditions, several school districts made the decision to move elementary and middle school students to a half day schedule on Tuesday June 18, 2024 including East Greenbush, Bethlehem, Lansingburgh, North Colonie, Stillwater, Voorheesville, and Schenectady. Additionally, the governor of NY activated the Natonal Guard and the state Emergency Operations Center to aid in any emergencies that arose related to the heat.

A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cameron County Airport near Bayview recorded an estimated 5 hours of heat index between 111F and 114F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In San Diego County, starting June 22, the Border 58 wildfire burned 137 acres east of Chula Vista on Otay Mountain Truck Trail, Otay Mountain Wilderness in Otay Mesa, California. Finally, in Del Mar Heights near Torrey Pines a wildfire burned 20 acres on June 25 and resulted in evacuation orders.  Riverside March ARB hit 106F on June 22 and  Palm Springs reached 115F again on June 23 and 24th, 2024, then the hottest date of the month was June 30 topping at 116F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A hiker likely passed away from heat stroke off Nighthawk Trail on Black Mountain. Medical examiner is determining exact cause. At 700 am the temperature was 76F with a dewpoint 64F, wind southeast below 5 mph and relative humidity 67 percent at the base of Black Mountain and 93F at the summit of 1558 feet MSL. At 915 am the summit was 98F (SDHGPA site) and then the wind shifted to the west and gusted to 16 mph with a sea breeze lowering the temperature to 86F at the summit by 1100 am. At 1100 am, the base temperature was 84F and humidity at 58 percent. The highest temperature measured at the base was 86F at 1010 am per SDGE Rancho Penasquitos. Media reported a distress call to her family at 1008 am by the hiker saying she was very hot and she needed water. The hiker was separated from a large group of persons. The last contact to her sister was a photo from the top of Black Mountain summit. The hike is listed as moderate difficulty with 5.6 miles loop and roughly 3 hours to complete with a 850 feet elevation gain. Search and rescue consisted of 3 helicopters including infrared and drones as well as about 50 persons on foot. The search was called off at 1 am. Cell phone pings were not able to get an exact location. The search resumed at 730 am Monday. The 50 year old female was found at 915 am Monday just off the main trail and 1/4 mile from a population center. A heat advisory was in effect.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures soared again starting June 14, 2024. Palm Springs reached 115F both June 14 and 15. In Riverside the high temperatures hit the mid to upper 90s on June 15.  The Hesperia wildfire began on June 15, The Stoddard fire burn 475 acres just north of Victorville and started June 11. The Lisa fire started on June 16 and scorched 890 acres near Highway 60 and Jack Rabbit Trail, East of Moreno Valley. An in Palm Springs the Tuscany fire erupted to just over 100 acres on June 17.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On both June 14 and 15, 2024, Palm Springs airport reached 115F, hottest days of the year and greatest HeatRisk (depature from averages).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperature and moisture has continued to prevail across the area, resulting in excessive heat indices across many coastal and urban areas in the islands. These heat values lead to the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in the Mesonet registered heat indices values of 112 degrees for two hours or more.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across East and Northeast Texas.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, before retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered just north of the Ark-La-Tex across the Ozarks and Mid-South region, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across North Louisiana.

June 21, 2024 was the fourth day in the stretch of hot, humid conditions though, unlike its predecessors, only featured such conditions in the lower Mid-Hudson Valley. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 100 degrees across eastern Ulster and Dutchess Counties.||A lingering surface trough and weak cold front tracked southward through eastern New York on June 21. Warm, moist antecedent conditions aided in providing a fairly unstable environment and requisite values of several severe weather parameters working in tandem with the aforementioned forcing mechanisms drove scattered severe thunderstorms in the Capital District and Mid-Hudson Valley.||Severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of downed trees and wires in Ulster, Saratoga, Rensselaer, and Dutchess Counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over the Desert Southwest led to an early-season heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on four straight days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over the Desert Southwest led to an early-season heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on four straight days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over the Desert Southwest led to an early-season heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on four straight days. During and immediately after the excessive heat, 19 people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport (KBRO) recorded max heat indices between 111-113F for a couple of hours, from around 11:30 through around 3 PM CDT on May 25, 2024. Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 111-115F for from around 1230 until 330 PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and high humidity combined to create dangerous heat indices (exceeding 110-degrees) across the western two-thirds of Oklahoma during the afternoon/evening of the 23rd through 28th.

A multi-day heatwave brought excessive heat to Maine with temperatures and high humidity bringing heat index values above 95 degrees.  The heat began on June 17th before peaking in intensity on June 19th and 20th with heat index values above 100F.  This was one of the earliest heat waves on record with July like heat and humidity being experienced in June.  Impacts: CDC data indicated a spike in hospitals visits for heat related illnesses.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An early season heat wave impacted Maine from June 17th through the 20th with the peak of the heat occurring June 19th-20th when excessive heat was observed through southern and central parts of the state away from the immediate coast. Heat index values reached above 105F across southwestern Maine, with the Rachel Carson RAWS reaching a heat index of 109F and the Sanford ASOS reached a value of 106F. Maine CDC data showed a spike in hospital visits across the state with heat related hospital visits well above the 95th percentile. It was the 2nd highest hospital visit rate for heat since the July heat wave of 2018.

Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered just north of the Ark-La-Tex across the Ozarks and Mid-South region, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across East and Northeast Texas.

Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across East and Northeast Texas.

June 21, 2024 was the fourth day in the stretch of hot, humid conditions though, unlike its predecessors, only featured such conditions in the lower Mid-Hudson Valley. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 100 degrees across eastern Ulster and Dutchess Counties.||A lingering surface trough and weak cold front tracked southward through eastern New York on June 21. Warm, moist antecedent conditions aided in providing a fairly unstable environment and requisite values of several severe weather parameters working in tandem with the aforementioned forcing mechanisms drove scattered severe thunderstorms in the Capital District and Mid-Hudson Valley.||Severe thunderstorms resulted in numerous reports of downed trees and wires in Ulster, Saratoga, Rensselaer, and Dutchess Counties.

June 21, 2024 was the fourth day in the stretch of hot, humid conditions. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across Litchfield County.||A lingering surface trough and weak cold front tracked southward through northwest Connecticut on June 21. Warm, moist antecedent conditions aided in providing a fairly unstable environment and requisite values of several severe weather parameters working in tandem with the aforementioned forcing mechanisms drove scattered severe thunderstorms in Litchfield County.||Severe thunderstorms resulted in several reports of downed trees. Additionally, one severe thunderstorm produced a weak, EF0 tornado that touched down in the town of Harwinton. The tornado touched down along Spring Hill Road just before 5 PM and followed along a path of about 2 miles. With maximum estimated wind speeds of 85 mph and a path width of 250 yards, extensive tree damage was sustained with limbs broken and trees uprooted sporadically along the path. An estimated $15000 in tree damage was sustained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Linn-San Manuel (Remote Automated Weather Sensor) recorded heat indices between 116-122F for 6 hours, from 12:46-6:46 PM CDT (1146-546 PM CST) on May 9, 2024. Between the hours of 11:46 AM to 7:46 PM CDT (1046 AM to 656 PM CST) (8 hours), heat indices were at least 111F. The South Texas International Airport (north of Edinburg) recorded heat indices between 117-123F for 4 hours, from 1:55-5:55 PM CDT (1255 to 455 PM CST) on May 9, 2024. Between the hours of 1:55 PM to 7:55 PM CDT (1255 to 655 CST; 6 hours), heat indices were at least 111F.||As of this writing, there were no known fatalities from these near-record heat index values (annual), but hospitalizations increased compared with average in the McAllen/Mission area due to heat-related illnesses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Texas Mesonet site at Sarita recorded heat index values between 111 and 114F+ from 120 through 330 PM CDT on May 27th.  By proxy with the Mesonet site at the Texas AgriScience Center near the northeast Hidalgo/northwest Willacy line, which had more than four hours of 111F+ but just 1.5 hours between 116 and 119, it is inferred that the majority of inland Kenedy County fell into the dangerous (111-115F), rather than excessive (116F+) heat category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Texas Mesonet site at Sarita reported peak heat index values between 111F and 114F  between 1 PM and 430 PM on May 28th. Proxy values from the Texas AgriScience center near the eastern Hidalgo/northwest Willacy line just southwest of the Kenedy line) indicated heat index values between 111 and 117F from 1255 and 540 PM, but 117 was only touched for an estimated 25 minutes between 345 and 410 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 111-115F for from around 1230 until 330 PM CDT. By proxy, it is inferred that at least southern Willacy County experienced similar conditions to northern Cameron (near Harlingen).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A multi-day heatwave brought excessive heat to Maine with temperatures and high humidity bringing heat index values above 95 degrees.  The heat began on June 17th before peaking in intensity on June 19th and 20th with heat index values above 100F.  This was one of the earliest heat waves on record with July like heat and humidity being experienced in June.  Impacts: CDC data indicated a spike in hospitals visits for heat related illnesses.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An early season heat wave impacted Maine from June 17th through the 20th with the peak of the heat occurring June 19th-20th when excessive heat was observed through southern and central parts of the state away from the immediate coast. Heat index values reached above 105F across southwestern Maine, with the Rachel Carson RAWS reaching a heat index of 109F and the Sanford ASOS reached a value of 106F. Maine CDC data showed a spike in hospital visits across the state with heat related hospital visits well above the 95th percentile. It was the 2nd highest hospital visit rate for heat since the July heat wave of 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A multi-day heatwave brought excessive heat to Maine with temperatures and high humidity bringing heat index values above 95 degrees.  The heat began on June 17th before peaking in intensity on June 19th and 20th with heat index values above 100F.  This was one of the earliest heat waves on record with July like heat and humidity being experienced in June.  Impacts: CDC data indicated a spike in hospitals visits for heat related illnesses.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An early season heat wave impacted Maine from June 17th through the 20th with the peak of the heat occurring June 19th-20th when excessive heat was observed through southern and central parts of the state away from the immediate coast. Heat index values reached above 105F across southwestern Maine, with the Portland ASOS reaching a heat index of 104F and numerous sites reaching around 108F further inland. Maine CDC data showed a spike in hospital visits across the state with heat related hospital visits well above the 95th percentile. It was the 2nd highest hospital visit rate for heat since the July heat wave of 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture surged into the region while a strong upper ridge prevailed over the ArkLaTex region. Surface dewpoints climbed into the low to middle 70s while high temperatures rose into the lower to middle 90s resulting in high heat indices. The aforementioned upper ridge continued to intensify resulting in a couple of days of dangerous heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first of a multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on June 18, 2024 across much of eastern New York outside of the Adirondacks and eastern Catskills. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region. In anticipation of dangerous conditions, several school districts made the decision to move elementary and middle school students to a half day schedule on Tuesday June 18, 2024 including East Greenbush, Bethlehem, Lansingburgh, North Colonie, Stillwater, Voorheesville, and Schenectady. Additionally, the governor of NY activated the Natonal Guard and the state Emergency Operations Center to aid in any emergencies that arose related to the heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across East and Northeast Texas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: South Texas International Airport, 11 mile north of Edinburg along the north/south Hidalgo County line, recorded max heat indices between 113-120F for 5 hours, from 12:55-5:55 PM CDT on May 27, 2024. Linn-San Manuel recorded max heat indices between 112-120F degrees for 6 hours, from 11:46 AM-5:46 PM CDT. Max heat indices fell within Excessive Heat Criteria with values between 116-120F for 4 hours, between 1:46-5:46PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 113-120F for 4 hours, from 12:52-4:52 PM CDT on May 27, 2024. Excessive heat criteria with values between 116-120F for a couple of hours, from 1:30-3:30 PM CDT. By proxy, and using a reference of the Texas AgriScience Center along the Willacy/Hidalgo line, which had 1.5 hours of heat index between 116 and 119, inland Willacy is assumed to have three hours of excessive heat index values.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong high pressure ridge aloft produced temperatures above 100 degrees along with heat index values at or above 105 degrees for the last week of June. Heat Advisories were needed for many days with a few Excessive Heat Warnings needed June 27-29th (see separate Episode for Excessive Heat information).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above average temperatures stretched from June 24th through the end of the month and into July. Several prolonged Heat Advisories were in effect, and at times Excessive Heat Warnings were needed, as temperatures soared over 100 degrees and/or heat index values recorded over 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A multi-day heatwave brought excessive heat to Maine with temperatures and high humidity bringing heat index values above 95 degrees.  The heat began on June 17th before peaking in intensity on June 19th and 20th with heat index values above 100F.  This was one of the earliest heat waves on record with July like heat and humidity being experienced in June.  Impacts: CDC data indicated a spike in hospitals visits for heat related illnesses.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An early season heat wave impacted Maine from June 17th through the 20th with the peak of the heat occurring June 19th-20th when excessive heat was observed through southern and central parts of the state away from the immediate coast. Heat index values reached above 105F across southwestern Maine, with the Portland ASOS reaching a heat index of 104F and numerous sites reaching around 108F further inland. Maine CDC data showed a spike in hospital visits across the state with heat related hospital visits well above the 95th percentile. It was the 2nd highest hospital visit rate for heat since the July heat wave of 2018.

CDC data showed a spike in hospital visits across the Northeast with heat related hospital visits well above the 95th percentile.  It was the 4th highest hospital visit rate since 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mostly clear skies and plenty of moisture surging in from the south allowed for heat indices to reach 105 to 112 degrees across Southern Illinois. The highest observed heat index in Southern Illinois was 112 degrees at the Dixon Springs RAWS site. A line of thunderstorms advancing southward through the afternoon hours brought an end to heat concerns for the day with the passage of an outflow boundary.

Moisture surged into the region while a strong upper ridge prevailed over the ArkLaTex region. Surface dewpoints climbed into the low to middle 70s while high temperatures rose into the lower to middle 90s resulting in high heat indices. The aforementioned upper ridge continued to intensify resulting in a couple of days of dangerous heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first of a multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on June 18, 2024 across much of eastern New York outside of the Adirondacks and eastern Catskills. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region. In anticipation of dangerous conditions, several school districts made the decision to move elementary and middle school students to a half day schedule on Tuesday June 18, 2024 including East Greenbush, Bethlehem, Lansingburgh, North Colonie, Stillwater, Voorheesville, and Schenectady. Additionally, the governor of NY activated the Natonal Guard and the state Emergency Operations Center to aid in any emergencies that arose related to the heat.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during late June. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the upper 90s, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across west central Arkansas on the 24th.

Above normal temperature and moisture has continued to prevail across the area, resulting in excessive heat indices across many coastal and urban areas in the islands. These heat values lead to the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in the Mesonet registered heat indices values of 112 degrees for two hours or more.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cameron County Airport Automated Surface Observing Sensor near Bayview recorded around 4.5 hours of heat index values between 111 and 115F between 1153 AM CDT and 430 PM CDT. Peak values of 115 occurred between 253 and 353 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across North Louisiana.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, before retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered just north of the Ark-La-Tex across the Ozarks and Mid-South region, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across East and Northeast Texas.

A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: La Puerta (AWOS) recorded max heat indices between 111-122F for 7 hours, from 11:11-6:11 PM CDT on May 28, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 117-122F for 3 hours, from 1:11-4:11 PM CDT. Rancho Los Comitos (AWOS) recorded max heat indices between 111-114F for a couple of hours, from 3:00-5:00 PM CDT on May 28, 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cameron County Airport near Bayview recorded an estimated 5 hours of heat index between 111F and 114F.  By proxy, and accounting for slightly lower temperatures and heat index in inland Kenedy County, the likely time of dangerous heat (111F to 115F) was one hour less on each side of the observation from Bayview, for coastal Willacy County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong high pressure ridge aloft produced temperatures above 100 degrees along with heat index values at or above 110 degrees for most of North and Central Texas during a couple of days in late June. Amid ongoing Heat Advisories, much of the region was placed under an Excessive Heat Warning between June 27-29, 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values at or above 110 occurred across much of the county June 28 and June 29.

Amid ongoing Heat Advisories, much of the region was placed under an Excessive Heat Warning between June 27-29, 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values at or above 110 occurred across much of the county on June 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A multi-day heatwave brought excessive heat to New Hampshire with temperatures and high humidity bringing heat index values above 95 degrees. The heat began on June 17th before peaking in intensity on June 19th and 20th with heat index values above 100F. This was one of the earliest heat waves on record with July like heat and humidity being experienced in June. Impacts: CDC data indicated a spike in hospitals visits for heat related illnesses.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An early season heat wave impacted New Hampshire from June 17th through the 20th with the peak of the heat occurring June 19th-20th when excessive heat was observed through southern and central parts of the state.  Heat index values reached above 105F across southern New Hampshire, with the Manchester ASOS recording a reading of 106F and other AWOS readings at 108F.  CDC data showed a spike in hospital visits across the Northeast with heat related hospital visits well above the 95th percentile.  It was the 4th highest hospital visit rate since 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mostly clear skies and plenty of moisture surging in from the south allowed for heat indices to reach 105 to 112 degrees across Southern Illinois. The highest observed heat index in Southern Illinois was 112 degrees at the Dixon Springs RAWS site. A line of thunderstorms advancing southward through the afternoon hours brought an end to heat concerns for the day with the passage of an outflow boundary.

Moisture surged into the region while a strong upper ridge prevailed over the ArkLaTex region. Surface dewpoints climbed into the low to middle 70s while high temperatures rose into the lower to middle 90s resulting in high heat indices. The aforementioned upper ridge continued to intensify resulting in a couple of days of dangerous heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging prevailed from the southwest U.S. eastward across the southern states. Moisture pooled along a stalled frontal boundary across the Mid-South with dewpoints rising into the upper 70s. The abundance of moisture combined with temperatures around 100 degrees resulted in widespread high heat indices.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first of a multi-day stretch of hot and humid conditions began on June 18, 2024 across much of eastern New York outside of the Adirondacks and eastern Catskills. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across the region. In anticipation of dangerous conditions, several school districts made the decision to move elementary and middle school students to a half day schedule on Tuesday June 18, 2024 including East Greenbush, Bethlehem, Lansingburgh, North Colonie, Stillwater, Voorheesville, and Schenectady. Additionally, the governor of NY activated the Natonal Guard and the state Emergency Operations Center to aid in any emergencies that arose related to the heat.

Above normal temperature and moisture has continued to prevail across the area, resulting in excessive heat indices across many coastal and urban areas in the islands. These heat values lead to the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in the Mesonet registered heat indices values of 112 degrees for two hours or more.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across North Louisiana.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, before retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered just north of the Ark-La-Tex across the Ozarks and Mid-South region, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across East and Northeast Texas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during late June. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the upper 90s, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across portions of eastern Oklahoma on the 24th through the 25th. At least ten people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, five of which were transported to the hospital.

At least ten people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, five of which were transported to the hospital.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late June. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid to upper 90s, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 117 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 28th through the 30th. At least ten people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, five of which were transported to the hospital. This heat wave persisted into early July.

A multi-day heatwave brought excessive heat to New Hampshire with temperatures and high humidity bringing heat index values above 95 degrees. The heat began on June 17th before peaking in intensity on June 19th and 20th with heat index values above 100F. This was one of the earliest heat waves on record with July like heat and humidity being experienced in June. Impacts: CDC data indicated a spike in hospitals visits for heat related illnesses.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An early season heat wave impacted New Hampshire from June 17th through the 20th with the peak of the heat occurring June 19th-20th when excessive heat was observed through southern and central parts of the state.  Heat index values reached above 105F across southern New Hampshire, with the Rochester ASOS recording a heat index reading of 109F and other unofficial readings of 106F.  CDC data showed a spike in hospital visits across the Northeast with heat related hospital visits well above the 95th percentile.  It was the 4th highest hospital visit rate since 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mostly clear skies and plenty of moisture surging in from the south allowed for heat indices to reach 105 to 112 degrees across Southern Illinois. The highest observed heat index in Southern Illinois was 112 degrees at the Dixon Springs RAWS site. A line of thunderstorms advancing southward through the afternoon hours brought an end to heat concerns for the day with the passage of an outflow boundary.

Moisture surged into the region while a strong upper ridge prevailed over the ArkLaTex region. Surface dewpoints climbed into the low to middle 70s while high temperatures rose into the lower to middle 90s resulting in high heat indices. The aforementioned upper ridge continued to intensify resulting in a couple of days of dangerous heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging prevailed from the southwest U.S. eastward across the southern states. Moisture pooled along a stalled frontal boundary across the Mid-South with dewpoints rising into the upper 70s. The abundance of moisture combined with temperatures around 100 degrees resulted in widespread high heat indices.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperature and moisture has continued to prevail across the area, resulting in excessive heat indices across many coastal and urban areas in the islands. These heat values lead to the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in the Mesonet registered heat indices values of 112 degrees for two hours or more.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across North Louisiana.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, before retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered just north of the Ark-La-Tex across the Ozarks and Mid-South region, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across East and Northeast Texas.

Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across East and Northeast Texas.

June 22, 2024 was the fifth day in the stretch of hot, humid conditions and, like the day prior, only featured such conditions in the lower Mid-Hudson Valley. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 102 degrees across eastern Ulster and Dutchess Counties.||A stationary boundary was draped across northern portions of eastern New York (southwest Adirondacks and Upper-Hudson Valley), creating a warm sector for areas to the south. Decent instability paired with requisite shear and steep low-level lapse rates allowed scattered showers and thunderstorms, some of which became severe, to develop. Severe storms primarily occurred in the Eastern Catskills and Mid-Hudson Valley, resulting in several reports of downed trees and wires. Additionally, an isolated thunderstorm in Herkimer County resulted in the occurrence of an EF1 tornado. The tornado touched down near West Winfield and followed along a path of 1.96 miles with a width of 200 yards and maximum estimated wind gusts of 100 mph. Damage consisted of detriment to a barn, destruction of a small shed and snapped and uprooted trees that fell and damaged two homes.

A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport (KBRO) recorded max heat indices between 111-119F for 7 hours, from 9:53 AM-4:53 PM CDT on May 26, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-119F for 5 hours, from 11:53 AM-4:53 PM CDT. Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 113-119F for 6 hours, from 11:52 AM-5:52 PM CDT on May 26, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-119F for 4 hours, from 12:52-4:52 PM CDT.

Moisture pooled along a stalled frontal boundary across the Mid-South with dewpoints rising into the upper 70s. The abundance of moisture combined with temperatures around 100 degrees resulted in widespread high heat indices.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in between 105 and 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperature and moisture has continued to prevail across the area, resulting in excessive heat indices across many coastal and urban areas in the islands. These heat values lead to the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in the Mesonet registered heat indices values of 112 degrees for two hours or more.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Linn-San Manuel Remote Automated Weather System (RAWS) recorded max heat indices between 111-115F for up to 6 hours, from 12:46-6:46 PM CDT on May 8, 2024.  The South Texas International Airport (KEBG) Automated Weather Observing Station along the edge of northern and southern Hidalgo County peaked at 117F at 215 PM, with 111F+ values generally from 1235 through 555 PM.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: La Puerta Remote Automated Weather Sensor (RAWS) 5.65 miles east of Rio Grande City recorded max heat indices between 111-117F for 4 hours, from 2:11-6:11 PM CDT on May 8, 2024. Rancho Los Comitos (Texas Mesonet) recorded max heat indices between 111-115F for 3 hours, from 3:00-6:00 PM CDT on May 8, 2024.  Note that the La Puerta location runs a bit higher, so proxy values may be closer to 111-113 nearby.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across North Louisiana.

June 22, 2024 was the fifth day in the stretch of hot, humid conditions and, like the day prior, only featured such conditions in the lower Mid-Hudson Valley. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 102 degrees across eastern Ulster and Dutchess Counties.||A stationary boundary was draped across northern portions of eastern New York (southwest Adirondacks and Upper-Hudson Valley), creating a warm sector for areas to the south. Decent instability paired with requisite shear and steep low-level lapse rates allowed scattered showers and thunderstorms, some of which became severe, to develop. Severe storms primarily occurred in the Eastern Catskills and Mid-Hudson Valley, resulting in several reports of downed trees and wires. Additionally, an isolated thunderstorm in Herkimer County resulted in the occurrence of an EF1 tornado. The tornado touched down near West Winfield and followed along a path of 1.96 miles with a width of 200 yards and maximum estimated wind gusts of 100 mph. Damage consisted of detriment to a barn, destruction of a small shed and snapped and uprooted trees that fell and damaged two homes.

A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rancho Los Comitos (Texas Mesonet) recorded max heat indices between 112-119F for 6 hours, from 2:00-8:00 PM CDT. Heat indices met Excessive Heat Warning criteria for 3 hours, from 4:00-7:00 PM CDT with values between 116-119F on May 26, 2024. La Puerta Remote Automated Weather Station recorded max heat indices between 111-127F for 9 hours, from 11:11 AM-8:11 PM CDT on May 26, 2024. This not only fell within the Heat Advisory criteria range, but also the Excessive Heat range with values between 118-127F for 6 hours, from 1:11-7:11 PM CDT.  Please note that the La Puerta site has a high bias, so actual peak heat index values closer to the Rio Grande may have ranged from 119 to 123F.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: McAllen International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 112-125F for 7 hours, from 11:53 AM-6:53 PM CDT on May 26, 2024. Heat indices reached excessive heat criteria with values between 116-125F for 6 hours, from 12:53-6:53 PM CDT.  South Texas International Airport, along the northern and southern Hidalgo County line, reached xxx.  Weslaco/Mid Valley Airport experienced heat index of 111F or higher form 1230 until 630 PM, with excessive heat (116 or higher) from 345 through 445 PM.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: South Texas International Airport, 11 miles north of Edinburg and along the north/south Hidalgo County line, recorded max heat indices between 112-120F for 7 hours, from 11:55 AM-6:55 PM CDT on May 26, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-120F for 3 hours, from 2:55-5:55 PM CDT. Linn-San Manuel Remote Automated Weather Station recorded max heat indices between 111-124F degrees for 9 hours, between 10:46 AM-7:46 PM CDT. Max heat indices fell within Excessive Heat Criteria with values between 116-124F for 7 hours, between 11:46 AM-6:46 PM CDT.  Note, however, that this site has a high bias; therefore, the data at South Texas International Airport is accepted as more accurate.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mostly clear skies and plenty of moisture surging in from the south allowed for heat indices to reach 105 to 113 degrees across Southeast Missouri. The highest observed heat index in Southeast Missouri was 113 degrees at the Cape Girardeau Regional Airport ASOS site. An outflow boundary advancing southward during the late afternoon into the early evening brought an end to heat concerns for the day.

Moisture surged into the region while a strong upper ridge prevailed over the ArkLaTex region. Surface dewpoints climbed into the low to middle 70s while high temperatures rose into the lower to middle 90s resulting in high heat indices. The aforementioned upper ridge continued to intensify resulting in a couple of days of dangerous heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brownsville/South Padre International Airport (KBRO) recorded max heat indices between 111 and just below 114.5F for around four hours from around 130 through 530 PM CDT on May 23, 2024. Harlingen/Valley International Airport (KHRL) stayed just below criteria due to slightly lower humidity, but the southern half of inland Cameron likely reached criteria.

June 23, 2024 was the sixth and final day in the stretch of hot, humid conditions and, like the two days prior, only featured such conditions in the lower Mid-Hudson Valley. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across eastern Ulster and Dutchess Counties.||A low pressure system and potent upper shortwave tracked east from the Great Lakes region, lifting a warm front through eastern New York on the morning of June 23. With a cold front to the west, eastern New York fell into the warm sector of the system with warm, moist antecedent conditions contributing to sufficient instability. Higher values of low- and deep-layer shear and steep lapse rates paired with ample forcing from a low level jet gave way to scattered showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon of June 23. Some storms became severe, leading to numerous reports of tree and wire damage in Fulton, Montgomery, Washington, Rensselaer, Dutchess, Ulster, and Schenectady Counties.

An upper-level ridge prevailed across the region in late June. A cold front had stalled just to the north of the area and moisture continued to surge into the Mid-South allowing dewpoints to rise into the upper 70s and lower 80s resulting in triple-digit heat indices.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture surged into the region while a strong upper ridge prevailed over the ArkLaTex region. Surface dewpoints climbed into the low to middle 70s while high temperatures rose into the lower to middle 90s resulting in high heat indices. The aforementioned upper ridge continued to intensify resulting in a couple of days of dangerous heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices around 106 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging prevailed from the southwest U.S. eastward across the southern states. Moisture pooled along a stalled frontal boundary across the Mid-South with dewpoints rising into the upper 70s. The abundance of moisture combined with temperatures around 100 degrees resulted in widespread high heat indices.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in between 105 and 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: McAllen International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 113-121F for 5 hours, from 11:53 to around 6:30 PM CDT on May 24, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-121F for 4 hours, from around 130 until 530 PM. At South Texas International Airport 11 miles north of Edinburg and on the line between north and south Hidalgo County, peak heat index ranged from 112F to 117F between around 125 and 615 PM CDT, peaking qt 117F between 315 and 415 PM.  Weslaco Mid-Valley airport, in southeast Hidalgo, reached 111 to near 113F between 230 and 400 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across Southwest Arkansas.
