An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport (KBRO) recorded heat indices between 118-125F for 4 hours, from 12:53-4:53 PM CDT (1153 to 353 CST) on May 9, 2024. Peak value was 125F at 253 PM, a May record and near the all-time record since hourly data have been available. Between the hours of 10:53 AM (953 AM to 510 PM CDT) to 6:10 PM CDT (about 7.5 hours), heat indices were at least 111F. Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded heat indices between 117-125F for 4 hours, from 1:52-5:52 PM CDT (1252 to 452 CST). The value of 125F was a May record, and rivaled all-time hourly records.  Between the hours of 11:52 AM to 6:52 PM CDT (7 hours), heat indices were at least 111F.  ||Ambient temperatures set daily and monthly records for May 9th.  There were no known direct fatalities, though hospitalizations for heat-related illnesses increased by an unknown number on this day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport (KBRO) recorded max heat indices between 111-115F for 5 hours, from 11:43 AM to around 5:00 PM CDT. Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 112-115F for 3 hours, from 12:52-3:52 PM CDT on May 24, 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falfurrias (AWOS) recorded max heat indices between 112-123F for 7 hours, from 11:55 AM-6:55 PM CDT on May 27, 2024. Excessive heat values  (116F or higher) fell between 118-123F occurred for 3 hours, between 2 and 430 PM CDT.  Note that the Brooks Co. Airport AWOS appeared to have high bias issues since mid-May, so actual values and time duration of excessive heat are of shorter duration than shown on the observations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong high pressure ridge aloft produced temperatures above 100 degrees along with heat index values at or above 105 degrees for the last week of June. Heat Advisories were needed for many days with a few Excessive Heat Warnings needed June 27-29th (see separate Episode for Excessive Heat information).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above average temperatures stretched from June 24th through the end of the month and into July. Several prolonged Heat Advisories were in effect, and at times Excessive Heat Warnings were needed, as temperatures soared over 100 degrees and/or heat index values recorded over 105 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falfurrias (AWOS) recorded max heat indices between 111-119F from 12:55-5:55 PM CDT on May 28, 2024. Excessive heat warning values fell between 116-119F occurred between 2:55-4:55 PM CDT.  Note that these values may be up to two degrees two high based on proxy observations and a high bias at the location (temperature and especially dewpoint) since mid May.  A better estimate was from around 330 until 530 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mostly clear skies and plenty of moisture surging in from the south allowed for heat indices to reach 105 to 115 degrees across much of Southwest Kentucky. The highest observed heat index in Southwest Kentucky was 115 degrees at the Sturgis Municipal Airport AWOS site. Thunderstorms and a surging outflow boundary advancing southward during the mid-afternoon through the early evening brought an end to heat concerns for the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture surged into the region while a strong upper ridge prevailed over the ArkLaTex region. Surface dewpoints climbed into the low to middle 70s while high temperatures rose into the lower to middle 90s resulting in high heat indices. The aforementioned upper ridge continued to intensify resulting in a couple of days of dangerous heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging prevailed from the southwest U.S. eastward across the southern states. Moisture pooled along a stalled frontal boundary across the Mid-South with dewpoints rising into the upper 70s. The abundance of moisture combined with temperatures around 100 degrees resulted in widespread high heat indices.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in between 105 and 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cameron County Airport Automated Surface Observing Sensor near Bayview recorded around 4.5 hours of heat index values between 111 and 115F between 1153 AM CDT and 430 PM CDT. Peak values of 115 occurred between 253 and 353 PM.  By proxy, it can be interpolated that Coastal Willacy also observed similar heat index values during the same time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest before building back east during the last few days of the month. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across Southwest Arkansas.

Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered over the Ark-La-Tex before retreating northward, which allowed for dew points to surge back into the mid and upper 70s for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s through the last weekend in June, with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from June 28th through June 30th across Southwest Arkansas.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, before retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered just north of the Ark-La-Tex across the Ozarks and Mid-South region, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across Southeast Oklahoma.

An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, before retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered just north of the Ark-La-Tex across the Ozarks and Mid-South region, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across Southwest Arkansas.

A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mesonet site at Sarita in northern Kenedy County observed heat index values between  111 and 114 from 1230 until 530 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Texas Mesonet site at Sarita recorded nearly four hours with heat index values betwee 111 and 115, with a single peak at 116 at 420 PM CDT.  By proxy with the Texas Agriscience Center Mesonet along the western Willacy County line, which had less than an hour of excessive heat values (116) and the west-central Kleberg County site (west of Kingsville) havine about the same amount of time at 116-117, it is inferred that heat is the most appropriate category for this date.

At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rancho Los Comitos (AWOS) recorded max heat indices between 111-114F for 5 hours, from 2:00-7:00 PM CDT on May 27, 2024. La Puerta Remote Automated Weather Station recorded max heat indices between 112-123F for 7 hours, from 12:11-7:11 PM CDT on May 27, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-123F for 5 hours, from 1:11-6:11 PM CDT.  However, the site tends to have a high bias in temperature and dewpoint, and the likely heat index values were up to 2 or 3 degrees less.  By proxy with Rancho Los Comitas, the likely average peak heat index was likely closer to 116 to 118 and occurred from 230 until 5 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong high pressure ridge aloft produced temperatures above 100 degrees along with heat index values at or above 105 degrees for the last week of June. Heat Advisories were needed for many days with a few Excessive Heat Warnings needed June 27-29th (see separate Episode for Excessive Heat information).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above average temperatures stretched from June 24th through the end of the month and into July. Several prolonged Heat Advisories were in effect, and at times Excessive Heat Warnings were needed, as temperatures soared over 100 degrees and/or heat index values recorded over 105 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: McAllen International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 111-118F for 7 hours, from 10:53 AM-5:53 PM CDT on May 28, 2024.  Excessive heat criteria (116F or higher) were reached from 12:30 PM until approximately 4:45 PM).  The South Texas International Airport, 11 miles north of Edinburg and along the north/south Hidalgo County line, recorded 111F of higher heat index values from 1145 AM until 630 PM, with 116F or higher from 2:25 until 5:45 PM.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: South Texas International Airport (11 miles north of Edinburg) recorded max heat indices of 112F for 4 hours, from 11:15 AM -5:55 PM CDT on May 25, 2024.The Remote Automated Weather Station at Linn-San Manuel recorded max heat indices between 112-117F degrees for 7 hours, between 10:46 AM-5:46 PM CDT on May 25, 2024. However, this location is notoriously high, so it is more likely that proxy heat index values were closer to 111 to 114 and the duration was similar to that of the South Texas International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mostly clear skies and plenty of moisture surging in from the south allowed for heat indices to reach 105 to 115 degrees across much of Southwest Kentucky. The highest observed heat index in Southwest Kentucky was 115 degrees at the Sturgis Municipal Airport AWOS site. Thunderstorms and a surging outflow boundary advancing southward during the mid-afternoon through the early evening brought an end to heat concerns for the day.

Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered just north of the Ark-La-Tex across the Ozarks and Mid-South region, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across Southwest Arkansas.

A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rancho Los Comitos in northern Starr County (Texas Mesonet) recorded max heat indices between 111-115F for 4 hours, from 3:00-7:00 PM CDT on May 24, 2024. La Puerta - 5.65 miles east of Rio Grande City (Remote Automated Weather Station) recorded heat indices between 112-123F for 7 hours, from 12:11-7:11 PM CDT on May 24, 2024. Though Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning with values between 120-123F for 4 hours, from 2:11-6:11 PM CDT, these values are notoriously high and therefore not considered representative of the county as a whole. Therefore, an hour has been added to the start and end time based on the Mesonet site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The South Texas International Airport, 11 miles north of Edinburg and along the north/south Hidalgo County line, recorded 111F of higher heat index values from 1145 AM until 630 PM, with 116F or higher from 2:25 until 5:45 PM. Linn-San Manuel Remote Automated Weather Station (RAWS) recorded max heat indices between 116-122F degrees for 5 hours, from 12:46-5:46 PM CDT. These values were considered excessive heat criteria the entire duration.  However, the RAWS data have a high bias with temperature and dewpoint compared with surrounding (proxy) observations, so the likely heat index values were lower by a couple degrees.  Therefore, the timing from the better calibrated airport site is used here.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: McAllen International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 111 and just below 116F for 5.5 hours from around 1230 through 6 PM CDT on May 23, 2024. Weslaco, farther east, held below 110 through the afternoon, but South Texas International Airport 11 miles north of Edinburg and along the south/north Hidalgo line reached 112F between 215 and 415 PM CDT (with a few breaks).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: McAllen International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 111-118F for 6 hours, from 11:30 AM-615 PM CDT on May 25, 2024. Peak value reached just below 118 at 353 PM, with values likely at 116 or higher from 330 and 430 PM.  South Texas International Airport (11 miles north of Edinburg) recorded max heat indices of 112F for 4 hours, from 11:15 AM -5:55 PM CDT on May 25, 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong high pressure aloft resulted in an early season heat episode across parts of Central Texas. Heat index values of 105 or greater occurred in the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached or exceeded 105 the afternoon of June 4 across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late June. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid to upper 90s, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 117 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 28th through the 30th. At least ten people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, five of which were transported to the hospital. This heat wave persisted into early July.

Mostly clear skies and plenty of moisture surging in from the south allowed for heat indices to reach 105 to 115 degrees across much of Southwest Kentucky. The highest observed heat index in Southwest Kentucky was 115 degrees at the Sturgis Municipal Airport AWOS site. Thunderstorms and a surging outflow boundary advancing southward during the mid-afternoon through the early evening brought an end to heat concerns for the day.

An upper-level ridge prevailed across the region in late June. A cold front had stalled just to the north of the area and moisture continued to surge into the Mid-South allowing dewpoints to rise into the upper 70s and lower 80s resulting in triple-digit heat indices.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture surged into the region while a strong upper ridge prevailed over the ArkLaTex region. Surface dewpoints climbed into the low to middle 70s while high temperatures rose into the lower to middle 90s resulting in high heat indices. The aforementioned upper ridge continued to intensify resulting in a couple of days of dangerous heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging prevailed from the southwest U.S. eastward across the southern states. Moisture pooled along a stalled frontal boundary across the Mid-South with dewpoints rising into the upper 70s. The abundance of moisture combined with temperatures around 100 degrees resulted in widespread high heat indices.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in between 105 and 110 degrees.

An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: McAllen International Airport (KMFE) recorded heat indices between 117 and at least 122F for 7 hours, from 12:53-7:53 PM CDT on May 9, 2024. Peak value of 122F (hourly) was reached at 453 CDT. Between the hours of 11:53 AM to 8:35 PM CDT (9 hours), heat indices were at least 111F. Weslaco Mid Valley Airport (AWOS) recorded heat indices between 116-122F for 3 hours, from 3:55-6:55 PM CDT on May 9, 2024. Between the hours of 12:55 PM to 7:35 PM CDT (6.5 hours), heat indices were at least 111F.  Peak value of 122 occurred at 635 PM CDT. Other observing locations (Mesonet, Remote Automated Weather Station) recorded similar values. ||As of this writing, there were no known direct fatalities from the heat, but there was an unknown increase in hospitalizations compared with other times in early May.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: June 22, 2024 was the sixth and final day in the stretch of hot, humid conditions. Heat index (or feels like temperatures) reached between 95 and 104 degrees across Litchfield County.||A low pressure system and potent upper shortwave tracked east from the Great Lakes region, lifting a warm front through Litchfield County on the morning of June 23. With a cold front to the west, northwest Connecticut fell into the warm sector of the system with warm, moist antecedent conditions contributing to sufficient instability. Higher values of low- and deep-layer shear and steep lapse rates paired with ample forcing from a low level jet gave way to scattered showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon of June 23. Some storms became severe, leading to a few reports of tree and wire damage in Litchfield County.

A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 110-120F for 5 hours, from 11:52 AM-4:52 PM CDT on May 28, 2024.  Values reached excessive heat criteria (116F or higher) from approximately 1230 until 345 PM. By proxy, it can be inferred that southern Willacy County had excessive heat values for a similar time period.  Note that the Texas Mesonet site at AgriScience Center recorded 111F or higher heat index from 1255 until 540 PM, with a shorter window (345 until 410 PM) with peak heat index between 116 and 117.6F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Partial clearing of skies, along with moisture advection in southerly flow, resulted in heat advisory criteria being reached in much of the Quad State, including the far southwestern corner of Indiana, during the afternoon.

Partial clearing of skies, along with moisture advection in southerly flow, resulted in heat indices reaching 105 to 115 degrees across far Southern Illinois and along the Wabash River during the afternoon. The highest heat index in Southern Illinois was 115 degrees at the Cairo Regional Airport AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging prevailed from the southwest U.S. eastward across the southern states. Moisture pooled along a stalled frontal boundary across the Mid-South with dewpoints rising into the upper 70s. The abundance of moisture combined with temperatures around 100 degrees resulted in widespread high heat indices.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in between 105 and 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ranchos Los Comitos (Texas Mesonet) recorded peak heat indices between 111-115F for 3 hours, from 1:55-4:55 PM CDT. La Puerta (Remote Automated Weather Station) recorded peak heat indices between 111-118F for 6 hours, from 12:11-6:11 PM CDT.  Note that the La Puerta site, 5.65 miles east of Rio Grande City, tends to run a bit high on temperature and humidity.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure expanded across the Southern Plains during the last week of June, before retrograding slightly over the Desert Southwest. Meanwhile, a weak frontal boundary lingered just north of the Ark-La-Tex across the Ozarks and Mid-South region, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling for several days. Temperatures climbed into the middle and upper 90s throughout the week with the moisture pooling resulting in very limited mixing of dew points as attendant heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees each afternoon from June 23rd through June 26th across North Louisiana.

A slightly stronger sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico returned northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into another short-lived but intense heat wave over the region with surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 26-30. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, heat indices ranged between a sweltering 111F-126F  across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C; several hours with values of 116 or higher - considered Excessive Heat - were noted each day in many parts of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System at Brownsville had heat index values between 111 and 153 until 430 PM, with a peak value of 115 at 353 PM. Harlingen/Valley International Airport had a slightly lesser duration, but still reached above 111F (352 until 430 PM).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level subtropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands the week prior to Memorial Day. The strong ridge aided lower level temperatures at around five thousand feet to soar to between 78 and 86F, which translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s on most days between May 21-25. With dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, apparent temperatures (feels like temperatures) ranged anywhere between 111-116F across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley with a few locales reaching higher than this. The hottest apparent temperatures were located along and east of IH-69C from Hidalgo and Brooks County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County - but all of Deep South Texas observed at least dangerous heat levels by local definition (111F or higher for at least two hours) on most days.||Actual temperatures during the period were even hotter than the peak of the summer heat (late July through mid August) for most areas.  The month would shatter all-time temperature records by 1 to more than 3 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Texas Mesonet site at Rancho Las Comitas reached 111 to 114 heat index values from 225 until 330 PM.  La Puerta (Remote Automated Observing Station) recorded max heat indices between 114-119F for 6 hours, from 12:11-6:11 PM CDT on May 25, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 117-119F for 4 hours, from 1:11-5:11 PM CDT.  However, the location, 5.65 miles east of Rio Grande City, has a known high bias.  Proxy values from Rancho Las Comitas were used, with an hour of duration added on each side of the period for a better estimate.

The highest heat index in Southern Illinois was 115 degrees at the Cairo Regional Airport AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second heatwave that occurred was the hottest of the two heatwaves that occurred in July of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Alberton COOP reported temperatures ranging from 98 to 102 for eight days straight. Other locations including St. Regis, and Trout Creek reported multiple days of temperatures in the low 100's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second heatwave that occurred was the hottest of the two heatwaves that occurred in July of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Missoula International Airport reported five straight days of low 100s. The Stevensville COOP reported two days of 100 degrees. Low temperatures were in the upper 50s to mid 60s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second heatwave that occurred was the hottest of the two heatwaves that occurred in July of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Private weather stations in both the Fish Creek and Rock Creek areas reported temperatures from the upper 90s as high as 101 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged and extended heat wave impacted the state of California from the early to the middle of July. An upper level ridge set up over the region, leading to a historically long period of dangerous heat. The event resulted in the issuing of an Excessive Heat Warning for interior regions of the Bay Area and Central Coast, which extended From July 2 to the 10th and became the longest recorded Excessive Heat Warning issued by the NWS Bay Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 51-year old man drowned in the Russian River on Saturday July 6. A group of paddleboarders noticed a commotion near the Bohemian Highway Bridge around 6:40 PM and noticed the man in distress. They attempted CPR until fire officials arrived and attempted life saving measures for 25 minutes until he was pronounced dead.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged and extended heat wave impacted the state of California from the early to the middle of July. An upper level ridge set up over the region, leading to a historically long period of dangerous heat. The event resulted in the issuing of an Excessive Heat Warning for interior regions of the Bay Area and Central Coast, which extended From July 2 to the 10th and became the longest recorded Excessive Heat Warning issued by the NWS Bay Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 28-year old man drowned in the Russian River near the Patterson Point Preserve on Wednesday July 3, while seeking relief from the heat. Observers reported that the man was sucked down by a whirlpool around 6 PM and never came back on shore; his body was found near Monte Rio on Friday after a search.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Jose police responded to a call around 8 PM to a homeless man who was found dead. The day saw San Jose tie an all-time daily record with a high of 102.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE

The event resulted in the issuing of an Excessive Heat Warning for interior regions of the Bay Area and Central Coast, which extended From July 2 to the 10th and became the longest recorded Excessive Heat Warning issued by the NWS Bay Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Through the month of July, 28 deaths across Santa Clara County were being investigated for heat-related impacts. 19 of those were reported from July 1 to July 11; the remaining 9 died on unknown days. Ages ranged from 32 to 84. Of the 19 people who died from the 1st to the 11th, four were homeless, one was in a transitional housing program, and nine were over 65.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during mid July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 15th and 16th.

Hot temperatures typically 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona July 8-12. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert, eight in the Tucson area, two in the Safford area and another in Rio Rico. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of twelve individuals in the Tucson area and another near Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 8 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson Metro Area July 8 through July 12, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. Tucson International Airport topped out each day between 109 and 112 degrees. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of eight individuals and a contributing factor in the deaths of twelve individuals.

CZ_NAME: UPPER GILA RIVER AND ARAVAIPA VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona July 8-12. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert, eight in the Tucson area, two in the Safford area and another in Rio Rico. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of twelve individuals in the Tucson area and another near Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 4 to 8 degrees above normal were experienced in the Upper Gila River Valley on July 10 through July 12, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The County Medical Examiner Office reported two deaths, both with the primary cause as heat in Safford and Pima during this time period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 7 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in the Upper San Pedro River Valley on July 10 causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across portions of southeast Arizona July 3 through July 4. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation on July 3 and July 4. Additionally, heat was a contributing factor of death for an individual in Tucson on July 3.

A large upper-level ridge of high pressure centered over the Midwest brought very hot weather to central Illinois on August 26th and 27th.  High temperatures were mostly in the lower to middle 90s on August 26th, but climbed into the 95-100 degree range on the 27th.  With dewpoints hovering in the upper 70s to near 80 degrees, heat index readings peaked from 105 to 115 degrees along and north of the I-72 corridor during the afternoon of August 27th.  While no heat-related deaths were reported, this was the hottest period of weather across central Illinois during the entire summer of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index readings peaked at 110-115 degrees during the afternoon of August 27th.  No heat-related deaths were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second heatwave that occurred was the hottest of the two heatwaves that occurred in July of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On the 21st Kalispell reached 100 degrees, SKQ Dam saw 96 degrees and Hot Springs reached 100 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during mid July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 15th and 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached 112 degrees F at Easton Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong subtropical atmospheric ridge, or heat dome, remained anchored over the region, creating up to six days of dangerous heat conditions at the start of June. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into a continuation of what was a short-lived, but intense heat wave over the region with actual temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from June 1-6. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, and heat index values ranged between a sweltering 111F-1xxF across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C.  The hottest feeling day was June 5th, from Brooks/Hidalgo County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Edinburg International Airport recorded max heat indices between 111-117F for 7 hours, from 10:55 AM-5:55 PM CDT on June 5, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-117F over 4 hours, from 12:55-5:15 PM CDT.

CZ_NAME: UPPER GILA RIVER AND ARAVAIPA VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Upper Gila River Valley near Safford experienced major Heat Risk on June 16 with high temperatures of 106 degrees. These temperatures were about 4 to 6 degrees above normal. The Tucson Metro experienced moderate Heat Risk on June 16 and 17 with a high of 107 degrees and 105 degrees, respectively. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals and a contributing factor for another during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Safford area experienced major Heat Risk on June 16 with high temperatures of 106 degrees. These temperatures were about 4 to 6 degrees above normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 11 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was a contributing factor in the death of one individual in Tucson on June 7 and another on June 8.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 7 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in southeast Pinal County on June 6 and  June 7, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. Temperatures reached as high as 109 in the Mammoth area.

CZ_NAME: UPPER GILA RIVER AND ARAVAIPA VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 11 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was a contributing factor in the death of one individual in Tucson on June 7 and another on June 8.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 8 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in the Upper Gila River Valley on June 6 and June 7, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. Safford Airport recorded highs of 110 degrees and 108 degrees for June 6 and June 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 3 to 6 degrees above normal were experienced across much of southeast Arizona June 10-13. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals, one in Cochise County and another in Tucson. Additionally, the Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the cause of death for another individual.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 8 to 12 degrees above normal were experienced in western Pima County, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. Ajo topped out at as high as 113 degrees on June 13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 3 to 8 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona June 22-27. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for eight individuals found in the desert, one in Tucson and another in the Saddlebrooke area. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of two individuals, one in Tucson and the other in Cochise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 6 to 9 degrees above normal were experienced in western Pima County on June 23, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. Ajo had a high of 110 degrees on June 23. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of one individual found in the desert near Ajo.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Remote Automated Weather Station (RAWS) site at La Puerta, 5.65 miles east of Rio Grande City, reported an estimated 2.5 hours of heat index of 111 to 112F.  Rancho Las Comitas, along the Starr/Jim Hogg County line, fell just shy of 111 (107 to 110) during the same window.  Note that values shown here are lower than those observed by 3 degrees, based on a known high bias compared with proxy observations in the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: McAllen International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 111-114F for 3 hours, from 12:53 AM-4:55 PM CDT on June 1, 2024.  The Remote Automated Weather Station (RAWS) at Santa Ana NWR east of Pharr recorded a peak heat index of 113.6F at 145 PM CDT, with 112F+ continuing through 445 CDT.  Given the site's slight high bias, it can be assumed that peak values were closer to 111F for this period. The Automated Weather Observing Station (AWOS) at Mid-Valley Airport in Weslaco fell just shy of 111F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure building in from the east brought late-season heat to the Mojave Desert, breaking daily temperature records and also cumulative heat records for the year. The episode continued into October.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on each of the last four days of September. The event continued into October.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the death of one individual on June 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 11 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was a contributing factor in the death of one individual in Tucson on June 7 and another on June 8.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 8 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced on June 6, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. Nogales and Sasabe topped both topped out at 104 degrees on June 6.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong subtropical atmospheric ridge, or heat dome, remained anchored over the region, creating up to six days of dangerous heat conditions at the start of June. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into a continuation of what was a short-lived, but intense heat wave over the region with actual temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from June 1-6. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, and heat index values ranged between a sweltering 111F-1xxF across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falfurrias Brooks County Airport recorded max heat indices between 111-124F for 5 hours, from 10:55 AM-3:55 PM CDT on June 5, 2024. Excessive Heat Warning criteria was met for 4 hours from 12:35-3:55 PM with estimated values between 116-119F based on a known high bias at the station. Edinburg International Airport recorded max heat indices between 111-117F for 7 hours, from 10:55 AM-5:55 PM CDT on June 5, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-117F over 4 hours, from 12:55-5:15 PM CDT. Kleberg County Airport (KIKG) in Kingsville recorded peak heat indices between 111-117F for 3 hours (from 12:55-2:55 PM). By proxy, it's conceivable that sites across Brooks County recorded peak heat indices estimated between 116 and 119F for at least 3 hours between the time of 12:35 AM-4:35 PM.  For purposes of this event, only the Excessive Heat period is used.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwave troughs traversing the northern CONUS brought unsettled weather to the area for the end of June. On the 21st, a stationary front was draped across northeast Nebraska into Iowa. Ahead of one of the aforementioned shortwave troughs, several rounds of strong thunderstorms developed near this frontal zone and moved across northeast Nebraska. At 8 pm on the 21st, radar imagery showed training thunderstorms had set up across central Nebraska. These storms moved into east-central Nebraska dropping 2 to 6 inches of rain across the Platte River Basin. As a result, minor flooding was observed along the Platte River in Dodge, Saunders, Douglas and Sarpy Counties. Further north in Knox County, additional rounds of thunderstorms brought flooding to the Ponca Creek, prompting emergency management to deploy sand bags. Flooding in these locations continued for several days before subsiding the 23rd.||Behind this first shortwave, a shortwave ridge moved out into the central Plains accompanied by a surface high pressure system. Afternoon high temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the mid and upper 70s brought excessive heat to much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa the afternoons of the 24th and the 25th. Excessive heat was most widespread on the 24th, with heat indices across the entire WFO ranging from 107 to 120 degrees. Afternoon thunderstorms on the 25th mitigated excessive heat, though heat indices did hit 110 in far southwest Iowa.||On the 25th, another shortwave trough brought more unsettled weather to the region. A surface front was draped across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa when the first convection initiated over downtown Omaha. This storm quickly became intense, producing multiple instances of 3 to 4 inch hail in the Omaha metro. As this storm weakened over eastern Sarpy County, additional strong to severe thunderstorms developed across northeast Nebraska. While the most widespread hazard was large hail up to the size of golf balls, two tornadoes were confirmed in Madison County. Later that evening, a bow echo developed and moved through the northern Omaha Metro, bringing wind gusts up to 90 miles per hour at Eppley Airfield and into northern Pottawattamie County. An additional line of storms developed after dark that night across southeast Nebraska and produced scattered damaging wind gusts, the highest of which was an 83 mph wind gust measured by emergency management in Jefferson County.||The unsettled weather at the end of June brought widespread excessive rain to much of southeast South Dakota and Northwest Iowa. Rainfall estimated from these storms showed a swath of 4 to 8 inches of rain that fell between Sioux Falls and Sioux City. The result of this rain and additional rain across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa was river flooding along the Missouri and Little Sioux the last week of June and into July. Flooding during this time frame resulted in numerous road closures, including I-29 between Council Bluffs and Missouri Valley. This stretch of the interstate was closed beginning midnight the night of the 25th, and remained closed through the end of the month. Levee breaches in Monona County on the 25th prompted several evacuations, as resultant flash flooding inundated multiple county roads and homesteads. No injuries or fatalities were reported from this. While flooding subsided in and north of the Omaha metro by the end of the month, river flooding along the Missouri persisted into the first week of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A max heat index of 112 degrees was observed at the Clarinda AWOS.

The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C.  The hottest feeling day was June 5th, from Brooks/Hidalgo County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged and extended heat wave impacted the state of California from the early to the middle of July. An upper level ridge set up over the region, leading to a historically long period of dangerous heat. The event resulted in the issuing of an Excessive Heat Warning for interior regions of the Bay Area and Central Coast, which extended from July 2 to the 10th and became the longest recorded Excessive Heat Warning issued by the NWS Bay Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight heat-related deaths were recorded in Santa Clara County from July 7 to 12.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 6 to 9 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson Metro Area June 11 and June 12, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Texas Mesonet station at Sarita recorded heat index values between 111 and 118F between 1210 and 7 PM CDT, with excessive heat only lasting a total of an hour (250 to 330 and again at 505 PM). Kleberg County Airport (KIKG) in Kingsville recorded peak heat indices between 111-117F for 6 hours (from 12:55-6:55 PM). Excessive Heat Warning criteria was met for 2 hours from 2:55-4:55 PM with values between 116-117F.  Averaging these sites, and by proxy with locations south and southwest, the event is considered a Heat level (111 to 115 for 2 hours or more).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Texas Mesonet site at Sarita recorded heat index values between 116 and 121F between 210 PM and 320 PM CST.  Kleberg County Airport (KIKG) in Kingsville recorded peak heat indices between 111-117F for 3 hours (from 12:55-2:55 PM) but reached 116F or higher from 130 PM CDT until 330 PM CDT. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 3 to 8 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona June 22-27. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for eight individuals found in the desert, one in Tucson and another in the Saddlebrooke area. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of two individuals, one in Tucson and the other in Cochise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 6 to 9 degrees above normal were experienced in western Pima County and the Tohono O'odham Nation June 26-27, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. Ajo topped out at 108 and 109 degrees on June 26 and 27 with a low temperature of 85 degrees. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of three individuals found in the desert near Ajo. Two of those were on June 26 and the other on June 27.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 3 to 8 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona June 22-27. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for eight individuals found in the desert, one in Tucson and another in the Saddlebrooke area. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of two individuals, one in Tucson and the other in Cochise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced in southeast Pinal County on June 26, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of one individual located in their vehicle outside their residence in Saddlebrooke.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwave troughs traversing the northern CONUS brought unsettled weather to the area for the end of June. On the 21st, a stationary front was draped across northeast Nebraska into Iowa. Ahead of one of the aforementioned shortwave troughs, several rounds of strong thunderstorms developed near this frontal zone and moved across northeast Nebraska. At 8 pm on the 21st, radar imagery showed training thunderstorms had set up across central Nebraska. These storms moved into east-central Nebraska dropping 2 to 6 inches of rain across the Platte River Basin. As a result, minor flooding was observed along the Platte River in Dodge, Saunders, Douglas and Sarpy Counties. Further north in Knox County, additional rounds of thunderstorms brought flooding to the Ponca Creek, prompting emergency management to deploy sand bags. Flooding in these locations continued for several days before subsiding the 23rd.||Behind this first shortwave, a shortwave ridge moved out into the central Plains accompanied by a surface high pressure system. Afternoon high temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the mid and upper 70s brought excessive heat to much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa the afternoons of the 24th and the 25th. Excessive heat was most widespread on the 24th, with heat indices across the entire WFO ranging from 107 to 120 degrees. Afternoon thunderstorms on the 25th mitigated excessive heat, though heat indices did hit 110 in far southwest Iowa.||On the 25th, another shortwave trough brought more unsettled weather to the region. A surface front was draped across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa when the first convection initiated over downtown Omaha. This storm quickly became intense, producing multiple instances of 3 to 4 inch hail in the Omaha metro. As this storm weakened over eastern Sarpy County, additional strong to severe thunderstorms developed across northeast Nebraska. While the most widespread hazard was large hail up to the size of golf balls, two tornadoes were confirmed in Madison County. Later that evening, a bow echo developed and moved through the northern Omaha Metro, bringing wind gusts up to 90 miles per hour at Eppley Airfield and into northern Pottawattamie County. An additional line of storms developed after dark that night across southeast Nebraska and produced scattered damaging wind gusts, the highest of which was an 83 mph wind gust measured by emergency management in Jefferson County.||The unsettled weather at the end of June brought widespread excessive rain to much of southeast South Dakota and Northwest Iowa. Rainfall estimated from these storms showed a swath of 4 to 8 inches of rain that fell between Sioux Falls and Sioux City. The result of this rain and additional rain across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa was river flooding along the Missouri and Little Sioux the last week of June and into July. Flooding during this time frame resulted in numerous road closures, including I-29 between Council Bluffs and Missouri Valley. This stretch of the interstate was closed beginning midnight the night of the 25th, and remained closed through the end of the month. Levee breaches in Monona County on the 25th prompted several evacuations, as resultant flash flooding inundated multiple county roads and homesteads. No injuries or fatalities were reported from this. While flooding subsided in and north of the Omaha metro by the end of the month, river flooding along the Missouri persisted into the first week of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A max heat index of 118 was observed at the Council Bluffs AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwave troughs traversing the northern CONUS brought unsettled weather to the area for the end of June. On the 21st, a stationary front was draped across northeast Nebraska into Iowa. Ahead of one of the aforementioned shortwave troughs, several rounds of strong thunderstorms developed near this frontal zone and moved across northeast Nebraska. At 8 pm on the 21st, radar imagery showed training thunderstorms had set up across central Nebraska. These storms moved into east-central Nebraska dropping 2 to 6 inches of rain across the Platte River Basin. As a result, minor flooding was observed along the Platte River in Dodge, Saunders, Douglas and Sarpy Counties. Further north in Knox County, additional rounds of thunderstorms brought flooding to the Ponca Creek, prompting emergency management to deploy sand bags. Flooding in these locations continued for several days before subsiding the 23rd.||Behind this first shortwave, a shortwave ridge moved out into the central Plains accompanied by a surface high pressure system. Afternoon high temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the mid and upper 70s brought excessive heat to much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa the afternoons of the 24th and the 25th. Excessive heat was most widespread on the 24th, with heat indices across the entire WFO ranging from 107 to 120 degrees. Afternoon thunderstorms on the 25th mitigated excessive heat, though heat indices did hit 110 in far southwest Iowa. The Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services reported 80 heat related hospitalizations across the state during this period of excessive heat. While many of the 19 counties reporting these cases masked the exact number of hospitalizations in order to protect personal health information, it was released that there were 37 heat related hospitalizations in Douglas County, 13 in Lancaster County, and 7 in Sarpy County. The vast majority of these heat related illnesses (66.25%) occurred at work or while participating in outdoor recreation. 12.5% were among the homeless population, and 8.75% of heat related hospitalizations were due to a lack of air conditioning. Furthermore, the age group most impacted by heat related illness for this event were between the ages of 20 and 29, accounting for 30% of heat related hospitalizations in the state.||On the 25th, another shortwave trough brought more unsettled weather to the region. A surface front was draped across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa when the first convection initiated over downtown Omaha. This storm quickly became intense producing multiple instances of 3 to 4 inch hail in the Omaha metro. As this storm weakened over eastern Sarpy County, additional strong to severe thunderstorms developed across northeast Nebraska. While the most widespread hazard was large hail up to the size of golf balls, two tornadoes were confirmed in Madison County. Later that evening, a bow echo developed and moved through the northern Omaha Metro, bringing wind gusts up to 90 miles per hour at Eppley Airfield and into northern Pottawattamie County. An additional line of storms developed after dark that night across southeast Nebraska and produced scattered damaging wind gusts, the highest of which was an 83 mph wind gust measured by emergency management in Jefferson County.||The unsettled weather at the end of June brought widespread excessive rain to much of southeast South Dakota and Northwest Iowa. Rainfall estimated from these storms showed a swath of 4 to 8 inches of rain that fell between Sioux Falls and Sioux City. The result of this rain and additional rain across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa was river flooding along the Missouri and Little Sioux the last week of June and into July. Flooding during this time frame resulted in numerous road closures, including I-29 between Council Bluffs and Missouri Valley. This stretch of the interstate was closed beginning midnight the night of the 25th, and remained closed through the end of the month. Levee breaches in Monona County on the 25th prompted several evacuations, as resultant flash flooding inundated multiple county roads and homesteads. No injuries or fatalities were reported from this. While flooding subsided in and north of the Omaha metro by the end of the month, river flooding along the Missouri persisted into the first week of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A max heat index of 111 was observed at the Albion AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong subtropical atmospheric ridge, or heat dome, remained anchored over the region, creating up to six days of dangerous heat conditions at the start of June. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into a continuation of what was a short-lived, but intense heat wave over the region with actual temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from June 1-6. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, and heat index values ranged between a sweltering 111F-1xxF across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C.  The hottest feeling day was June 5th, from Brooks/Hidalgo County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Edinburg International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 111-112F for 2 hours, from 1:55-3:55 PM CDT on June 3, 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southeasterly winds steering warmer tropical air into the islands, and sufficient moisture lead to heat index values exceeding Heat Advisory criteria across most coastal and lower elevation areas. Heat index values exceeded Excessive Heat Warning criteria on up to several days of the second half of May across San Juan and Vicinity, North Central Puerto Rico and Northwestern PR. Several stations across those areas reported heat indices surpassing 112 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several weather stations reported heat indices above 112 degrees for up to over two hours. These conditions were observed widespread along the coastal areas and the valleys.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heat wave developed starting Labor Day weekend and peaked the next weekend September 5 to 9, 2024. The hottest days included Ramona reaching 114, Santa Ana 113,  and Anaheim an all-time record of 112.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme heat started September 3 and continued through September 10, 2024. The hottest days were September 5 to 8, when high temperatures reached 105 to 114F across the entire Inland Empire. Despite scattered thunderstorms on September 7 and 8th, the high temperatures were still around 110F at many locations in the Inland Empire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 3 to 6 degrees above normal were experienced across much of southeast Arizona June 10-13. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwave troughs traversing the northern CONUS brought unsettled weather to the area for the end of June. On the 21st, a stationary front was draped across northeast Nebraska into Iowa. Ahead of one of the aforementioned shortwave troughs, several rounds of strong thunderstorms developed near this frontal zone and moved across northeast Nebraska. At 8 pm on the 21st, radar imagery showed training thunderstorms had set up across central Nebraska. These storms moved into east-central Nebraska dropping 2 to 6 inches of rain across the Platte River Basin. As a result, minor flooding was observed along the Platte River in Dodge, Saunders, Douglas and Sarpy Counties. Further north in Knox County, additional rounds of thunderstorms brought flooding to the Ponca Creek, prompting emergency management to deploy sand bags. Flooding in these locations continued for several days before subsiding the 23rd.||Behind this first shortwave, a shortwave ridge moved out into the central Plains accompanied by a surface high pressure system. Afternoon high temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the mid and upper 70s brought excessive heat to much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa the afternoons of the 24th and the 25th. Excessive heat was most widespread on the 24th, with heat indices across the entire WFO ranging from 107 to 120 degrees. Afternoon thunderstorms on the 25th mitigated excessive heat, though heat indices did hit 110 in far southwest Iowa. The Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services reported 80 heat related hospitalizations across the state during this period of excessive heat. While many of the 19 counties reporting these cases masked the exact number of hospitalizations in order to protect personal health information, it was released that there were 37 heat related hospitalizations in Douglas County, 13 in Lancaster County, and 7 in Sarpy County. The vast majority of these heat related illnesses (66.25%) occurred at work or while participating in outdoor recreation. 12.5% were among the homeless population, and 8.75% of heat related hospitalizations were due to a lack of air conditioning. Furthermore, the age group most impacted by heat related illness for this event were between the ages of 20 and 29, accounting for 30% of heat related hospitalizations in the state.||On the 25th, another shortwave trough brought more unsettled weather to the region. A surface front was draped across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa when the first convection initiated over downtown Omaha. This storm quickly became intense producing multiple instances of 3 to 4 inch hail in the Omaha metro. As this storm weakened over eastern Sarpy County, additional strong to severe thunderstorms developed across northeast Nebraska. While the most widespread hazard was large hail up to the size of golf balls, two tornadoes were confirmed in Madison County. Later that evening, a bow echo developed and moved through the northern Omaha Metro, bringing wind gusts up to 90 miles per hour at Eppley Airfield and into northern Pottawattamie County. An additional line of storms developed after dark that night across southeast Nebraska and produced scattered damaging wind gusts, the highest of which was an 83 mph wind gust measured by emergency management in Jefferson County.||The unsettled weather at the end of June brought widespread excessive rain to much of southeast South Dakota and Northwest Iowa. Rainfall estimated from these storms showed a swath of 4 to 8 inches of rain that fell between Sioux Falls and Sioux City. The result of this rain and additional rain across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa was river flooding along the Missouri and Little Sioux the last week of June and into July. Flooding during this time frame resulted in numerous road closures, including I-29 between Council Bluffs and Missouri Valley. This stretch of the interstate was closed beginning midnight the night of the 25th, and remained closed through the end of the month. Levee breaches in Monona County on the 25th prompted several evacuations, as resultant flash flooding inundated multiple county roads and homesteads. No injuries or fatalities were reported from this. While flooding subsided in and north of the Omaha metro by the end of the month, river flooding along the Missouri persisted into the first week of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A max heat index of 110 was observed at the Millard AWOS. A peak heat index of 113 was also observed at the Eppley Airfield ASOS. 37 heat related hospitalizations were reported in Douglas County by the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation on June 28 and another near Ajo on June 29. Additionally, heat was a contributing factor of death for an individual near Redington Pass on June 27 and another in Tucson on June 28.

Sells topped out at 103 degrees. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of one individual found in the desert near Vamori.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge over the western states with a thermal trough extending from northern California to near the southern Oregon coast brought a few days of hot temperatures, with extreme heat during the hottest day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to the Eastern Douglas County Foothills during the hottest day of the episode on September 5th. During the excessive heat, low temperatures were generally in the lower 50s to lower 60s, and high temperatures in the mid 90s to 104 degrees. A peak reading of 104 degrees was recorded at the Buckeye RAWS.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE MOUNTAINS NORTH OF HIGHWAY 198
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge pushed into California from the eastern Pacific Ocean on September 3 and shifted inland and strengthened on September 5 and 6. This resulted in a period of much of above normal temperatures over the area with Heat Risk reaching high levels across the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Kern County Deserts. The ridge finally broke down and shifted east of the region on September 10 as a trough pushed into the Pacific Northwest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 102 and 107 degrees each day between September 4 and September 9.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 102 and 107 degrees each day between September 4 and September 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge pushed into California from the eastern Pacific Ocean on September 3 and shifted inland and strengthened on September 5 and 6. This resulted in a period of much of above normal temperatures over the area with Heat Risk reaching high levels across the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Kern County Deserts. The ridge finally broke down and shifted east of the region on September 10 as a trough pushed into the Pacific Northwest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 102 and 107 degrees each day between September 4 and September 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong subtropical atmospheric ridge, or heat dome, remained anchored over the region, creating up to six days of dangerous heat conditions at the start of June. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into a continuation of what was a short-lived, but intense heat wave over the region with actual temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from June 1-6. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, and heat index values ranged between a sweltering 111F-1xxF across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C.  The hottest feeling day was June 5th, from Brooks/Hidalgo County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Edinburg International Airport recorded max heat indices between 111-117F for 7 hours, from 10:55 AM-5:55 PM CDT on June 5, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-117F over 4 hours, from 12:55-5:15 PM CDT. Harlingen/Valley International Airport (about 7 miles from the Willacy/Cameron line) recorded 116 to 118F heat index between 1153 and 353 PM CDT. By proxy, it's conceivable that sites across Willacy County recorded peak heat indices between 111-117F for at least 3 hours between the time of 10:55 AM-5:55 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southeasterly winds steering warmer tropical air into the islands, and sufficient moisture lead to heat index values exceeding Heat Advisory criteria across most coastal and lower elevation areas. Heat index values exceeded Excessive Heat Warning criteria on up to several days of the second half of May across San Juan and Vicinity, North Central Puerto Rico and Northwestern PR. Several stations across those areas reported heat indices surpassing 112 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several weather stations reported heat indices above 112 degrees for up to over two hours. These conditions were observed widespread along the coastal areas and the valleys.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport (KBRO) recorded max heat indices between 111-118F for 7 hours, from 9:53 AM-4:53 PM CDT on June 5, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-118F for 3 hours, from 11:53 AM-2:53 PM CDT. Harlingen Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded max heat indices between 113-118F for 8 hours, from 9:53 AM-5:30 PM CDT on June 5, 2024. Heat indices reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria with values between 116-118F for 4 hours, from 11:53-3:55 PM CDT.  Times used for this event are based on the Excessive Heat condition.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwave troughs traversing the northern CONUS brought unsettled weather to the area for the end of June. On the 21st, a stationary front was draped across northeast Nebraska into Iowa. Ahead of one of the aforementioned shortwave troughs, several rounds of strong thunderstorms developed near this frontal zone and moved across northeast Nebraska. At 8 pm on the 21st, radar imagery showed training thunderstorms had set up across central Nebraska. These storms moved into east-central Nebraska dropping 2 to 6 inches of rain across the Platte River Basin. As a result, minor flooding was observed along the Platte River in Dodge, Saunders, Douglas and Sarpy Counties. Further north in Knox County, additional rounds of thunderstorms brought flooding to the Ponca Creek, prompting emergency management to deploy sand bags. Flooding in these locations continued for several days before subsiding the 23rd.||Behind this first shortwave, a shortwave ridge moved out into the central Plains accompanied by a surface high pressure system. Afternoon high temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the mid and upper 70s brought excessive heat to much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa the afternoons of the 24th and the 25th. Excessive heat was most widespread on the 24th, with heat indices across the entire WFO ranging from 107 to 120 degrees. Afternoon thunderstorms on the 25th mitigated excessive heat, though heat indices did hit 110 in far southwest Iowa. The Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services reported 80 heat related hospitalizations across the state during this period of excessive heat. While many of the 19 counties reporting these cases masked the exact number of hospitalizations in order to protect personal health information, it was released that there were 37 heat related hospitalizations in Douglas County, 13 in Lancaster County, and 7 in Sarpy County. The vast majority of these heat related illnesses (66.25%) occurred at work or while participating in outdoor recreation. 12.5% were among the homeless population, and 8.75% of heat related hospitalizations were due to a lack of air conditioning. Furthermore, the age group most impacted by heat related illness for this event were between the ages of 20 and 29, accounting for 30% of heat related hospitalizations in the state.||On the 25th, another shortwave trough brought more unsettled weather to the region. A surface front was draped across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa when the first convection initiated over downtown Omaha. This storm quickly became intense producing multiple instances of 3 to 4 inch hail in the Omaha metro. As this storm weakened over eastern Sarpy County, additional strong to severe thunderstorms developed across northeast Nebraska. While the most widespread hazard was large hail up to the size of golf balls, two tornadoes were confirmed in Madison County. Later that evening, a bow echo developed and moved through the northern Omaha Metro, bringing wind gusts up to 90 miles per hour at Eppley Airfield and into northern Pottawattamie County. An additional line of storms developed after dark that night across southeast Nebraska and produced scattered damaging wind gusts, the highest of which was an 83 mph wind gust measured by emergency management in Jefferson County.||The unsettled weather at the end of June brought widespread excessive rain to much of southeast South Dakota and Northwest Iowa. Rainfall estimated from these storms showed a swath of 4 to 8 inches of rain that fell between Sioux Falls and Sioux City. The result of this rain and additional rain across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa was river flooding along the Missouri and Little Sioux the last week of June and into July. Flooding during this time frame resulted in numerous road closures, including I-29 between Council Bluffs and Missouri Valley. This stretch of the interstate was closed beginning midnight the night of the 25th, and remained closed through the end of the month. Levee breaches in Monona County on the 25th prompted several evacuations, as resultant flash flooding inundated multiple county roads and homesteads. No injuries or fatalities were reported from this. While flooding subsided in and north of the Omaha metro by the end of the month, river flooding along the Missouri persisted into the first week of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A max heat index of 111 was observed at the Beatrice AWOS.
