EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure building in from the east brought late-season heat to the Mojave Desert, breaking daily temperature records and also cumulative heat records for the year. The episode continued into October.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on each of the last five days of September. The event continued into October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper-level ridge of high pressure centered over the Midwest brought very hot weather to central Illinois on August 26th and 27th.  High temperatures were mostly in the lower to middle 90s on August 26th, but climbed into the 95-100 degree range on the 27th.  With dewpoints hovering in the upper 70s to near 80 degrees, heat index readings peaked from 105 to 115 degrees along and north of the I-72 corridor during the afternoon of August 27th.  While no heat-related deaths were reported, this was the hottest period of weather across central Illinois during the entire summer of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index readings peaked at 115-120 degrees during the afternoon of August 27th...including 119 degrees at the Galesburg Airport.  No heat-related deaths were reported.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE MOUNTAINS SOUTH OF HIGHWAY 198
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge pushed into California from the eastern Pacific Ocean on September 3 and shifted inland and strengthened on September 5 and 6. This resulted in a period of much of above normal temperatures over the area with Heat Risk reaching high levels across the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Kern County Deserts. The ridge finally broke down and shifted east of the region on September 10 as a trough pushed into the Pacific Northwest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 102 and 107 degrees each day between September 4 and September 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 11 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was a contributing factor in the death of one individual in Tucson on June 7 and another on June 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong subtropical atmospheric ridge, or heat dome, remained anchored over the region, creating up to six days of dangerous heat conditions at the start of June. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into a continuation of what was a short-lived, but intense heat wave over the region with actual temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from June 1-6. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, and heat index values ranged between a sweltering 111F-1xxF across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C.  The hottest feeling day was June 5th, from Brooks/Hidalgo County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falfurrias Brooks County Airport recorded max heat indices between 111-119F for over 8 hours, from 10:55 AM-7:15 PM CDT on June 4, 2024. Excessive Heat Warning criteria was met for over 4 hours from 12:55-5:35 PM with values between 116-119F. Edinburg International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 111-112F for 3 hours, from 1:55-4:55 PM CDT on June 4, 2024. Kleberg County Airport (KIKG) in Kingsville recorded peak heat indices between 111-117F for 6 hours (from 12:55-6:55 PM). Excessive Heat Warning criteria was met for 2 hours from 2:55-4:55 PM with values between 116-117F. By proxy, it's conceivable that sites across Brooks County recorded peak heat indices between 111-117F for at least 3 hours between the time of 1:00-7:00 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwave troughs traversing the northern CONUS brought unsettled weather to the area for the end of June. On the 21st, a stationary front was draped across northeast Nebraska into Iowa. Ahead of one of the aforementioned shortwave troughs, several rounds of strong thunderstorms developed near this frontal zone and moved across northeast Nebraska. At 8 pm on the 21st, radar imagery showed training thunderstorms had set up across central Nebraska. These storms moved into east-central Nebraska dropping 2 to 6 inches of rain across the Platte River Basin. As a result, minor flooding was observed along the Platte River in Dodge, Saunders, Douglas and Sarpy Counties. Further north in Knox County, additional rounds of thunderstorms brought flooding to the Ponca Creek, prompting emergency management to deploy sand bags. Flooding in these locations continued for several days before subsiding the 23rd.||Behind this first shortwave, a shortwave ridge moved out into the central Plains accompanied by a surface high pressure system. Afternoon high temperatures in the 90s and dew points in the mid and upper 70s brought excessive heat to much of eastern Nebraska and western Iowa the afternoons of the 24th and the 25th. Excessive heat was most widespread on the 24th, with heat indices across the entire WFO ranging from 107 to 120 degrees. Afternoon thunderstorms on the 25th mitigated excessive heat, though heat indices did hit 110 in far southwest Iowa. The Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services reported 80 heat related hospitalizations across the state during this period of excessive heat. While many of the 19 counties reporting these cases masked the exact number of hospitalizations in order to protect personal health information, it was released that there were 37 heat related hospitalizations in Douglas County, 13 in Lancaster County, and 7 in Sarpy County. The vast majority of these heat related illnesses (66.25%) occurred at work or while participating in outdoor recreation. 12.5% were among the homeless population, and 8.75% of heat related hospitalizations were due to a lack of air conditioning. Furthermore, the age group most impacted by heat related illness for this event were between the ages of 20 and 29, accounting for 30% of heat related hospitalizations in the state.||On the 25th, another shortwave trough brought more unsettled weather to the region. A surface front was draped across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa when the first convection initiated over downtown Omaha. This storm quickly became intense producing multiple instances of 3 to 4 inch hail in the Omaha metro. As this storm weakened over eastern Sarpy County, additional strong to severe thunderstorms developed across northeast Nebraska. While the most widespread hazard was large hail up to the size of golf balls, two tornadoes were confirmed in Madison County. Later that evening, a bow echo developed and moved through the northern Omaha Metro, bringing wind gusts up to 90 miles per hour at Eppley Airfield and into northern Pottawattamie County. An additional line of storms developed after dark that night across southeast Nebraska and produced scattered damaging wind gusts, the highest of which was an 83 mph wind gust measured by emergency management in Jefferson County.||The unsettled weather at the end of June brought widespread excessive rain to much of southeast South Dakota and Northwest Iowa. Rainfall estimated from these storms showed a swath of 4 to 8 inches of rain that fell between Sioux Falls and Sioux City. The result of this rain and additional rain across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa was river flooding along the Missouri and Little Sioux the last week of June and into July. Flooding during this time frame resulted in numerous road closures, including I-29 between Council Bluffs and Missouri Valley. This stretch of the interstate was closed beginning midnight the night of the 25th, and remained closed through the end of the month. Levee breaches in Monona County on the 25th prompted several evacuations, as resultant flash flooding inundated multiple county roads and homesteads. No injuries or fatalities were reported from this. While flooding subsided in and north of the Omaha metro by the end of the month, river flooding along the Missouri persisted into the first week of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A max heat index of 115 was observed at Offutt Airforce Base. 7 heat related hospitalizations were reported in Sarpy County by Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 3 to 8 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona June 22-27. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for eight individuals found in the desert, one in Tucson and another in the Saddlebrooke area. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of two individuals, one in Tucson and the other in Cochise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 3 to 6 degrees above normal were experienced in eastern Pima County on June 23, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. Tucson had a high of 101 degrees on June 23. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the death of one individual located in a parking lot in Tucson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 3 to 8 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona June 22-27. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for eight individuals found in the desert, one in Tucson and another in the Saddlebrooke area. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of two individuals, one in Tucson and the other in Cochise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona on June 25. The high in Tucson was 103 which is just above normal and in the moderate Heat Risk category. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for an individual near Redington.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 3 degrees above normal were experienced on the Tohono O'odham Nation June 22, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. Sells had a high of 99 degrees on June 22. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of one individual found in the desert near Topawa.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona June 27 through 29. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation on June 28 and another near Ajo on June 29. Additionally, heat was a contributing factor of death for an individual near Redington Pass on June 27 and another in Tucson on June 28.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced in western Pima County on June 29, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. Ajo had a high of 109 degrees on June 29. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of one individual found in the desert near Ajo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona June 27 through 29. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in the desert on the Tohono O'odham Nation on June 28 and another near Ajo on June 29. Additionally, heat was a contributing factor of death for an individual near Redington Pass on June 27 and another in Tucson on June 28.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 5 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson Metro Area June 27 and 28, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. Tucson International Airport topped out at 107 degrees on June 27 and 105 degrees on June 28. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing cause of death in one individual on June 27 and another on June 28.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong subtropical atmospheric ridge, or heat dome, remained anchored over the region, creating up to six days of dangerous heat conditions at the start of June. At five thousand feet above ground, the temperature soared anywhere from 78 to 90 degrees Fahrenheit, which translated into a continuation of what was a short-lived, but intense heat wave over the region with actual temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from June 1-6. The combination of heat and dewpoint temperatures well into the 70s to around 80, and heat index values ranged between a sweltering 111F-1xxF across parts of Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. The hottest temperatures were once again located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C.  The hottest feeling day was June 5th, from Brooks/Hidalgo County to Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kleberg County Airport (KIKG) in Kingsville recorded peak heat indices between 111-113F for 2 hours (from 2:55-4:55 PM). Edinburg International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 111-112F for 2 hours, from 1:55-3:55 PM CDT on June 3, 2024. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southeasterly winds steering warmer tropical air into the islands, and sufficient moisture lead to heat index values exceeding Heat Advisory criteria across most coastal and lower elevation areas. Heat index values exceeded Excessive Heat Warning criteria on up to several days of the second half of May across San Juan and Vicinity, North Central Puerto Rico and Northwestern PR. Several stations across those areas reported heat indices surpassing 112 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several weather stations reported heat indices above 112 degrees for up to over two hours. These conditions were observed widespread along the coastal areas and the valleys.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana on August 1st before exceeding 110 degrees on August 2nd.

An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana on August 1st before exceeding 110 degrees on August 2nd.

An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana on August 1st before exceeding 110 degrees on August 2nd.

An expansive upper-level ridge of high pressure across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region led to a prolonged period of excessive heat through much of mid August across East and Northeast Texas. Afternoon temperatures rose into the upper 90s to lower 100s for several consecutive days totaling a full week from the 13th through the 19th. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices exceeding 110 degrees each day across East and Northeast Texas before the frontal boundary finally advanced southward on August 19th with slightly milder and drier air in its wake.

Some of the hottest weather of the season occurred as a mid and upper ridge dominated North and Central Texas during the middle to latter part of August. All of the forecast area reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the region reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria more than once during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached or exceeded 105 and/or heat index values reached or exceeded 110 across much of the county on August 23 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 6 to 10 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona resulting in major Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death in two individuals and a contributing factor in the death of seven individuals in Tucson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 6 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced on the Tohono O'odham Nation, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure locked in very warm and extremely humid conditions. Dew points in the upper 70s and lower 80s combined with temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s to produce daily heat index values from 100 to 120 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon and early evening heat index values near Maurice reached as high as 108 degrees on August 25 and 111 degrees on August 26.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE MOUNTAINS NORTH OF HIGHWAY 198
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge strengthened over California on October 1 and 2 then remained over the region through October 6. This resulted in several days of record heat over the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra Foothills. October 3 was the hottest day of the heat wave as several long standing all time record highs for the month of October were exceeded. The ridge finally shifted east into the Desert Southwest region on October 7 which reduced the heat impact across the area, but not before 3 additional days with  several records being broken. Temperatures finally cooled down to below record levels by October 10 as a weak shortwave trough moved into California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 101 and 106 degrees each day between October 2 and October 6.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 8 to 16 degrees above normal caused record-breaking heat across Southeast Arizona. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three individuals in Douglas, Bisbee, and Ajo. The Pima County Medical Examiner also found heat contributed to the death of another individual in the Tucson Metro area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 8 to 16 degrees above normal caused record-breaking heat across Southeast Arizona. A Bisbee CWOP station reached a high temperature of 89 degrees Fahrenheit. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for an individual in Bisbee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 10 to 15 degrees above normal caused record-breaking heat across Southeast Arizona. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals in Tucson and Oro Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 10 to 15 degrees above normal caused record-breaking heat across Southeast Arizona. An Oro Valley CWOP station recorded a high temperature of 102 degrees Fahrenheit. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for an individual in Oro Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 10 to 15 degrees above normal caused record-breaking heat across Southeast Arizona. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals in Tucson and Oro Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 6 degrees above normal and Tucson International Airport reached a high temperature of 93 degrees Fahrenheit. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor of death for an individual in Tucson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stagnant conditions south of a stalled frontal boundary across North Dakota and central Minnesota led to high dew points and very warm conditions across the region. Afternoon and early evening heat index values varied from 100 to 110 degrees each afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two-day heat index readings peaked very briefly at 106 degrees at a South Dakota Road Weather Information System site near Plankinton and 103 degrees at a South Dakota State University Mesonet site at White Lake.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE OF FRESNO AND KINGS COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge strengthened over California on October 1 and 2 then remained over the region through October 6. This resulted in several days of record heat over the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra Foothills. October 3 was the hottest day of the heat wave as several long standing all time record highs for the month of October were exceeded. The ridge finally shifted east into the Desert Southwest region on October 7 which reduced the heat impact across the area, but not before 3 additional days with  several records being broken. Temperatures finally cooled down to below record levels by October 10 as a weak shortwave trough moved into California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 101 and 106 degrees each day between October 2 and October 6.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana on August 1st before exceeding 110 degrees on August 2nd.

Some of the hottest weather of the season occurred as a mid and upper ridge dominated North and Central Texas during the middle to latter part of August. All of the forecast area reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the region reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria more than once during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached or exceeded 105 and/or heat index values reached or exceeded 110 across much of the county on August 23 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas ahead of a weak frontal boundary exhibited pooling of moisture with dew point readings into the upper 70s to lower 80s.  As temperatures reached the lower to mid 90s, dangerous heat conditions developed during the afternoon hours with heat index values from 100 to 111 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat index values reached 102 degrees at a personal weather station near Utica.

As temperatures reached the lower to mid 90s, dangerous heat conditions developed during the afternoon hours with heat index values from 100 to 111 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat index values very briefly reached 105 degrees at a personal weather station near Centerville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another short-lived heat wave in early August produced widespread above-normal temperature with triple digit readings and dangerous heat index values across most of North and Central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 103 or greater, and/or heat index values of 105 or greater impacted much of the county during the afternoon hours of August 7 and 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stagnant conditions south of a stalled frontal boundary across North Dakota and central Minnesota led to high dew points and very warm conditions across the region. Afternoon and early evening heat index values varied from 100 to 110 degrees each afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two-day heat index readings peaked very briefly at 105 degrees at the Automated Surface Observing System site at Chamberlain and 102 degrees at the South Dakota Road Weather Information System site at Kimball.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure locked in very warm and extremely humid conditions. Dew points in the upper 70s and lower 80s combined with temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s to produce daily heat index values from 100 to 120 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon and early evening heat index values reached as high as 113 degrees at Harrisburg and 107 degrees 10 miles east of Davis on August 25, as well as 112 degrees near Harrisburg and 107 degrees 10 miles east of Davis on August 26.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during mid August. Temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 120 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma from August 13th through 19th. At least sixteen people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, eight of which were transported to the hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperature and moisture have continued to prevail across the area, resulting in excessive heat indices across many coastal and urban areas in the islands. These heat values lead to the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in the Mesonet registered heat indices of 112 degrees for two hours or more.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across East and Northeast Texas on August 1st before exceeding 110 degrees on August 2nd.

After a relatively mild summer, a period of excessive heat impacted much of the region prompting air temperatures to reach well above 90 degrees during the afternoon on August 26th. This combined with dewpoints as high as 80 degrees in some locations allowed for heat indices to climb above 110 degrees on August 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anomalously warm air temperatures and high humidity allowed the heat index to reach between 110 to 115 degrees on August 26th across La Crosse County. Heat index values reached 112 degrees at the automated surface observation station at La Crosse Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another short-lived heat wave in early August produced widespread above-normal temperature with triple digit readings and dangerous heat index values across most of North and Central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 103 or greater, and/or heat index values of 105 or greater impacted much of the county during the afternoon hours of August 7 and 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Some of the hottest weather of the season occurred as a mid and upper ridge dominated North and Central Texas during the middle to latter part of August. All of the forecast area reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the region reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria more than once during this period. Unfortunately there were 4 heat related fatalities during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached or exceeded 105, or heat index values reached or exceeded 110 degrees across the county each afternoon from August 16 through August 19 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stagnant conditions south of a stalled frontal boundary across North Dakota and central Minnesota led to high dew points and very warm conditions across the region. Afternoon and early evening heat index values varied from 100 to 110 degrees each afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two-day peak heat index values reached 106 degrees at the South Dakota Road Weather Information System site near Wolsey, 105 degrees near Cavour, and 103 degrees at the Automated Surface Observing System site at Huron.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during mid August. Temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 120 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma from August 13th through 19th. At least sixteen people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, eight of which were transported to the hospital.

A large upper ridge strengthened over California on October 1 and 2 then remained over the region through October 6. This resulted in several days of record heat over the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra Foothills. October 3 was the hottest day of the heat wave as several long standing all time record highs for the month of October were exceeded. The ridge finally shifted east into the Desert Southwest region on October 7 which reduced the heat impact across the area, but not before 3 additional days with  several records being broken. Temperatures finally cooled down to below record levels by October 10 as a weak shortwave trough moved into California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 101 and 106 degrees each day between October 2 and October 6.

CZ_NAME: UPPER SANTA CRUZ RIVER AND ALTAR VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona August 3 and 4. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals in Tucson on August 3 and one individual found in the desert near Arivaca on August 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced in the Arivaca and Sasabe areas, causing the moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in the desert near Arivaca on August 4.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced in south central Pinal County, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperature and moisture have continued to prevail across the area, resulting in excessive heat indices across many coastal and urban areas in the islands. These heat values lead to the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in the Mesonet registered heat indices of 112 degrees for two hours or more.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An expansive upper-level ridge of high pressure across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region led to a prolonged period of excessive heat through much of mid August across Southwest Arkansas. Afternoon temperatures rose into the upper 90s to lower 100s for several consecutive days totaling nearly a full week from the 13th through the 18th. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices exceeding 110 degrees across Southwest Arkansas each day before the frontal boundary finally advanced southward on August 19th with slightly milder and drier air in its wake.

An expansive upper-level ridge of high pressure across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region led to a prolonged period of excessive heat through much of mid August across Southwest Arkansas. Afternoon temperatures rose into the upper 90s to lower 100s for several consecutive days totaling nearly a full week from the 13th through the 18th. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices exceeding 110 degrees across Southwest Arkansas each day before the frontal boundary finally advanced southward on August 19th with slightly milder and drier air in its wake.

After a relatively mild summer, a period of excessive heat impacted much of the region prompting air temperatures to reach well above 90 degrees during the afternoon on August 26th. This combined with dewpoints as high as 80 degrees in some locations allowed for heat indices to climb above 110 degrees on August 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anomalously warm air temperatures and high humidity allowed the heat index to reach between 106 to 113 degrees on August 26th across Trempealeau County. Heat index values reached 113 degrees at the Wisconsin Department of Transportation observation station south of Arcadia.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anomalously warm air temperatures and high humidity allowed the maximum heat index to reach up to 111 degrees on August 26th across Richland County on August 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another short-lived heat wave in early August produced widespread above-normal temperature with triple digit readings and dangerous heat index values across most of North and Central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 103 or greater, and/or heat index values of 105 or greater impacted much of the county during the afternoon hours of August 7 through August 9.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Heat Advisory continued from the end of July into the first few days of August across a good portion of North and Central Texas largely due to heat index values climbing above 105 degrees each afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached or exceeded 103, and/or heat index values reached or exceeded 105 across the county each afternoon on August 1 and 2. Denton County Public Health reported 4 heat related illnesses on these 2 days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another short-lived heat wave in early August produced widespread above-normal temperature with triple digit readings and dangerous heat index values across most of North and Central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 103 or greater, and/or heat index values of 105 or greater impacted much of the county during the afternoon hours of August 7 and 8. Denton County Public Health reported 9 heat related illnesses on these 2 days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Some of the hottest weather of the season occurred as a mid and upper ridge dominated North and Central Texas during the middle to latter part of August. All of the forecast area reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the region reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria more than once during this period. Unfortunately there were 4 heat related fatalities during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached or exceeded 105, or heat index values reached or exceeded 110 degrees across the county each afternoon from August 16 through August 19 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stagnant conditions south of a stalled frontal boundary across North Dakota and central Minnesota led to high dew points and very warm conditions across the region. Afternoon and early evening heat index values varied from 100 to 110 degrees each afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two-day heat index readings peaked at 104 degrees at a personal weather station in Sioux Falls, 103 degrees at the South Dakota State University Mesonet site near Baltic, and 102 degrees at the South Dakota State University Mesonet site near Wall Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stagnant conditions south of a stalled frontal boundary across North Dakota and central Minnesota led to high dew points and very warm conditions across the region. Afternoon and early evening heat index values varied from 100 to 110 degrees each afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two-day heat index readings peaked at 103 degrees at personal weather stations near Wagner and Platte, 102 degrees at the RAWS site near Geddes, and 100 degrees at the South Dakota Road Weather Information System site near Wagner.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during mid August. Temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 120 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma from August 13th through 19th. At least sixteen people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa, eight of which were transported to the hospital.

A large upper ridge strengthened over California on October 1 and 2 then remained over the region through October 6. This resulted in several days of record heat over the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra Foothills. October 3 was the hottest day of the heat wave as several long standing all time record highs for the month of October were exceeded. The ridge finally shifted east into the Desert Southwest region on October 7 which reduced the heat impact across the area, but not before 3 additional days with  several records being broken. Temperatures finally cooled down to below record levels by October 10 as a weak shortwave trough moved into California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 98 and 103 degrees each day between October 2 and October 6.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperature and moisture have continued to prevail across the area, resulting in excessive heat indices across many coastal and urban areas in the islands. These heat values lead to the issuance of Excessive Heat Warnings across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in the Mesonet registered heat indices of 112 degrees for two hours or more.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona July 8-12. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert, eight in the Tucson area, two in the Safford area and another in Rio Rico. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of twelve individuals in the Tucson area and another near Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 7 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in Western Pima County July 8 through July 11 causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 6 to 10 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona resulting in major Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death in two individuals and a contributing factor in the death of seven individuals in Tucson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 6 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in south central Pinal County, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

A summertime ridge of atmospheric high pressure centered over the U.S. Four Corners region and extending southeast through north Texas combined with light southeast flow and ample surface humidity across the Lower Rio Grande Valley to produce a few days of apparent temperature values briefly at or just below local Heat Advisory criteria (110F to 111F). ||Values reached 111F or higher in southern Hidalgo County for around 2 hours on the 8th; values reached near these values on the 9th through 12th but did not last for more than an hour in any location.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 111 or higher at McAllen/Miller International Airport (KMFE) for several hours. Values occurred between 1130 AM and 130 PM CST, and again from 330 to 5 PM CST.  Peak values reached 114 at 1153 AM CST.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of one individual on July 9 in the Rio Rico area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona July 8-12. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert, eight in the Tucson area, two in the Safford area and another in Rio Rico. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of twelve individuals in the Tucson area and another near Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 7 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in South Central Pinal County July 8 through July 11 causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 6 to 10 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona resulting in major Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death in two individuals and a contributing factor in the death of seven individuals in Tucson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 6 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in western Pima County, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 6 to 10 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona resulting in major Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death in two individuals and a contributing factor in the death of seven individuals in Tucson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 6 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson area, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. Tucson had a high of 109 degrees on July 6. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of two individuals and a contributing factor for seven other individuals.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure remained entrenched over the Desert Southwest, leading to more daily and annual records for heat. The episode began in September.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on the first seven days of the month. The event began in September.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly 2 week heat wave occurred October 1 to October 12. Palm Springs reached 117F for a high on October 1, making it the hottest day recorded in October. It also reached 115F on October 6 and 7, 2024.  The month average high of 98.0F and average temperature of 83.3F (average high and low) making it the 3rd warmest on record. Hot temperatures also occurred across the inland valleys and mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Palm Springs airport reached 117F on October 1st. Hottest day recorded in October. Note that Phoenix also recorded record highs of 117F in late September 28-29, 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An expansive upper-level ridge of high pressure across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region led to a prolonged period of excessive heat through much of mid August across all of North Louisiana. Afternoon temperatures rose into the upper 90s to lower 100s for several consecutive days totaling nearly a full week from the 13th through the 18th. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices exceeding 110 degrees each day across North Louisiana before the frontal boundary finally advanced southwestward on August 19th with slightly milder and drier air in its wake.

Some of the hottest weather of the season occurred as a mid and upper ridge dominated North and Central Texas during the middle to latter part of August. All of the forecast area reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the region reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria more than once during this period. Unfortunately there were 4 heat related fatalities during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values met or exceeded 105 across much of the county from August 13 to August 23 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stagnant conditions south of a stalled frontal boundary across North Dakota and central Minnesota led to high dew points and very warm conditions across the region. Afternoon and early evening heat index values varied from 100 to 110 degrees each afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two-day heat index values peaked very briefly at 105 degrees at a personal weather station near Alta, as well as 102 degrees at a Iowa Road Weather Information System site near Rembrandt and 100 degrees at a personal weather station near Storm Lake.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly 2 week heat wave occurred October 1 to October 12. Palm Springs reached 117F for a high on October 1, making it the hottest day recorded in October. It also reached 115F on October 6 and 7, 2024.  The month average high of 98.0F and average temperature of 83.3F (average high and low) making it the 3rd warmest on record. Hot temperatures also occurred across the inland valleys and mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An unusual heat wave occurred October 5-6, 2024. High temperatures in the Inland Empire, in region known as the Lake Elsinore convergence zone (most protected by sea breeze from the south and another from the northwest) reached 104 to 108F each day. This was when air temperature monitoring was occurring at Galway Downs equestrian center and brought high concern about hosting events in Temecula in the Los Angeles 2028 Olympics.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 8 to 16 degrees above normal caused record-breaking heat across Southeast Arizona. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three individuals in Douglas, Bisbee, and Ajo. The Pima County Medical Examiner also found heat contributed to the death of another individual in the Tucson Metro area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 10 to 15 degrees above normal caused record-breaking high temperatures across Southeast Arizona. Tucson International Airport reached a high temperature of 104 degrees causing the Moderate HeatRisk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was a contributing factor in the death of an individual.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 9 to 14 degrees above normal caused record-breaking heat across Southeast Arizona. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the cause of death for an individual in Tucson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 12 to 16 degrees above normal caused record-breaking temperatures across Southeast Arizona. Tucson International Airport reached a high temperature of 99 degrees Fahrenheit. The Pima County Medical Examiner found that heat was a contributing factor in the death of an individual in Tucson.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three individuals in Douglas, Bisbee, and Ajo. The Pima County Medical Examiner also found heat contributed to the death of another individual in the Tucson Metro area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 8 to 16 degrees above normal caused record-breaking heat across Southeast Arizona. An Ajo CWOP station reached a high temperature of 103 degrees Fahrenheit and reached Major HeatRisk. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for an individual in Ajo.

The Pima County Medical Examiner also found heat contributed to the death of another individual in the Tucson Metro area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 14 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson Metro area causing Major HeatRisk category to be reached. An airshow at McConnell Air Force Base was held over the weekend of the 23rd to 25th. On Saturday, temperatures rose to near 100 degrees with the base reporting 99 degrees and heat indices of 106 to 107. According to emergency medical services, there were 607 people treated for potential heat stress with 15 of them being transported to the hospital.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency medical services provided onsite at the air show treated 607 people for heat stress according to their after action review which was relayed by emergency management. The responders included military medical personnel too. There were 15 people transported to the hospital. Temperatures ranged from 91 to 99 degrees based on the sensor at the base during the afternoon hours with dewpoints ranging from 69 to 73 resulting in heat indices of 98 to 107. Wind speeds ranged from 13 to 17 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure locked in very warm and extremely humid conditions. Dew points in the upper 70s and lower 80s combined with temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s to produce daily heat index values from 100 to 120 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon and early evening heat index values reached as high as 107 degrees near Letcher and Forestburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure locked in very warm and extremely humid conditions. Dew points in the upper 70s and lower 80s combined with temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s to produce daily heat index values from 100 to 120 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stagnant conditions south of a stalled frontal boundary across North Dakota and central Minnesota led to high dew points and very warm conditions across the region. Afternoon and early evening heat index values varied from 100 to 110 degrees each afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two-day heat index values peaked very briefly at 106 degrees at a personal weather in the northern portions of Sioux City, 102 degrees at the RAWS site near Westfield, and 100 degrees at the Automated Weather Observing System site in Le Mars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona July 8-12. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert, eight in the Tucson area, two in the Safford area and another in Rio Rico. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of twelve individuals in the Tucson area and another near Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 7 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced on the Tohono O'odham Nation July 8 through July 11 causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of one individual on July 8 and another on July 11. Additionally, heat was a contributing factor in the death of one individual on July 10.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona August 3 and 4. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals in Tucson on August 3 and one individual found in the desert near Arivaca on August 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced in western Pima County, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced on the Tohono O'odham Nation, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An expansive upper-level ridge of high pressure across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region led to a prolonged period of excessive heat through much of mid August across all of North Louisiana. Afternoon temperatures rose into the upper 90s to lower 100s for several consecutive days totaling nearly a full week from the 13th through the 18th. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices exceeding 110 degrees each day across North Louisiana before the frontal boundary finally advanced southwestward on August 19th with slightly milder and drier air in its wake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas ahead of a weak frontal boundary exhibited pooling of moisture with dew point readings into the upper 70s to lower 80s. As temperatures reached the lower to mid 90s, dangerous heat conditions developed during the afternoon hours with heat index values from 100 to 111 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat index values peaked at 103 degrees at a personal weather in Milford, 102 degrees at Terril, and 101 degrees near Lake Park.

An expansive upper-level ridge of high pressure across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region led to a prolonged period of excessive heat through much of mid August across East and Northeast Texas. Afternoon temperatures rose into the upper 90s to lower 100s for several consecutive days totaling a full week from the 13th through the 19th. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices exceeding 110 degrees each day across East and Northeast Texas before the frontal boundary finally advanced southward on August 19th with slightly milder and drier air in its wake.

Some of the hottest weather of the season occurred as a mid and upper ridge dominated North and Central Texas during the middle to latter part of August. All of the forecast area reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the region reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria more than once during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached or exceeded 105 and/or heat index values reached or exceeded 110 across much of the county on August 23 2024.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona July 8-12. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert, eight in the Tucson area, two in the Safford area and another in Rio Rico. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of twelve individuals in the Tucson area and another near Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 7 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in Southeast Pinal County July 8 through July 11 causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 7 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in South Central Pinal County July 8 through July 9 causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

CZ_NAME: UPPER GILA RIVER AND ARAVAIPA VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona July 8-12. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert, eight in the Tucson area, two in the Safford area and another in Rio Rico. Heat was determined to be a contributing factor in the death of twelve individuals in the Tucson area and another near Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 7 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in the Upper Gila River Valley July 8 through July 9 causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure locked in very warm and extremely humid conditions. Dew points in the upper 70s and lower 80s combined with temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s to produce daily heat index values from 100 to 120 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon and early evening heat index values reached as high as 104 degrees near Rushmore and at Worthington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure locked in very warm and extremely humid conditions. Dew points in the upper 70s and lower 80s combined with temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s to produce daily heat index values from 100 to 120 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon and early evening heat index values reached as high as 102 degrees near Pipestone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas ahead of a weak frontal boundary exhibited pooling of moisture with dew point readings into the upper 70s to lower 80s. As temperatures reached the lower to mid 90s, dangerous heat conditions developed during the afternoon hours with heat index values from 100 to 111 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat index values peaked at 109 degrees at a personal weather station on the southern side of Sioux City, 108 degrees near Washta, and 104 degrees at the Iowa Road Weather Information System site at Moville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure locked in very warm and extremely humid conditions. Dew points in the upper 70s and lower 80s combined with temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s to produce daily heat index values from 100 to 120 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon and early evening heat index values reached as high as 117 degrees at Alta on August 25 and at Storm Lake  on August 26.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 8 to 16  degrees above normal caused record-breaking heat across Southeast Arizona. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals in Sells. The Pima County Medical Examiner also found heat contributed to the death of another individual in the Tucson Metro area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 8 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in Sells causing Moderate HeatRisk category to be reached. The Sells RAWS reached a high temperature of 104 degrees Fahrenheit. The Pima County Medical Examiner found that heat was the primary factor in the death of one individual.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three individuals in Douglas, Bisbee, and Ajo. The Pima County Medical Examiner also found heat contributed to the death of another individual in the Tucson Metro area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona August 3 and 4. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals in Tucson on August 3 and one individual found in the desert near Arivaca on August 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 7 to 11 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson Metro area, causing the Major Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals in Tucson on August 3.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of high pressure systems contributed to a week-long heat wave to begin the month of October. During this period, every long-term climate site in the region set or tied at least one daily high temperature record. In San Jose, a high of 106 recorded on October 2 set a monthly high temperature record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sonoma County reported 19 calls to 911 for heat related illnesses between October 2 and 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across East and Northeast Texas on August 1st before increasing even further on August 2nd.

An upper-level ridge of high pressure expanded back eastward across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region on August 7th through the 8th. Afternoon temperatures rose into the mid and upper 90s to lower 100s on both days. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana before the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward with slightly lower humidity and milder temperatures in its wake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The end of July heat event continued through the afternoon on August 1st, with a line of storms crossing northwest Kentucky mid-afternoon, continuing through the Pennyrile late afternoon. Cooler and drier conditions remained afterwards. The highest heat index on the 1st in Western Kentucky was 120F at the Murray-Calloway County Regional Airport AWOS site.

The end of July heat event continued through the afternoon on August 1st, with a line of storms crossing northwest Kentucky mid-afternoon, continuing through the Pennyrile late afternoon. Cooler and drier conditions remained afterwards. The highest heat index on the 1st in Western Kentucky was 120F at the Murray-Calloway County Regional Airport AWOS site.

The end of July heat event continued through midday on August 1st, at which point a line of storms moved through the I-64 corridor, resulting in cooler and drier conditions afterwards. Isolated storms developed late afternoon into the evening. The highest heat indices on the 1st in Southern Illinois were 112F observations at the Crab Orchard RAWS site, the Dixon Springs RAWS site, and the Cairo Regional Airport AWOS. Some counties reached excessive heat warning criteria by meeting heat advisory criteria 4 consecutive days.

A strong upper-level high-pressure system covered the Lower Mississippi Valley at the beginning of August. Persistent moist southwest flow brought high dewpoints into the region. Hot temperatures combined with dewpoints well into the 70s resulted in widespread afternoon heat index values above 110 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level high pressure spread eastward across the Mid-South while surface moisture advected into the region from Hurricane Debby, which made landfall along the west coast of Florida on August 5, 2024.  As a result, hot and humid conditions returned to the Mid-South with heat index values exceeding 105 degrees in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana on August 1st before increasing even further on August 2nd.

The combination of hot temperatures, high low-level moisture, and a Saharan Air Layer results in dangerous heat levels for people's health, especially in urban and coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station GW0592 Moca reported 115F, and the heat index remained above 112F for more than 2 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The area was experiencing an east-to-southeasterly wind pattern with above-normal sea surface temperatures, warmer-than-normal minimum temperatures, and near-to-above-normal moisture content. This pattern led to higher-than-average temperatures throughout the end of August despite the arrival of weak tropical waves. As a result, the urban and coastal areas of Puerto Rico experienced a heat spell, prompting the issuance of Heat Advisories and Excessive Heat Warnings during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stations in Ponce registered heat indices of 112 degrees or more for two hours or more each day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a relatively mild summer, a period of excessive heat impacted much of the region prompting air temperatures to reach well above 90 degrees during the afternoon on August 26th. This combined with dewpoints as high as 80 degrees in some locations allowed for heat indices to climb above 110 degrees on August 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anomalously warm air temperatures and high humidity allowed the heat index to reach between 108 and 120 degrees across Floyd County on August 26th. The heat index reached 117 degrees at the automated weather observation station at Charles City.

Hot temperatures combined with dewpoints well into the 70s resulted in widespread afternoon heat index values above 110 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level high pressure spread eastward across the Mid-South while surface moisture advected into the region from Hurricane Debby, which made landfall along the west coast of Florida on August 5, 2024.  As a result, hot and humid conditions returned to the Mid-South with heat index values exceeding 105 degrees in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a relatively mild summer, a period of excessive heat impacted much of the region prompting air temperatures to reach well above 90 degrees during the afternoon on August 26th. This combined with dewpoints as high as 80 degrees in some locations allowed for heat indices to climb above 110 degrees on August 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anomalously warm air temperatures and high humidity allowed the heat index to reach 108 degrees at an Iowa Department of Transportation surface observation station near New Hampton on August 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a relatively mild summer, a period of excessive heat impacted much of the region prompting air temperatures to reach well above 90 degrees during the afternoon on August 26th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anomalously warm air temperatures and high humidity allowed the maximum heat index to reach between 105 and 117 degrees across Olmsted County on August 26th. The heat index reached 111 degrees at the automated weather observation station at Rochester International Airport. Rochester Public Schools decided to cancel all outdoor activities for the afternoon hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana on August 1st before increasing even further on August 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The end of July heat event continued through midday on August 1st, at which point a line of storms moved through the I-64 corridor, resulting in cooler and drier conditions afterwards. Isolated storms developed late afternoon into the evening. The highest heat indices on the 1st in Southern Illinois were 112F observations at the Crab Orchard RAWS site, the Dixon Springs RAWS site, and the Cairo Regional Airport AWOS. Some counties reached excessive heat warning criteria by meeting heat advisory criteria 4 consecutive days.

An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana on August 1st. Heat indices increased even further on August 2nd and then dropped slightly below 110 degrees by August 3rd as the ridge retrograded westward and the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward into North Louisiana.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High heat and humidity moved into the region during the early days of August. High temperatures in the upper 90s to low 100s were widespread across central, north central and northeast South Dakota on both August 2nd and 3rd. A peak high temperature of 104 degrees was recorded at the South Dakota State University Mesonet stations 7 miles southwest of Hayes and 16 miles east southeast of Pierre on August 3rd.  Dewpoints across much of northeast South Dakota were also well into the 70s with a few locations topping an 80 degree dewpoint. Heat index values reached 110 degrees at Stratford and Millette on Friday August 2nd and 113 degrees in Redfield on Saturday August 3rd.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late July and continued into early August. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma from July 29th through August 1st.

Another hot and humid airmass moved into the region in late August. Heat index values topped out at 114 degrees at the Department of Transportation weather station 5 miles east of Orient, with an additional 30 weather stations across 16 counties in central and northeast South Dakota reporting a heat index above 105 degrees that afternoon. This was thanks to temperatures in the upper 90s and dewpoints up to 80 degrees. Aberdeen would also see a record warm low temperature of 75 degrees that morning.

A strong upper-level high-pressure system covered the Lower Mississippi Valley at the beginning of August. Persistent moist southwest flow brought high dewpoints into the region. Hot temperatures combined with dewpoints well into the 70s resulted in widespread afternoon heat index values above 110 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values exceeded 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front approached the region, excessive moisture and heat pooled across parts of the Mid-South. Dewpoints surged into the mid-70s ahead of the slow-moving front resulting in heat indices between 105 and 114 degrees for southwestern portions of the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in between 105 and 109 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana on August 1st. Heat indices increased even further on August 2nd and then dropped slightly below 110 degrees by August 3rd as the ridge retrograded westward and the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward into North Louisiana.

An upper-level ridge of high pressure expanded back eastward across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region on August 7th through the 8th. Afternoon temperatures rose into the mid and upper 90s to lower 100s on both days. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana before the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward with slightly lower humidity and milder temperatures in its wake.

High heat and humidity moved into the region during the early days of August. High temperatures in the upper 90s to low 100s were widespread across central, north central and northeast South Dakota on both August 2nd and 3rd. A peak high temperature of 104 degrees was recorded at the South Dakota State University Mesonet stations 7 miles southwest of Hayes and 16 miles east southeast of Pierre on August 3rd.  Dewpoints across much of northeast South Dakota were also well into the 70s with a few locations topping an 80 degree dewpoint. Heat index values reached 110 degrees at Stratford and Millette on Friday August 2nd and 113 degrees in Redfield on Saturday August 3rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values ranged from 110 to 118 degrees. A 22-month old died this day after being left in a hot car. The child was left in a vehicle in the Tom Browne Middle School parking lot in Corpus Christi, TX. A Heat Advisory was in effect at the time of the incident. The Advisory was upgraded to an Excessive Heat Warning at 3:28 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level high-pressure system covered the Lower Mississippi Valley at the beginning of August. Persistent moist southwest flow brought high dewpoints into the region. Hot temperatures combined with dewpoints well into the 70s resulted in widespread afternoon heat index values above 110 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front approached the region, excessive moisture and heat pooled across parts of the Mid-South. Dewpoints surged into the mid-70s ahead of the slow-moving front resulting in heat indices between 105 and 114 degrees for southwestern portions of the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana on August 1st. Heat indices increased even further on August 2nd and then dropped slightly below 110 degrees by August 3rd as the ridge retrograded westward and the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward into North Louisiana.

An upper-level ridge of high pressure expanded back eastward across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region on August 7th through the 8th. Afternoon temperatures rose into the mid and upper 90s to lower 100s on both days. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across East and Northeast Texas before the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward with slightly lower humidity and milder temperatures in its wake.

High heat and humidity moved into the region during the early days of August. High temperatures in the upper 90s to low 100s were widespread across central, north central and northeast South Dakota on both August 2nd and 3rd. A peak high temperature of 104 degrees was recorded at the South Dakota State University Mesonet stations 7 miles southwest of Hayes and 16 miles east southeast of Pierre on August 3rd.  Dewpoints across much of northeast South Dakota were also well into the 70s with a few locations topping an 80 degree dewpoint. Heat index values reached 110 degrees at Stratford and Millette on Friday August 2nd and 113 degrees in Redfield on Saturday August 3rd.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late July and continued into early August. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma from July 29th through August 1st.

Another hot and humid airmass moved into the region in late August. Heat index values topped out at 114 degrees at the Department of Transportation weather station 5 miles east of Orient, with an additional 30 weather stations across 16 counties in central and northeast South Dakota reporting a heat index above 105 degrees that afternoon. This was thanks to temperatures in the upper 90s and dewpoints up to 80 degrees. Aberdeen would also see a record warm low temperature of 75 degrees that morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High heat and humidity moved into the region during the early days of August. High temperatures in the upper 90s to low 100s were widespread across central, north central and northeast South Dakota on both August 2nd and 3rd. A peak high temperature of 104 degrees was recorded at the South Dakota State University Mesonet stations 7 miles southwest of Hayes and 16 miles east southeast of Pierre on August 3rd.  Dewpoints across much of northeast South Dakota were also well into the 70s with a few locations topping an 80 degree dewpoint. Heat index values reached 110 degrees at Stratford and Millette on Friday August 2nd and 113 degrees in Redfield on Saturday August 3rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late July and continued into early August. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma from July 29th through August 1st.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE MOUNTAINS NORTH OF HIGHWAY 198
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure strengthened over the Great Basin between August 4 and 6 bringing a return of dangerous heat to the area. The ridge strengthened further on August  7 resulting in several new daily climatological records being set before a cold front pushed through central California on August 8 which lowered temperatures below dangerous levels at most locations although widespread triple digit heat prevailed across the lower elevations through August 11. An upper trough moved into central California on August 12 lowering temperatures to near normal levels for the middle portion of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 104 and 109 degrees each day between August 4 and August 6 and between 107 and 112 degrees on August 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another hot and humid airmass moved into the region in late August. Heat index values topped out at 114 degrees at the Department of Transportation weather station 5 miles east of Orient, with an additional 30 weather stations across 16 counties in central and northeast South Dakota reporting a heat index above 105 degrees that afternoon. This was thanks to temperatures in the upper 90s and dewpoints up to 80 degrees. Aberdeen would also see a record warm low temperature of 75 degrees that morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level high-pressure system covered the Lower Mississippi Valley at the beginning of August. Persistent moist southwest flow brought high dewpoints into the region. Hot temperatures combined with dewpoints well into the 70s resulted in widespread afternoon heat index values above 110 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Typical late August heat became more uncomfortable as humidity climbed due to the return of moist southerly flow. Dewpoints across parts of east-central Arkansas and north Mississippi surged into the mid to upper 70s during the afternoon hours of August 29, 2024, which resulted in heat indices at or above 105 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana on August 1st. Heat indices increased even further on August 2nd and then dropped slightly below 110 degrees by August 3rd as the ridge retrograded westward and the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward into North Louisiana.
