An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across the lower half of East Texas through August 3rd.

An upper-level ridge of high pressure expanded back eastward across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region on August 7th through the 8th. Afternoon temperatures rose into the mid and upper 90s to lower 100s on both days. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across East and Northeast Texas before the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward with slightly lower humidity and milder temperatures in its wake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across the lower half of East Texas through August 3rd.

An upper-level ridge of high pressure expanded back eastward across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region on August 7th through the 8th. Afternoon temperatures rose into the mid and upper 90s to lower 100s on both days. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across East and Northeast Texas before the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward with slightly lower humidity and milder temperatures in its wake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late July and continued into early August. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of west central Arkansas on August 1st.

Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of west central Arkansas on August 1st.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late July and continued into early August. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of west central Arkansas on August 1st.

A large area of high pressure strengthened over the Great Basin between August 4 and 6 bringing a return of dangerous heat to the area. The ridge strengthened further on August  7 resulting in several new daily climatological records being set before a cold front pushed through central California on August 8 which lowered temperatures below dangerous levels at most locations although widespread triple digit heat prevailed across the lower elevations through August 11. An upper trough moved into central California on August 12 lowering temperatures to near normal levels for the middle portion of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 104 and 109 degrees each day between August 4 and August 6 and between 107 and 112 degrees on August 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Typical late August heat became more uncomfortable as humidity climbed due to the return of moist southerly flow. Dewpoints across parts of east-central Arkansas and north Mississippi surged into the mid to upper 70s during the afternoon hours of August 29, 2024, which resulted in heat indices at or above 105 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees.

An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across Harrison County on August 1st. Heat indices increased even further on August 2nd and then dropped slightly below 110 degrees by August 3rd as the upper ridge retrograded westward and the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward into Harrison County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure expanded back eastward across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region on August 7th through the 8th. Afternoon temperatures rose into the mid and upper 90s to lower 100s on both days. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across Southwest Arkansas before the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward with slightly lower humidity and milder temperatures in its wake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere redeveloped over the south central United States during late August. Temperatures reaching the mid 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with unseasonably high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on August 24th.

A large area of high pressure strengthened over the Great Basin between August 4 and 6 bringing a return of dangerous heat to the area. The ridge strengthened further on August  7 resulting in several new daily climatological records being set before a cold front pushed through central California on August 8 which lowered temperatures below dangerous levels at most locations although widespread triple digit heat prevailed across the lower elevations through August 11. An upper trough moved into central California on August 12 lowering temperatures to near normal levels for the middle portion of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 104 and 109 degrees each day between August 4 and August 6 and between 107 and 112 degrees on August 7.

CZ_NAME: LOWER HELLS CANYON / SALMON RIVER REGION
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge of high pressure resulted in major to extreme heat risk in the lower Salmon and lower Clearwater River valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure resulted in Excessive Heat Watches and Warnings.  The Heat Risk was rated Major to Extreme.  A RAWS observing site in Slate Creek, ID reached a high of 113 degrees on August 2 with low temperatures only getting down to about 78 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent ridge of high pressure resulted in major to extreme heat risk in the lower Salmon and lower Clearwater River valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure resulted in Excessive Heat Watches and Warnings.  The Heat Risk was rated Major to Extreme.  An observing site in Orofino, ID reached a high of 104 degrees on August 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The end of July heat event continued through the afternoon on August 1st, with a few isolated showers late afternoon. Cooler and drier conditions remained afterwards. The highest heat index on the 1st in Southeast Missouri was 114F at the Cape Girardeau Regional Airport ASOS site. Some counties reached excessive heat warning criteria by meeting at least heat advisory criteria 4 consecutive days.

A strong upper-level high-pressure system covered the Lower Mississippi Valley at the beginning of August. Persistent moist southwest flow brought high dewpoints into the region. Hot temperatures combined with dewpoints well into the 70s resulted in widespread afternoon heat index values above 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across East and Northeast Texas on August 1st before increasing even further on August 2nd.

Hot, humid conditions were present across eastern New York on Friday, August 2, 2024. Heat index values (feels-like temperatures) reached the upper 80s to low 90s across much of the region, but mid to upper 90s were reached in eastern Ulster, Dutchess, and Washington counties, creating dangerously hot and humid conditions. ||Additionally, scattered thunderstorms, some of which reached severe strength in Dutchess County, developed across portions of the region in the afternoon and evening hours. Severe thunderstorms lead to several reports of tree damage in Dutchess County.

Heat index values (feels-like temperatures) reached the upper 80s to low 90s across much of the region, but mid to upper 90s were reached in eastern Ulster, Dutchess, and Washington counties, creating dangerously hot and humid conditions. ||Additionally, scattered thunderstorms, some of which reached severe strength in Dutchess County, developed across portions of the region in the afternoon and evening hours. Severe thunderstorms lead to several reports of tree damage in Dutchess County.

A strong upper-level high-pressure system covered the Lower Mississippi Valley at the beginning of August. Persistent moist southwest flow brought high dewpoints into the region. Hot temperatures combined with dewpoints well into the 70s resulted in widespread afternoon heat index values above 110 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in excess of 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level ridge of high pressure extending from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region that began in late July, maintained its presence into early August. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s during the first few days of the month. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of a weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across East and Northeast Texas on August 1st before increasing even further on August 2nd.

An upper-level ridge of high pressure expanded back eastward across the Southern Plains and Gulf Coast region on August 7th through the 8th. Afternoon temperatures rose into the mid and upper 90s to lower 100s on both days. Deep southerly moisture pooling in advance of another weak frontal boundary resulted in very minimal mixing of dew points, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees across all of North Louisiana before the frontal boundary slowly advanced southwestward with slightly lower humidity and milder temperatures in its wake.

Areas ahead of a weak frontal boundary exhibited pooling of moisture with dew point readings into the upper 70s to lower 80s. As temperatures reached the lower to mid 90s, dangerous heat conditions developed during the afternoon hours with heat index values from 100 to 111 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat index values peaked at 109 degrees at a personal weather station in Battle Creek and 105 degrees at the Iowa Road Weather Information System site at Ida Grove.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure locked in very warm and extremely humid conditions. Dew points in the upper 70s and lower 80s combined with temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s to produce daily heat index values from 100 to 120 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon and early evening heat index values reached as high as 117 degrees near Lakefield and 110 degrees at Jackson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The end of July heat event continued through the afternoon on August 1st, with a line of storms crossing northwest Kentucky mid-afternoon, continuing through the Pennyrile late afternoon. Cooler and drier conditions remained afterwards. The highest heat index on the 1st in Western Kentucky was 120F at the Murray-Calloway County Regional Airport AWOS site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure prevailed over Texas and the southwest United States. The upper level ridge amplified over the area and moved little. Dry and very hot conditions prevailed through most of the month. Abilene and San Angelo both had 23 days in August with high temperatures of 100 or more.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Abilene Regional Airport set an all time hottest temperature of 113 degrees  on August 21st. Also, record highs of 111 degrees and 112 degrees were set on August 22nd and 23rd. Other record highs of between 105 degrees and 110 degrees were set on August 8th and August 19th and 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure prevailed over Texas and the southwest United States. The upper level ridge amplified over the area and moved little. Dry and very hot conditions prevailed through most of the month. Abilene and San Angelo both had 23 days in August with high temperatures of 100 or more.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The San Angelo Regional Airport set a new monthly record high for August which was  112 degrees on August 22nd. Also, record highs of 111 degrees and 108 degrees were set on August 21st and 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 4 to 9 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across portions of southeast Arizona resulting in moderate to major Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death of one individual found in the desert near Ajo on July 23, another just south of Tucson on July 24 and a third on July 25 in Nogales. Heat was a contributing factor in the cause of death for two individuals in the Tucson area on July 24.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 4 to 9 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across the Tucson Metro resulting in moderate Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death of one individual found in the desert just south of Tucson on July 24. Heat was a contributing factor in the cause of death for two individuals in the Tucson area on July 24.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 3 to 6 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona July 17 through July 20. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for a total of five individuals during this period. Four of these individuals were located in the desert. Heat was a contributing factor in the death of two individuals during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 3 to 6 degrees above normal were experienced on the Tohono O'odham Nation July 17 and July 18, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of one individual found in the desert near Sells on July 17, another near Sells on July 18 and a third near Topowa on July 18.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 4 to 9 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across portions of southeast Arizona resulting in moderate to major Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death of one individual found in the desert near Ajo on July 23, another just south of Tucson on July 24 and a third on July 25 in Nogales. Heat was a contributing factor in the cause of death for two individuals in the Tucson area on July 24.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 9 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across western Pima County resulting in major Heat Risk. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death of one individual found in the desert near Ajo on July 23.

CZ_NAME: UPPER SANTA CRUZ RIVER AND ALTAR VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 4 to 9 degrees degrees above normal were experienced across portions of southeast Arizona resulting in moderate to major Heat Risk. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures typically 3 to 6 degrees above normal were experienced across southeast Arizona July 17 through July 20. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for a total of five individuals during this period. Four of these individuals were located in the desert. Heat was a contributing factor in the death of two individuals during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 3 to 6 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson area July 18 through July 20, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary factor in the death of two individuals during this period and a contributing factor in two additional individuals.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong sub-tropical ridge/heat dome centered over central and southern Mexico strengthened and shifted northward towards the Rio Grande Valley/Deep South Texas region. Temperatures at around 5,000 feet above the ground soared to 78 to 86 degrees Fahrenheit over the local area. This translated to surface temperatures rising into the upper 90s to mid 100s from May 7-9. Combined with dewpoint temperatures in the 70s to around 80, this produced apparent, or feels-like temperatures, between 111-116F across locations along and east of IH-69C/US 281 from Brooks/Hidalgo County into Cameron, Willacy, and Kenedy County. The hottest temperatures were located from the mid-lower Rio Grande Valley northward along I-69E and I-69C, peaking on May 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: McAllen International Airport (KMFE) recorded max heat indices between 111-114F for a couple of hours, from 3:30-5:40 PM CDT on May 7, 2024.  Values peaked at 114F at 353 PM CST.  The South Texas International Airport (11 miles north of Edinburg) along the edge of southern and northern Hidalgo County reached 112F at 335 PM CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper ridge of high pressure built back across the Southern Plains during mid-July, gradually expanding eastward into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s from July 15th through the 17th. Deep southerly moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees each afternoon across all of Southwest Arkansas.

Hot temperatures 3 to 6 degrees above normal were experienced across much of southeast Arizona September 1-4. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three individuals, two in the Tucson metro area and one in the desert near Sells. Additionally, the Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was a contributing factor in the cause of death for two other individuals.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures about 2 degrees above normal were experienced in the Tucson Metro Area September 1, causing the Minor Heat Risk category to be reached. Tucson International Airport topped out at 100 degrees on September 1. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was contributing factor in the death in one individual.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong ridge of high pressure brought record high temperatures to many locations across western and central Wyoming. In addition, 4 sites had their latest occurrence of a 90 degree high temperature in history. The most notable site was Lander, which has records dating back to 1891.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Johnson County airport had a record high temperature of 94 degrees. This was the latest occurrence of 90 degrees in station history.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of September 25, the Riverton airport recorded a high temperature of 90 degrees. This was a record high temperature and also the latest occurrence of a 90 degree high temperature in station history. Four days later this latest 90 F or greater record was broken on September 29.

A heat wave developed starting Labor Day weekend and peaked the next weekend September 5 to 9, 2024. The hottest days included Ramona reaching 114, Santa Ana 113,  and Anaheim an all-time record of 112.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperature reached a record 112 in Anaheim on September 6, 2024.  The heat wave lasted through September 9th with high temperatures of 104 to 113F across inland Orange County. A woman and a child were found in a locked vehicle on September 6th. The child died at the hospital. Authorities reported the air temperature at 104 when they arrived at 420 pm. Authorities reported that alcohol was involved and the mother of the child was later arrested. 112 exceeds the prior all-time high temperature at Anaheim which was 109 set in September 2020.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge over the western states with a thermal trough extending from northern California to near the southern Oregon coast brought a few days of hot temperatures, with extreme heat during the hottest day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent high pressure brought excessive heat to Central Douglas County during the hottest day of the episode on September 5th. Low temperatures were generally in the mid 50s to lower 60s, and high temperatures in the upper 90s to 105 degrees. A record high temperature was set at Roseburg Regional Airport of 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105 to 109 degrees for much of the late morning and afternoon hours in north central and northwest Alabama. The heat index peaked at 110 to 112 degrees for a few hours during the mid afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second of three days of hot and humid conditions continued across eastern New York on July 16, 2024. Heat index (feels-like temperatures) reached 95 to 104 degrees across much of the Mohawk and Hudson valleys.||During the afternoon hours, a strong upper level disturbance developed an organized line of thunderstorms which tracked eastward across the region. Widespread severe weather occurred along this line. Widespread and, in some areas, considerable wind damage was observed along with embedded tornadoes through the western and southern Adirondacks, Mohawk Valley, Upper Hudson Valley and Capital District with the most intense storms occurring along and north of Interstate 90. Observed wind gusts ranged between 50 and 87 mph with these storms with the latter wind gust reported at the New York State Mesonet at Glens Falls.||National Weather Service Storm Surveys, with some being assisted by other state authorities, concluded seven tornado touchdowns. Six of these tornadoes were rated EF-1 with estimated peak winds between 90 and 110 mph. These tornadoes occurred in the Town of Ohio (Herkimer County), Little Moose Lake/Limekiln Lake (Hamilton County), the West Branch of the Sacandaga River/West River Road (Hamilton County), Oxbow Lake (Hamilton County), Wilcox Lake Wild Forest (Hamilton/Warren County), and the Town of Day (Saratoga County). One EF-0 tornado touched down near The Glen in central Warren County with estimated peak winds of 85 mph. During clean up efforts from the Town of Day tornado, a woman was seriously injured (indirect) after being struck by a tree.||In addition to tornadoes, two microbursts, determined through remote damage assessment using drone footage and satellite imagery, were noted in Warren County. Both brought large areas of extensive tree damage with hundreds of hardwood trees being uprooted and snapped. The first was noted in western Warren County along and east of Stewart Creek with the second around Bear Point at the Tongue Mountain Range that extends into Lake George. ||These thunderstorms resulted in numerous to widespread power outages with Hamilton and Warren counties the hardest hit. Some power outages lasted for multiple days and some area roads were also impassable for days.||States of Emergency were declared for multiple municipalities including the City of Glens Falls and all of Warren and Saratoga counties. New York Governor Kathy Hochul also declared a state of emergency for all of New York State following all of the severe thunderstorms that impacted the state over the past week.||The governor requested a Federal Emergency Declaration following this severe weather event which included the counties of Hamilton, Herkimer, Montgomery, Saratoga and Warren counties.||Scattered thunderstorms gradually developed across the mid-Hudson Valley eastward across the central and southern Taconics producing some additional pockets of wind damage, but this activity was much less widespread and intense compared to the storms farther north.

Heat index values reached 105 to 109 degrees for much of the late morning and afternoon hours in north central and northwest Alabama. The heat index peaked at 110 to 112 degrees for a few hours during the mid afternoon.

During clean up efforts from the Town of Day tornado, a woman was seriously injured (indirect) after being struck by a tree.||In addition to tornadoes, two microbursts, determined through remote damage assessment using drone footage and satellite imagery, were noted in Warren County. Both brought large areas of extensive tree damage with hundreds of hardwood trees being uprooted and snapped. The first was noted in western Warren County along and east of Stewart Creek with the second around Bear Point at the Tongue Mountain Range that extends into Lake George. ||These thunderstorms resulted in numerous to widespread power outages with Hamilton and Warren counties the hardest hit. Some power outages lasted for multiple days and some area roads were also impassable for days.||States of Emergency were declared for multiple municipalities including the City of Glens Falls and all of Warren and Saratoga counties. New York Governor Kathy Hochul also declared a state of emergency for all of New York State following all of the severe thunderstorms that impacted the state over the past week.||The governor requested a Federal Emergency Declaration following this severe weather event which included the counties of Hamilton, Herkimer, Montgomery, Saratoga and Warren counties.||Scattered thunderstorms gradually developed across the mid-Hudson Valley eastward across the central and southern Taconics producing some additional pockets of wind damage, but this activity was much less widespread and intense compared to the storms farther north.

Heat index values reached 105 to 109 degrees for much of the late morning and afternoon hours in north central and northwest Alabama. The heat index peaked at 110 to 112 degrees for a few hours during the mid afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index peaked at 110 degrees for a short period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level flow the evening of the 13th features a low-amplitude shortwave trough that had ejected out into the northern Great Plains. At the surface, a weakening stationary front was noted on WPC surface analysis to extend from northwest Nebraska into southeast Nebraska. Isolated strong thunderstorms that developed along this boundary brought a single severe wind gust in Knox County. However, the primary impact of this episode was the excessive heat that impacted much of southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. Heat indices the afternoon of the 15th in this area peaked between 110 and 115 degrees. The highest heat index was 117 degrees, observed by an AWOS station in Harlan, Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A maximum heat index of 114 degrees was observed the afternoon of the 15th. There were 8 hospitalizations from heat-related illness reported in Lancaster County as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southeasterly winds steering warmer tropical air into the islands, and sufficient moisture lead to heat index values exceeding Heat Advisory criteria across most coastal and lower elevation areas. Heat index values exceeded Excessive Heat Warning criteria on up to several days of the second half of May across San Juan and Vicinity, North Central Puerto Rico, Northwestern PR, Mayagez and Vicinity and Southwestern PR. Several stations across those areas reported heat indices surpassing 112 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several weather stations reported heat indices above 112 degrees for up to over two hours. These conditions were observed widespread along the coastal areas and the valleys.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper-level ridge of high pressure centered over the Midwest brought very hot weather to central Illinois on August 26th and 27th.  High temperatures were mostly in the lower to middle 90s on August 26th, but climbed into the 95-100 degree range on the 27th.  With dewpoints hovering in the upper 70s to near 80 degrees, heat index readings peaked from 105 to 115 degrees along and north of the I-72 corridor during the afternoon of August 27th.  While no heat-related deaths were reported, this was the hottest period of weather across central Illinois during the entire summer of 2024.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index readings peaked at 110-115 degrees during the afternoon of August 27th.  No heat-related deaths were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ridging continued into June and caused Heat Advisory to Excessive Heat Warning conditions with heat index values of 110-122 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Inland Nueces observed heat index values of 110-114.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Summer ridge heat pattern continued through late June and caused heat index values of 110-118 across the Coastal Bend and Brush Country.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coastal Aransas observed heat index values of 110-114.

An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across East Texas on the 3rd and 4th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees.

An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across East Texas on the 3rd and 4th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees.

An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across North Louisiana on the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

An upper ridge of high pressure built back across the Southern Plains during mid-July, gradually expanding eastward into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s from July 15th through the 17th. Deep southerly moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees each afternoon across all of East and Northeast Texas.

With breezy southerly winds bringing dew points in the mid to upper 70s to Southern Illinois under high pressure, heat indices in most of Southern Illinois surged to 105-113F on the 14th and 15th. The highest observed heat index was 113F at the Mount Vernon Airport AWOS on the 15th.
With breezy southerly winds bringing dew points in the mid 70s to Southwest Indiana under high pressure, heat indices in portions of Southwest Indiana surged to near 105F on the 14th and 15th.

An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across North Louisiana on the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the lower to middle 90s through July 2nd. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees each afternoon on July 1st and 2nd. However, the heat and humidity intensified by the afternoon of the 3rd and 4th as the front retreated back north, with heat indices surpassing 110 degrees.

Deep southerly moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees each afternoon across all of McCurtain County in Southeast Oklahoma.

Heat indices of 105-115F were reached in much of Southwest Kentucky on the 3rd and 4th. Strong moisture advection raised dew points to the mid 70s to lower 80s both days. The highest observed heat index was 126F on the 4th at the Murray-Calloway County Airport AWOS, though dew points and heat indices may be overestimated at that site (elsewhere, a 115F heat index was observed at the Cadiz 4 SW Kentucky Mesonet site on the 4th). Thunderstorms on the 3rd generally held off until sunset for Western Kentucky while scattered afternoon thunderstorms developed on the 4th.

Heat indices of 105-115F in much of Southeast Missouri on the 3rd and 4th while Perry and Carter counties only reached heat advisory criteria on the 4th. Strong moisture advection raised dew points to the mid 70s to around 80 both days. The highest observed heat index was 115F on the 3rd at the Cape Girardeau Regional Airport ASOS. Late afternoon thunderstorms in Southeast Missouri on the 3rd lowered heat indices for the evening while thunderstorm development the afternoon of the 4th was more isolated.

Heat indices of 105-114F were observed in much of Southern Illinois on the 3rd and 4th while the I-64 corridor only reached heat advisory criteria on the 4th. Strong moisture advection raised dew points to the mid to upper 70s both days. The highest observed heat index was 114F on the 4th at the Cairo Regional Airport AWOS. Late afternoon thunderstorms in Southern Illinois on the 3rd lowered heat indices for the evening while thunderstorms moved through Southern Illinois mid-morning on the 4th, temporarily delaying daytime heating.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees through July 2nd. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon on July 1st and 2nd. However, with the front retreating back northeast away from East Texas, allowing for slightly drier air to mix down to the ground from the west on the 3rd-5th.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees through July 2nd. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon on July 1st and 2nd. However, with the front retreating back northeast away from East Texas, allowing for slightly drier air to mix down to the ground from the west on the 3rd-5th.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees through July 4th. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from July 1st through the 4th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface on the 5th, resulting in lower heat indices of 105-109 degrees.

Far Western Southwest Kentucky reached heat indices of 103-108F on the 29th, with more widespread heat indices of 105-117F throughout Western Kentucky on the 30th and 31st, extending into the start of August. Dew points reached the upper 70s on the 30th and 31st. The highest heat index reached in Southwest Kentucky was 121F at Murray-Calloway County Airport AWOS on the 30th. Late afternoon to early evening severe thunderstorms interrupted the heat on the 30th.

Heat index values rose to around 105F in Southwest Indiana on the 3rd and 4th. Strong moisture advection raised dew points to 75F on the 3rd and up to 78F on the 4th. The highest observed heat index was 106F on the 3rd at the Evansville Regional Airport ASOS. Late afternoon thunderstorms in Southwest Indiana on the 3rd lowered heat indices for the evening while thunderstorms moved through Southwest Indiana during the morning on the 4th, temporarily delaying daytime heating.

With breezy southerly winds bringing dew points in the mid to upper 70s to Southeast Missouri under high pressure, heat indices in most of Southeast Missouri surged to 105-115F on the 14th and 15th, extending to the 16th at the Ripley County RAWS site near Doniphan. The highest observed heat index was 112F at the Cape Girardeau Regional Airport ASOS on the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across East Texas on the 3rd and 4th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees.

An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across North Louisiana on the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

An upper ridge of high pressure built back across the Southern Plains during mid-July, gradually expanding eastward into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s from July 15th through the 17th. Deep southerly moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees each afternoon across all of East and Northeast Texas.

Heat index values rose to around 105F in Southwest Indiana on the 3rd and 4th. Strong moisture advection raised dew points to 75F on the 3rd and up to 78F on the 4th. The highest observed heat index was 106F on the 3rd at the Evansville Regional Airport ASOS. Late afternoon thunderstorms in Southwest Indiana on the 3rd lowered heat indices for the evening while thunderstorms moved through Southwest Indiana during the morning on the 4th, temporarily delaying daytime heating.

Portions of Southern Illinois reached heat indices of 104-109F on the 29th, with more widespread heat indices of 105-116F on the 30th and 31st, extending into the start of August. Dew points reached the upper 70s on the 30th and 31st. The highest heat index reached in Southern Illinois was 116F at the Dixon Springs RAWS site on the 30th. Mid to late afternoon severe thunderstorms interrupted the heat on the 30th.

Portions of Southwest Indiana reached heat indices of 105-109F on the 30th and 31st, extending into the start of August. Dew points reached the upper 70s on the 30th and 31st. The highest heat index reached in Southwest Indiana was 109F at the Evansville Regional Airport ASOS on the 30th. Late morning and late afternoon rounds of severe thunderstorms interrupted the heat on the 30th.

Portions of Southwest Indiana reached heat indices of 105-109F on the 30th and 31st, extending into the start of August. Dew points reached the upper 70s on the 30th and 31st. Late morning and late afternoon rounds of severe thunderstorms interrupted the heat on the 30th.

Far Western Southwest Kentucky reached heat indices of 103-108F on the 29th, with more widespread heat indices of 105-117F throughout Western Kentucky on the 30th and 31st, extending into the start of August. Dew points reached the upper 70s on the 30th and 31st. The highest heat index reached in Southwest Kentucky was 121F at Murray-Calloway County Airport AWOS on the 30th. Late afternoon to early evening severe thunderstorms interrupted the heat on the 30th.

An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across North Louisiana on the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s through July 4th. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from July 1st to the 4th.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees through July 2nd. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon on July 1st and 2nd. However, with the front retreating back northeast away from East Texas, allowing for slightly drier air to mix down to the ground from the west on the 3rd-5th.

With breezy southerly winds bringing dew points in the mid to upper 70s to Southwest Kentucky under high pressure, heat indices in most of Southwest Kentucky surged to 103-111F on the 14th and 15th, extending to the 16th at the Murray-Calloway County Airport AWOS. The highest observed heat index was 111F at the Murray-Calloway County Airport AWOS on the 15th.

Heat indices of 105-114F were observed in much of Southern Illinois on the 3rd and 4th while the I-64 corridor only reached heat advisory criteria on the 4th. Strong moisture advection raised dew points to the mid to upper 70s both days. The highest observed heat index was 114F on the 4th at the Cairo Regional Airport AWOS. Late afternoon thunderstorms in Southern Illinois on the 3rd lowered heat indices for the evening while thunderstorms moved through Southern Illinois mid-morning on the 4th, temporarily delaying daytime heating.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across North Louisiana on the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

An upper level ridge that had been persistent across the Southern Plains to start the first several days of July finally began to shift off to the east, in response to an upper trough moving into the area. This trough allowed a weak cool front to slowly progress south through Southern Oklahoma, Western and Central Arkansas during the 5th, where increased large scale forcing and a moist, unstable air mass focused scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front. However, compressional warming occurred along and just south of the front over portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana, where temperatures were able to climb into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. When combined with the humidity, heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees. These storms gradually spread south into Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and extreme Northeast Texas during the afternoon of the 5th, resulting in cooler temperatures across extreme Northeast Texas and Southern Arkansas by mid-afternoon.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. However, with the front retreating back northeast away from East Texas, allowing for slightly drier air to mix down to the ground from the west on the 3rd-5th.

Heat indices of 105-115F were reached in much of Southwest Kentucky on the 3rd and 4th. Strong moisture advection raised dew points to the mid 70s to lower 80s both days. The highest observed heat index was 126F on the 4th at the Murray-Calloway County Airport AWOS, though dew points and heat indices may be overestimated at that site (elsewhere, a 115F heat index was observed at the Cadiz 4 SW Kentucky Mesonet site on the 4th). Thunderstorms on the 3rd generally held off until sunset for Western Kentucky while scattered afternoon thunderstorms developed on the 4th.

The highest observed heat index was 106F on the 3rd at the Evansville Regional Airport ASOS. Late afternoon thunderstorms in Southwest Indiana on the 3rd lowered heat indices for the evening while thunderstorms moved through Southwest Indiana during the morning on the 4th, temporarily delaying daytime heating.

Portions of Southern Illinois reached heat indices of 104-109F on the 29th, with more widespread heat indices of 105-116F on the 30th and 31st, extending into the start of August. Dew points reached the upper 70s on the 30th and 31st. The highest heat index reached in Southern Illinois was 116F at the Dixon Springs RAWS site on the 30th. Mid to late afternoon severe thunderstorms interrupted the heat on the 30th.

Heat indices of 105-115F were reached in much of Southwest Kentucky on the 3rd and 4th. Strong moisture advection raised dew points to the mid 70s to lower 80s both days. The highest observed heat index was 126F on the 4th at the Murray-Calloway County Airport AWOS, though dew points and heat indices may be overestimated at that site (elsewhere, a 115F heat index was observed at the Cadiz 4 SW Kentucky Mesonet site on the 4th). Thunderstorms on the 3rd generally held off until sunset for Western Kentucky while scattered afternoon thunderstorms developed on the 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across North Louisiana on the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s through July 4th. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from July 1st to the 4th.

The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from July 1st through the 4th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface on the 5th, resulting in lower heat indices of 105-109 degrees.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a weak surface front lifted back north before becoming stationary over Southeast Oklahoma and Central Arkansas on the 3rd and 4th, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, allowing temperatures to climb into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees through July 4th across the northern sections of Southwest Arkansas. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon.

An upper ridge of high pressure built back across the Southern Plains during mid-July, gradually expanding eastward into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s from July 15th through the 17th. Deep southerly moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees each afternoon across all of East and Northeast Texas.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the lower to middle 90s through July 2nd. With breezy southerly winds bringing dew points in the mid to upper 70s to Southeast Missouri under high pressure, heat indices in most of Southeast Missouri surged to 105-115F on the 14th and 15th, extending to the 16th at the Ripley County RAWS site near Doniphan. The highest observed heat index was 112F at the Cape Girardeau Regional Airport ASOS on the 15th.

With breezy southerly winds bringing dew points in the mid to upper 70s to Southeast Missouri under high pressure, heat indices in most of Southeast Missouri surged to 105-115F on the 14th and 15th, extending to the 16th at the Ripley County RAWS site near Doniphan. The highest observed heat index was 112F at the Cape Girardeau Regional Airport ASOS on the 15th.

Portions of Southern Illinois reached heat indices of 104-109F on the 29th, with more widespread heat indices of 105-116F on the 30th and 31st, extending into the start of August. Dew points reached the upper 70s on the 30th and 31st. The highest heat index reached in Southern Illinois was 116F at the Dixon Springs RAWS site on the 30th. Mid to late afternoon severe thunderstorms interrupted the heat on the 30th.

Heat indices of 105-115F were reached in much of Southwest Kentucky on the 3rd and 4th. Strong moisture advection raised dew points to the mid 70s to lower 80s both days. The highest observed heat index was 126F on the 4th at the Murray-Calloway County Airport AWOS, though dew points and heat indices may be overestimated at that site (elsewhere, a 115F heat index was observed at the Cadiz 4 SW Kentucky Mesonet site on the 4th). Thunderstorms on the 3rd generally held off until sunset for Western Kentucky while scattered afternoon thunderstorms developed on the 4th.

Heat indices of 105-114F were observed in much of Southern Illinois on the 3rd and 4th while the I-64 corridor only reached heat advisory criteria on the 4th. Strong moisture advection raised dew points to the mid to upper 70s both days. The highest observed heat index was 114F on the 4th at the Cairo Regional Airport AWOS. Late afternoon thunderstorms in Southern Illinois on the 3rd lowered heat indices for the evening while thunderstorms moved through Southern Illinois mid-morning on the 4th, temporarily delaying daytime heating.
Summer ridge heat pattern continued through late June and caused heat index values of 110-118 across the Coastal Bend and Brush Country.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Inland Kleberg observed heat index values of 110-114.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a weak surface front lifted back north before becoming stationary over Southeast Oklahoma and Central Arkansas on the 3rd and 4th, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, allowing temperatures to climb into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees through July 4th across the northern sections of Southwest Arkansas. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a weak surface front lifted back north before becoming stationary over Southeast Oklahoma and Central Arkansas on the 3rd and 4th, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, allowing temperatures to climb into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees through July 4th across the northern sections of Southwest Arkansas. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees through July 4th. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon from July 1st through the 4th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface on the 5th, resulting in lower heat indices of 105-109 degrees.

An upper ridge of high pressure built back southeastward from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region during late July. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s from July 29th through the 31st. Deep southerly moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees each afternoon across all of Southwest Arkansas.

An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across East Texas on the 3rd and 4th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across North Louisiana on the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the lower to middle 90s through July 2nd. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees each afternoon on July 1st and 2nd. However, the heat and humidity intensified by the afternoon of the 3rd and 4th as the front retreated back north, with heat indices surpassing 110 degrees.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees through July 2nd. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon on July 1st and 2nd. However, with the front retreating back northeast away from East Texas, allowing for slightly drier air to mix down to the ground from the west on the 3rd-5th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across North Louisiana on the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

An upper level ridge lingered over the Four State Region through the first several days of July, while at the surface, a stationary front persisted over Southeast Oklahoma into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana. Compressional warming along and just south of the front allowed temperatures to climb to the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across North Louisiana on the 5th. However, slightly drier air was able to mix down to the surface each afternoon, resulting in slightly lower heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees. This front eventually mixed back south through the region during the evening and overnight hours on the 5th-6th, with scattered showers and thunderstorms along the front helping to cool temperatures several degrees afterwards.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees through July 2nd. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each afternoon on July 1st and 2nd. However, with the front retreating back northeast away from East Texas, allowing for slightly drier air to mix down to the ground from the west on the 3rd-5th.

An upper ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first several days of July, before eventually sliding off to the east into the Mid-South and Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered from Southeast Oklahoma into extreme Southwest Arkansas and portions of North Louisiana, which aided in compressional heating and low level moisture pooling, with temperatures climbing into the lower to middle 90s through July 2nd. The moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees each afternoon on July 1st and 2nd. However, the heat and humidity intensified by the afternoon of the 3rd and 4th as the front retreated back north, with heat indices surpassing 110 degrees.

Far Western Southwest Kentucky reached heat indices of 103-108F on the 29th, with more widespread heat indices of 105-117F throughout Western Kentucky on the 30th and 31st, extending into the start of August. Dew points reached the upper 70s on the 30th and 31st. The highest heat index reached in Southwest Kentucky was 121F at Murray-Calloway County Airport AWOS on the 30th. Late afternoon to early evening severe thunderstorms interrupted the heat on the 30th.

Heat indices of 105-114F were observed in much of Southern Illinois on the 3rd and 4th while the I-64 corridor only reached heat advisory criteria on the 4th. Strong moisture advection raised dew points to the mid to upper 70s both days. The highest observed heat index was 114F on the 4th at the Cairo Regional Airport AWOS. Late afternoon thunderstorms in Southern Illinois on the 3rd lowered heat indices for the evening while thunderstorms moved through Southern Illinois mid-morning on the 4th, temporarily delaying daytime heating.

An upper ridge of high pressure built back southeastward from the Southern Plains across the Gulf Coast region during late July. Afternoon temperatures rose into the middle and upper 90s from July 29th through the 31st. Deep southerly moisture pooling resulted in minimal mixing of dewpoints, with attendant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees each afternoon across all of North Louisiana.

A ridge of high pressure over the Desert Southwest allowed for temperatures to climb well above normal on the 22nd and 23rd. The hottest temperatures occurred on the 22nd when Phoenix officially recorded a high of 102 degrees, which was 15 degrees above the daily normal high and 3 degrees short of the record high. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, three heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.
